caption:
We are a group of Canadian physicians from St. Michael’s Hospital who provide care to people who are pregnant and children in Toronto, Canada.
⠀
🤰🏻 Pregnant and postpartum individuals still require care during the COVID-19 pandemic. With fewer in-person prenatal visits, less one-on-one time with providers, cancellation of prenatal group classes, and restrictions to hospital visitors, expecting parents might feel increasingly anxious during this time. We are here for you.
⠀
▪️Our goal is to provide reliable medical information to help expecting parents feel well informed about their pregnancy and COVID-19.
⠀
Do you have any questions you’d like us to answer? Ask below!
⠀

caption:
This is a question that might be on the minds of many expecting parents. Swipe to see our response. We know that limiting support during labour, delivery, and postpartum is extremely stressful for parents and can significantly impact their childbirth experience. ⠀
⠀
Currently, hospitals are allowing one support person as long as you or they screen negative for COVID-19 (from survey done upon arrival). Each hospital’s policy will differ, so please ask ahead so you know what to expect when coming in to the hospital.⠀
⠀
While this uncertainty is so hard, you can take comfort in knowing that your care providers have your health and wellbeing at the heart of every decision they make. ⠀
⠀

caption:
Given that we are now doing more virtual visits, counting your baby’s movements can be a good way of checking in. In the last trimester of your pregnancy, your doctor may ask you to keep track of the baby’s movements every day. Just like you, your baby likes to be more active during certain times of the day. Usually, babies are more active in the evening making it a good time to do your counts.
⠀
When doing kick counts, having 6 movements in 2 hours or less is reassuring. Remember, when you’ve reached 6 movements, even if it’s in the first 30 minutes or hour, you can stop counting!
⠀
If you count less than 6 movements in 2 hours, don’t panic, but it is important for you to get in touch with your care provider or labour & delivery triage to see what you should do next.
⠀
There are lots of apps and worksheets on the web that can help you keep track of your counting. Which have you used and find helpful?
⠀

caption:
With the cancellation of in-person prenatal classes, we want to review one of the most important tips taught in prenatal classes ... “The 4-1-1 Rule.”
⠀
As you get closer to your due date, knowing when you’re in labour and when to go to the hospital is important. Often, the appropriate time to go to Labour & Delivery is when you’ve started active labour. The 4-1-1 Rule can help you decide if you’re there - contractions that are four minutes apart, each lasting around 1 minute, and this pattern happening for around 1 hour.
⠀
There are reasons to go in earlier or call ahead: your water breaking, vaginal bleeding, decreased fetal movement, or if you’re otherwise concerned. You know yourself best, so listen to your body and if you feel like it’s time to go…go.
⠀

caption:
Many of our followers have been asking about whether they should take their newborn for routine check-ups in the time of COVID-19.
⠀
We recommend the following schedule for well-child visits, based on the publication in the Canadian Family Physician journal by our very own Dr. @talibogler.
⠀
If possible, in-person visits in line with scheduled vaccines should take place. Delaying vaccines puts children at risk for common and serious childhood infections. As always, please discuss what is recommended for your child with your care provider.
⠀
If you have symptoms of a possible COVID19 infection, do not go to your appointment. Please call your doctor and see what you should do.
⠀
These guidelines are based on Canadian Paediatric Society recommendations to continue with routine vaccination during this pandemic. ⠀
Stay tuned for more #paediatrics and #newborn tips coming soon from the Deputy Chief of Pediatrics and Director of the the NICU at St. Michael's Hospital, Dr. @dougcampbell3672!
⠀
References:

1. Figure 1. Proposed interim schedule for well-child visits. Adapted from, Bogler T. Bogler O. Interim schedule for pregnant women and children during the COVID-19 pandemic. Blog Post. https://www.cfp.ca/news/2020/03/25/3-24.
⠀
2. https://www.cps.ca/en/documents/position/current-epidemiology-and-guidance-for-covid-19-march-2020

caption:
The tetanus, diphtheria, pertussis (Tdap) vaccine, otherwise known as the whooping cough vaccine, is recommended for all pregnant patients regardless of their vaccination history. This means that even if you have received this vaccine in the past, even in a previous and recent pregnancy, you should get it again. You should be getting this vaccine after 21 weeks’ gestation and at least 4 weeks before your due date.
⠀
When you receive this vaccination in pregnancy, your body makes antibodies that are passed on to your developing baby. When your baby is born, these antibodies will help their body defend against whooping cough, a very contagious illness that poses a serious risk to young babies. This will protect your baby until they can receive their own vaccine at 2 months of age.
⠀
When you see your care provider next, ask about the best way for you to get your Tdap vaccine. One option is to add it onto another visit if you happen to see your family doctor any time after 21 weeks, as most family physicians carry this vaccine in their office.
⠀
Where did you get your whooping cough vaccine during #COVID19? Please let us know in the comment section below!
⠀

caption:
Today we’re taking on a question we get asked about all the time in prenatal appointments!
⠀
Do I need to sleep in a certain position while pregnant? Is lying on my back unsafe?
⠀
The answer is, you can sleep in whatever position you like! We move into all different positions after we fall asleep anyways. There is no evidence of harm or risk to the growing fetus when you sleep on your back. We recommend you do whatever feels most comfortable for you.
⠀
Swipe through to see our detailed explanation.
⠀
Do you have any tips to share for getting a good night’s sleep while pregnant? Questions? Let us know in the comments below!
⠀
Reference: https://www.jogc.com/article/S1701-2163(16)32633-0/fulltext

caption:
Sarah, one of our medical students, spoke with Dr. Lee Schofield yesterday about guidelines for exercise in pregnancy. Dr. @tridoclee is a family physician who also practices low risk obstetrics and sports & exercise medicine at St. Michael’s Hospital and Pivot Sport Medicine and Orthopedics.
⠀
This is the second part of a three-part series. Part 2 and Part 3 follow a Q&A format. In this video, Dr. Schofield answers the following questions:
⠀
- If I want to start a new exercise routine in pregnancy, what are the recommendations and is it safe to start a new activity that I haven’t done before?
⠀
- Should I be wearing personal protective equipment (eg. a mask) if I exercise outside?
⠀
- Are core exercises safe during pregnancy? Does it depend on the stage of pregnancy?
⠀
- Can I do exercises lying on my back (in the supine position)?
⠀
We hope that this information can help you feel empowered and excited to exercise in your pregnancy. Remember to check with your care provider to make sure you don’t have any medical reasons to limit or restrict your exercise in pregnancy before starting a new routine!
⠀

caption:
Gestational diabetes is a type of diabetes that occurs during pregnancy. If untreated, it can increase the risk of pregnancy complications, including: a large baby, preeclampsia, and stillbirth. Therefore, it is important for all pregnant people to get screened for gestational diabetes between 24-28 gestational weeks, or earlier if their care provider determines they have risk factors for the condition.
⠀
The gold standard screening test is an Oral Glucose Challenge Test (OGCT). This test requires you to consume a standard 50-g sugar drink followed by a blood test 1 hour after. The current pandemic may make it more challenging to access this gold standard test. In response to reduced access or willingness to access hospitals and labs for the OGCT, the Society of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists of Canada (SOGC) has proposed alternative options for screening that will apply to some patients. To determine the best method of screening for you during #COVID19, you will need to have a discussion with your care provider.
⠀
Did you get an OGCT? What was the experience like for you?
⠀

caption:
As you know, some pregnancies deliver by cesarean section, a type of surgery that allows your baby to be delivered through the abdomen. We wanted to highlight a few important things to consider during your recovery.
⠀
In addition to the recommendations above, questions are often asked about climbing stairs and driving.
⠀
Stairs: We always recommend that you do what is comfortable. There are no restrictions to climbing stairs, just be careful not to exert yourself too much.
⠀
Driving: To test if you’ve recovered enough to drive safely, check in a parked car whether you are able to slam on the brakes without pain (in case you are in a situation where you need to stop suddenly while driving). Also practice looking back to check your blind spots without pain. You should not drive if you are taking narcotic (opioid) pain medications.
⠀
Always seek medical attention if you are concerned. Specific reasons that should prompt you to go to the emergency department or speak to your care provider include: heavy bleeding like a period, fever, signs of surgical site infection (persistent and worsening redness, warmth, pain to the touch, or foul-smelling/purulent discharge), persistent and worsening abdominal pain, and/or signs of a blood clot in your leg (one-sided swelling, redness, or pain in the calf region).
⠀
To all those parents who have had a cesarean section before, what tips do you have for the recovery period? Help out our parents-to-be in the comment section below!
⠀

caption:
Today, we’re going to discuss recovering from a vaginal delivery. While this is not a surgical procedure, your body still needs time and care to heal before you resume your normal activities. Check out our recommendations above to help guide you through a safe recovery, including some tips for perineal care.
⠀
You know your body best, and you should always seek medical attention if you are concerned. Specific reasons to go to the emergency department or speak to your care provider include: heavy bleeding like a period, fever, signs of surgical site infection (persistent and worsening redness, warmth, pain to the touch, or foul-smelling/purulent discharge), persistent/worsening abdominal pain, and/or signs of a blood clot in your leg (one-sided swelling, redness, or pain in the calf region). If you soak more than two pads in an hour or are passing clots larger than a golf ball, get in contact with your healthcare provider.
⠀
If you had stitches, you should follow the perineal care instructions. The stitches do not require any additional care and will absorb on their own over time. If you have concerns about their healing, please speak to your care provider.
⠀
For the first 24 hours after a vaginal delivery, we often recommend applying a popsicle pad to the perineum for 10-20 minutes every 1-2 hours. Popsicle pads can be made by running water on an open pad and leaving them open in the freezer until frozen.
⠀
To all those parents who have had a vaginal delivery before, what tips do you have for the recovery period? Please help out our parents-to-be in the comment section below!
⠀

caption:
Gestational hypertension (GHTN) is when you develop high blood pressure (BP) during pregnancy. It is a common condition, affecting 5% of all pregnancies.
⠀
You can develop GHTN even if you have never had high blood pressure before. Risk factors for developing GHTN include: previous history of high BP, personal or family history of high BP during pregnancy, first time pregnancy, and being <20 years old or >40 years old.
⠀
Generally, care providers will take your blood pressure at every appointment. Given that some prenatal appointments are now happening virtually, your provider may ask you to take your blood pressure at home.
⠀
If you develop GHTN, it is important for it to be managed by your care provider. If undiagnosed or untreated, it can progress to a more serious condition called preeclampsia. Preeclampsia presents as a combination of high blood pressure and signs or symptoms of organ dysfunction, most often in the liver or kidneys.
⠀
Preeclampsia can present with high blood pressure AND the following symptoms:
⠀
- Headache: Headache can resemble a migraine, characterized by a throbbing sensation and can be accompanied by nausea and photophobia (sensitivity to light) and/or phonophobia (sensitivity to sound). This headache does not resolve with acetaminophen (Tylenol) and can be a warning sign of a seizure.
⠀
- Visual changes: blurry vision, flashing light, spots
⠀
- Abdominal pain: right upper or central upper (epigastric) pain which may feel similar to heartburn but is not relieved with heartburn medication
⠀
It is very important for you to seek medical care if you develop symptoms of preeclampsia. Review the symptoms above.
⠀

caption:
Dr. Rachel Martin joined us to speak about how the medical management of pain during labour has changed during the #COVID19 pandemic. Dr. Martin is a staff anesthetist and the lead for obstetrical anesthesia at St. Michael’s Hospital.
⠀
In summary, nitrous oxide (laughing gas) is not being offered for labour pain currently in many hospitals and birthing centres. This is because its administration can potentially cause aerosolization of respiratory particles which can increase the risk of transmission of COVID19.
⠀
Dr. Martin also discussed epidurals for pain management in labour. In general, epidurals are safe for you and your baby, and provide effective pain management with few side effects. Another benefit of a labour epidural is that if a cesarean section is needed in an emergency, the epidural can be used for cesarean section and you can avoid having a general anesthetic, which is an aerosolizing procedure and thus can increase the risk of transmission of COVID19. It is important to note that due to COVID19, there are extra precautions that healthcare professionals have to take when providing general anesthesia and this can slow down the process and increase the risks to you and your baby. Therefore, an epidural can help facilitate delivering your baby as quickly as possible by cesarean section if needed.
⠀
What techniques and tips helped you manage pain in labour that might help our parents-to-be? Please share your thoughts in the comments below. ⠀
⠀

caption:
It is Canadian Infertility Awareness Week. 1 in 6 Canadians struggle with infertility. Despite infertility being a common issue, it can be difficult to discuss and many go through this journey feeling isolated and alone. The uncertainty created by paused fertility treatments during the #COVID19 pandemic adds an extra layer of stress during an already challenging time.
⠀
Thank you to everyone who has asked us about fertility treatment, we see you and hope that the following expert series can offer you some reassurance and helpful information.
⠀
During the pandemic, there have been a number of changes to fertility treatment in Canada based on public health recommendations. Yesterday, @drsheilaw had the opportunity to chat with Dr. @kaajalabrolmd, a reproductive endocrinology & infertility specialist at TRIO Fertility in Toronto. Dr. Abrol answered a number of questions, including:
⠀
- What is the state of fertility treatment in Canada during the COVID19 pandemic?
⠀
- What happens to those who have received provincial funding for fertility treatment?
⠀
- What are fertility clinics currently offering for their patients during the pandemic?
⠀
- What can for individuals waiting for fertility treatment do right now?
⠀
Fertility specialists are working together to find ways to best support their patients during this time. We realize that people who are experiencing infertility may not be following our account, so please share with those who may benefit. Dr. @kaajalabrolmd & @drsheilaw have added this video to their own accounts for those who understandably prefer not to visit our page.
⠀
If you or a loved one have had experience with infertility, what did you find most helpful or how did you support them? A resource for patients and those who support them can be found at @fertility_canada.

Swipe through to learn more about perinatal anxiety and generalized anxiety disorder.
⠀
Perinatal anxiety disorders are very common. Anxiety is often a very normal response to a major life change like pregnancy and becoming a parent. However, when anxiety becomes constant and difficult to control, it can cause significant distress.
⠀
Perinatal mental illness, including perinatal anxiety, is common and treatable. We also know that mental health symptoms may be heightened during a pandemic. Unfortunately, many people do not seek treatment because they feel guilt, shame, or dismiss their symptoms as normal worry that comes with being a new parent.
⠀
If you are worried that you have symptoms of perinatal anxiety, talk with your healthcare provider and with people in your life who you trust. You are not alone.

caption:
Today we’re taking on a question we get asked about all the time in prenatal appointments! “Can I drink coffee and other caffeinated beverages while pregnant?”
⠀
The answer is yes, but in moderation. Consuming less than than 200 mg of caffeine per day, across all sources of caffeine - including some chocolates, teas, and other foods and beverages - is safe. This generally translates to 1-2 small cups of coffee a day. As an example, a small Tim Horton’s coffee contains 140 mg of caffeine while a medium contains 205 mgs. A short Starbucks Medium Roast coffee contains 155 mg of caffeine while a tall contains 235 mg of caffeine.
⠀
It is also recommended for you to avoid energy drinks since they contain high amounts of caffeine and ingredients which have not been tested for their safety in pregnancy. ⠀
⠀
Caffeine can also contribute to or worsen symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux (heartburn), a condition which can develop or worsen in pregnancy. If you are experiencing these symptoms, it may be best to avoid or reduce your caffeine intake.
⠀
As a side note, although some herbal teas are decaffeinated, there are certain herbal teas which are not recommended during pregnancy. These include: Aloe, Buckthorn Bark, Chamomile, Coltsfoot, Comfrey, Duck Roots, Juniper berries, Labrador Tea, Lobelia, Pennyroyal, Sassafras, and Senna Leaves. Check with your care provider before consuming herbal tea.
⠀

caption:
We’ve received many questions about constipation in pregnancy. As you may have heard in our video with Pelvic Physiotherapist @jsnargi, constipation can contribute to pelvic pain in pregnancy.
⠀
Constipation can cause pain and discomfort if it goes untreated. Luckily, there are many easy steps you can take to prevent and treat constipation - swipe through our post to see.
⠀
We want to emphasize that although vitamin supplementation can contribute to constipation, people often require supplements like iron and calcium for their health in pregnancy. You should always consult your care provider before stopping a vitamin or supplement that they have recommended. If you are experiencing constipation that is not relieved with the steps we mention above, you should always talk to your care provider. Do not start any medications or laxatives to treat constipation without speaking to your physician first.
⠀
We hope that this post helps you better understand more about constipation in pregnancy and steps you can take to prevent/treat it.
⠀
Do you have more questions about constipation? What other common medical conditions in pregnancy do you want us to discuss next? Please let us know in the comments below!

caption:
This is a question that is best answered not by us, but by our followers! We’re getting things started with a few ideas, but please comment below to share tips for supporting expecting/new parents during the #COVID19 pandemic.
⠀
We are also aware that not everyone is going through pregnancy with a partner. These tips apply equally to family & friends who want to support a new/expecting parent.
⠀
Moreover, we recognize that the possibility of giving birth without a support person is distressing and upsetting. We want to emphasize that this is unlikely, while also acknowledging the reality of the current public health emergency & how it might impact you. For the most recent statement from the Society of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists of Canada regarding the presence of support people during labour: https://www.sogc.org/en/content/featured-news/A-Joint-Statement-on-the-Issue-of-Support-Persons-in-Labour-in-Canada.aspx.
⠀
For our recommendations around adding support people to the home during the pandemic, please refer to 3:45 of our video Q+A with Dr. Doug Campbell,  Expert Series 2 (Part 1) - Newborns and COVID-19, posted on April 10th.
⠀
Finally, an important message: if you are in a relationship where you feel unsafe, please tell someone you trust. We know that the risk of intimate partner violence (IPV) is heightened during pregnancy, and that rates are rising during the current pandemic. There are resources available to support you across Canada, some of which can be found at the following link: https://www.covidwi.com/get-help. We will be providing more information about IPV and supports available in the days ahead.
⠀
Reference: https://www.nytimes.com/article/pregnancy-birth-partner.html

caption:
You might be wondering, now that I’m pregnant, is it safe to have sex? As long as you have an uncomplicated pregnancy, it is generally considered safe to have oral, vaginal, and anal sex. Every pregnant person has different desires around sex during pregnancy and this can change throughout the course of your pregnancy.
⠀
When it comes to sex in pregnancy, there are a few things to avoid. You should never have vaginal sex right after anal sex as this can introduce bacteria that can potentially cause infection. Your partner should also never blow air into your vagina as the air can potentially enter a blood vessel and be harmful to your and your baby.
⠀
If you have had complications in your current or previous pregnancy, talk to your provider about whether sex is safe. Usually, avoiding sex is recommended for pregnant people who are at risk of preterm labour or who have certain conditions related to the placenta.
⠀
There is a small amount of evidence to suggest that sex close to your due date may help induce labour, but this practice is considered safe in people who have low-risk pregnancies.
⠀
Finally, after a vaginal or cesarean delivery, you should avoid inserting anything in your vagina for a period of at least 6 weeks. After that, you can resume sexual activity based on your level of comfort.
⠀
Reference: https://www.pregnancyinfo.ca/your-pregnancy/healthy-pregnancy/sex-and-pregnancy/
⠀

caption:
Content warning: Miscarriage, pregnancy loss.
⠀
We want to shed light on an experience that is very common and not often talked about. Miscarriage occurs in 15-20% of pregnancies. Miscarriage is usually a very difficult and upsetting event in a person’s life. It is normal to feel grief, loss, and other difficult emotions in response.
⠀
The current pandemic can cause people to feel more isolated and unsure of where to go for support or care in the event of a miscarriage. We have listed some places to seek care if you think you might be having a miscarriage and will also be sharing some these resources and more in our stories.
⠀
If you have vaginal bleeding or other symptoms of miscarriage as listed above, it is important to inform your care provider to make sure everything is ok. However, we also want to emphasize that vaginal bleeding in pregnancy is not always due to miscarriage. About ⅓ of pregnant people have some bleeding before the 20th week, and about half of those pregnancies continue without any further problems.
⠀
To those of you who have experienced or are experiencing miscarriage, we want you to know that you are seen and that there are many supports available to you. Please swipe through our post or check out our stories to see some recommended resources.
⠀
Image source: https://www.clipart.email/

caption:
Two out of 1,000 babies have hearing loss at birth. This can impact their ability to learn speech and language and can lead to challenges in behaviour and emotional regulation. Because we have early intervention options for hearing loss, it is important to identify hearing loss as soon as possible. The Ontario Infant Hearing Program (IHP) provides screening for all newborns <9 weeks of age to identify those with permanent hearing loss to support their language development.
⠀
Given the current #COVID19 pandemic, the IHP is postponing in-person hearing screening appointments until further notice. This is understandably stressful but please be reassured that the IHP continues to receive referrals from hospitals and midwives and should contact you within a week of birth. Currently, babies are being placed on a waiting list to be seen once services resume.
⠀
The risk factor screening done through blood work will continue during COVID-19 and babies who screen positive will be referred for further medical and audiological follow-up.
⠀
If you do not hear from the Infant Hearing Program within a week of discharge from the hospital, you are encouraged to call your regional program. The locations can be found at: http://www.children.gov.on.ca/htdocs/English/earlychildhood/hearing/index.aspx#locations.
⠀
Residents of Toronto are encouraged to use Toronto Public Health’s booking system to be contacted by a Hearing Screener in the future for information regarding next steps. The link for the booking system can be found here: https://www.tphbookings.ca/Default.aspx?PageID=11230
⠀

caption:
Group B streptococcus (GBS) is a common bacteria found in the urinary system, rectum, and vagina of approximately 15-40% of people. Typically, if you have GBS, you do not have symptoms or an infection because it is part of the normal bacteria in these areas of your body. However, if GBS is present in pregnancy, it can be passed onto the baby during birth and cause a rare but serious infection unless antibiotics are given during labour and delivery.
⠀
The presence of this bacteria can come and go. All pregnant people are usually screened for GBS between 35-37 weeks’ gestation (during one of their in-person visits) to detect if the bacteria is there around the time of delivery. You may be tested earlier if you go into labour or your water breaks before 35 weeks of pregnancy. Screening involves swabbing the opening of the vagina and rectum with a cotton-tipped swab. The swab is then tested to check if GBS is present (a positive test). If GBS was found in a urine test done before 35 weeks, this is also a positive test and you do not need to be swabbed.
⠀
If you test positive for GBS, it doesn't mean that you're ill or that your baby will be affected. It simply means the potential for newborn infection exists. It is recommended that individuals who test positive receive antibiotics during labour to decrease the chance of the baby developing an infection.
⠀
Please discuss with your care provider to determine when screening for GBS would be best for you. Remember to remind your care team about your GBS status during labour.
⠀

caption:
Today we want to answer some frequently asked questions around Prenatal Screening in Ontario.
⠀
Prenatal screening includes tests that can be done in pregnancy to determine the chance of having a baby with chromosomal differences such as trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) or trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome).
⠀
To help decide if prenatal screening is right for you, swipe to read suggested questions to ask yourself from Prenatal Screening Ontario, such as “How would knowing or not knowing affect you emotionally throughout the pregnancy?”
⠀
If you decide that prenatal screening is right for you, the most common prenatal screening tests performed in Ontario are done within certain time windows including:
⠀
Enhanced first trimester screening (eFTS): 11-14 weeks gestation
Maternal serum screening (MSS): 14-21 weeks gestation
Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT): after 10 weeks gestation
⠀
Swipe to read more about the specific tests available and the current policies around prenatal screening during #COVID19 in Ontario.
⠀
We encourage you read more about prenatal screening and the specific tests at www.prenatalscreeningontario.ca. Speak to your provider about which options are available in your region and appropriate for you.
⠀

caption:
Welcome back to prenatal class! Today, we will be focusing on an experience that about 40-80% of people can have in pregnancy: nausea and vomiting.
⠀
These symptoms can be experienced at any time in the day or night. Nausea and vomiting usually occurs from 6 to 14 weeks’ gestation, but it can last throughout pregnancy for some.
⠀
The physical and hormonal changes that your body goes through during pregnancy are thought to cause these symptoms. Mild nausea and vomiting is not harmful to you or your baby.
⠀
Even though these symptoms can be a normal part of pregnancy, the discomfort can be challenging. Swipe to read helpful tips for easing the symptoms. Keep in mind that everyone and every pregnancy is different.
⠀
If these tips are not relieving your nausea, please speak to your healthcare provider. There are several anti-nausea medications that are prescribed in pregnancy.
⠀
We would love to hear what has worked for you or someone you know who experienced nausea and vomiting during pregnancy?
⠀

caption:
NOTE: We have removed our previous post as it originally had the black lives matter hashtag and we do not want to deter from the amazing work being done using this hashtag.
⠀
This week, we are working to share information about black maternal health, amplify melanated voices, and share anti-Black racism resources.
⠀
This week and every week, we stand as allies to the Black community in rejecting racism and the continued violence towards Black people in Canada and internationally.
⠀
We are participating in the #amplifymelanatedvoices challenge created by @blackandembodied and @jessicawilson.msrd because we are committed to providing you with the best possible prenatal care. The best possible prenatal care includes recognizing that racial inequities lead to disparities in maternal health and educating ourselves on how we can do better to actively practice anti-racism.
⠀
To our followers who continue to face oppression: we see you.
⠀

caption:
As we resume posting informative content for our Pandemic Pregnancy Guide community, we are reflecting on how we can strengthen our commitment to being allies to the Black community and take action against anti-Black racism in Canada and around the world.
⠀
In addition to continuing to educate ourselves on the structural racism that exists in our healthcare system, we are committed to featuring more Black voices and issues in our content. Please stay tuned for upcoming speaker sessions with Emergency Room Physician Dr. Teela Johnson, Chiropractor Dr. Nekessa Remy @dr.nekessaremy, and Psychologist Dr. Stacy Thomas @drstacytoronto

As healthcare providers, we are committed to recognizing our own power and privilege and using it to listen to, and work directly with members of the Black community. We are committed to advocating for the collection of race-based data in order to start working towards addressing how anti-Black racism leads to disparities in Black maternal health.

Our team at PPG has donated funds to Black Health Alliance (@blackhealthcan), Women’s Health in Women’s Hands (@whiwhchc), and Ocama Collective (@ocamacollective) to support their excellent work. Look out for our story for some more incredible organizations you can contribute to.

caption:
Prenatal classes can help give you confidence as birth approaches. No matter the format or topic, prenatal classes aim to help you feel prepared for the upcoming months of your life. You and your birthing partner(s) can benefit from learning as much as possible about labour, delivery, and transitioning into parenthood. If this is not your first delivery, you may still find a refresher course helpful.

Unfortunately, the COVID-19 pandemic has limited expecting parents’ access to in-person classes. Thankfully, there are some classes that are now being offered virtually. We have included a list of publicly funded (*there may still be a fee)programs that are offering virtual prenatal classes at this time (link in bio.) caption:
A stretch and sweep is an optional procedure offered by your care provider between 38 and 41 weeks gestation. This procedure may help to initiate the start of your labour. It is commonly offered to patients who are approaching or already past their due date, and requires that the cervix is already partially opened (a sign that your body is getting ready for labour). A stretch and sweep may also prevent the need for a medical induction if your baby is overdue.
⠀
Your care provider will discuss with you the benefits and risks of having a stretch and sweep. Done in the clinic, hospital, or home, this procedure involves the use of a gloved finger to separate the amniotic sac from the cervix during a vaginal examination. This process will cause your body to release a natural substance called prostaglandins, which help to prepare your cervix for labour. You may experience symptoms of pain during the procedure, and spotting or cramping after the procedure which are normal. However, if you experience fluid leaking or heavy bleeding (very rare), call your care provider.
⠀
Although a stretch and sweep can increase your chances of going into labour, how soon this occurs will depend on how ready your body is for labour. If you still do not go into labour, your care provider may repeat a stretch and sweep or recommend a medical induction. They will discuss the best option for you depending on the risks and benefits for you and your baby.
⠀

Today we’re talking about a common question people ask when pregnant...
⠀
“Should I be eating for two?”
⠀
The short answer is no. The long answer is that additional energy demands vary with respect to trimester, as well as personal patient factors (i.e. if you are carrying multiples). Typically, additional energy demands are negligible in the first trimester, approximately 350 kcal/day in the second trimester, and 500 kcal/day in the third trimester. An extra 350 calories may look like 2 eggs (~75 cal/egg), 1 piece of multigrain toast (~120 cal), and 1 banana (~80 cal). 500 calories may look like that, plus half of an avocado (~150-160 cal).
⠀
Rather than eating for TWO, try eating TWICE as healthy to provide yourself and your baby with the nutrients you both need!
⠀
Why is it important to ensure you are eating healthy amounts? Weight gain during pregnancy is an important and modifiable risk factor for you and your baby’s health - both excessive and inadequate weight may have adverse effects. Swipe through for more details on suggested weight gain, and check out Health Canada’s easy-to-use Pregnancy Weight Gain Calculator - link in bio!
⠀
Stay tuned for our upcoming interview with a registered dietician discussing healthy eating and weight gain in pregnancy!
⠀
Do you have other questions or tips regarding prenatal nutrition? Let us know in the comments below!
⠀
Note: Consult your provider to determine what is safest and healthiest for YOU, taking into account your own physical, psychosocial and cultural factors, as well as eating habits.

caption:
Today, we will be focusing on how to create a safe sleep environment for your newborn. We list 7 recommendations that can be done to help lower your baby’s risk of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS) and other sleep related causes of injury or death. SIDS is a condition where a seemingly healthy baby unexpectedly passes away, usually in their sleep. SIDS is the second leading cause of death in healthy newborns.
⠀
Some of these recommendations include placing your baby on his or her back to sleep, providing a firm and flat sleep surface, ensuring your baby lives in a smoke-free environment and breastfeeding your newborn for any length of time.
⠀
A safe sleep environment is essential for your newborn’s physical and emotional well-being. Swipe right to learn more about these recommendations.
⠀
For more information about safe sleep environments for newborns please visit https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/health-promotion/childhood-adolescence/stages-childhood/infancy-birth-two-years/safe-sleep.html.
⠀

caption:
Today we are talking about skin-to-skin contact. This a practice in which a baby is laid directly on their parent/caregiver’s bare chest following birth until at least one hour after birth, or until after the first feed. Skin-to-skin contact can be used whenever your baby needs a feed or to be comforted, and the recommendation is at least 60 consecutive minutes daily when possible. One silver lining of COVID-19 is that there might be increased family time in the home and therefore, more opportunity for skin-to-skin. 
While often called ‘kangaroo mother care’, it can certainly be performed by the partner/support person - helping them bond with baby as well.

Skin-to-skin contact has many benefits for both babies and parents/caregivers alike. This practice helps babies adapt to life outside the womb, strengthens the parent/caregiver-baby relationship, helps with the initiation of breastfeeding, and promotes babies’ physical and neurological development. Swipe through this post to read more about skin-to-skin contact and its benefits!

caption:
Skin changes can occur during pregnancy including: acne, hyperpigmentation, and increased sensitivity. There are also many skin care options on the market to choose from. Today, we cover which skin care ingredients to avoid, which to use with caution, and which are safe to use during pregnancy.
⠀
Many skin care ingredients can be absorbed through the skin and some products contain strong and/or high concentrations of active ingredients. It is important for everyone to be able to take care of their skin without compromising the health of their baby.
⠀
Research on the effects of skin care ingredients on the pregnant population is limited. However, there are some general recommendations based on animal studies and skin absorption studies.
⠀
The main ingredients to avoid are topical and oral retinoids (found in acne and anti-aging products), hydroquinone (found in skin brightening products), parabens, and antibiotics in the tetracycline family.
⠀
Swipe right to find out more!
⠀
What else would you like to know about skin care during pregnancy? Comment below to let us know!
⠀

caption:
Have you been wondering if it really matters how much weight you gain during pregnancy?

Check out our first interview with Registered Dietitian, Sherri Storm. Cheyanne, one of our medical students, had the chance to ask Sherri to address common concerns around why and how weight can change in pregnancy and postpartum. Sherri was also able to share tools and strategies you can consider using depending on your experiences. In this video we want to emphasize that as your body goes through changes during pregnancy, every pregnancy and each person’s body is different and that is okay! 
Sherri works as a Registered Dietitian and Certified Diabetes Educator in the Prenatal Clinic @smhobgyn, Diabetes in Pregnancy Clinic and Family Practice Department at St. Michael’s Hospital. She has been working in these areas for over 10 years.
⠀
You can skip ahead to these timestamps for specific topics:

caption:
90% of pregnant people are iron deficient.
⠀
Talk to your healthcare provider about iron and how much you may need. In general, your iron intake should increase to 27mg per day in the final 6 months of pregnancy. Because prenatal vitamins contain calcium and magnesium which interfere with iron absorption, most pregnant people cannot get enough iron from their prenatal vitamin alone. For these reasons, a separate iron supplement is often recommended. Please speak to your own healthcare provider to discuss what supplement would be appropriate for you. As iron deficiency in pregnancy can lead to potential problems for pregnant people and their babies, appropriate iron supplementation is important for the prevention of these potential issues.
⠀
Three helpful tips to maximize your iron absorption include 1) taking your oral iron supplements with orange juice/lemon water either at bedtime OR 1-2 hours before/after coffee, tea, and calcium supplements, 2) eating foods rich in vitamin C, and 3) maintaining an iron-rich diet.
⠀
Swipe to read more about the side effects that you may experience with taking oral iron supplements. We recommend that you discuss with your healthcare provider what supplement may be best and how to manage any side effects.
⠀

caption:
Pregnancy and becoming a parent are major life changes. While it can be normal to feel anxious during these times of transition, unmanaged anxiety or depression can cause significant distress. During the COVID-19 pandemic, symptoms of depression and anxiety are heightened and many feel isolated. While perinatal mental health conditions are common and treatable, many do not seek support because they may feel guilt or shame and dismiss their symptoms as normal changes that come with being a new parent.
⠀
If you need extra support during this time, talk with your healthcare provider and with people in your life who you trust. You are not alone.
⠀
In this post, we list some resources you can find online, on Instagram, and in Toronto. The links to the resources can be found under “Perinatal and Postpartum Mental Health Resources” through the linktree in our bio.
⠀
Swipe to find out more about the resources available for perinatal mental health.
⠀
Have you found mental health resources that have helped you? Please share in the comments below.

caption:
Prenatal Class Tip #8: Breech Position and Breech Birth
⠀
What are breech position and breech birth?
In about 4% of births, the baby does not naturally turn to be head-down. Rather, the baby is head-up, in a breech position. Swipe to see more on the three main breech positions, how breech position is diagnosed, and delivery options for breech babies.
⠀
If your baby is breech, consult with your care provider to determine the best care plan and mode of delivery for you.

caption:
During pregnancy, there are certain considerations to keep in mind when choosing what you eat. Food safety is important during pregnancy as your immune system changes which can make you and your baby more susceptible to infections. Food poisoning during pregnancy can lead to uncomfortable symptoms but in rare but serious cases, it can lead to complications such as miscarriage, premature birth, or stillbirth.
⠀
In this post, we cover what food poisoning is, signs and symptoms, the risks during pregnancy, foods to avoid, food alternatives, and tips for shopping, food handling, and cleanliness.
⠀
Bottom line: Perishable foods should be treated with extra care. When you are unsure if the food is safe to eat, avoid consuming it.
⠀
Please note that the information we have provided is a general list of recommendations. Different regions of the world have different standards and regulations. For more information, please consult your care provider.
⠀
Stay tuned for separate upcoming content about sushi in pregnancy!
⠀
Do you have questions regarding food safety during pregnancy? Let us know in the comments below.

caption:
While we are loving the warmer weather of summer, it’s important to also take note of the heat warnings being issued so that everyone can enjoy the sunny weather in a safe manner. In this post, we are discussing the importance of taking precautions during heat waves while pregnant.
⠀
Warmer weather can affect certain populations more than others. The pregnant population is especially more vulnerable to overheating due to several factors, including the metabolic demands from your developing baby, and the work your body does to cool down both you and your baby. High temperatures can carry risks of dehydration, which can lead to dizziness and falling. Several studies have also described an association between heat exposure and an increased risk of adverse outcomes, such as preterm birth and low birth weight. There are many ways to stay safe and stay cool in the warm weather. Swipe right to find out more.
⠀
Bottom line: Take necessary precautions, be proactive in the heat (hydrate frequently and plan out your time outdoors), recognize the symptoms of overheating, and take action when you need to cool off.
⠀
Stay tuned for upcoming content about sunscreen!
⠀
Do you have more questions about staying safe in the heat? Let us know in the comments below!

caption:
⠀
⠀
We’ve talked about pelvic floor health before and during pregnancy, but what about in the postpartum period and beyond?
⠀
In this series, Xin, one of our medical students, interviews Kim Vopni (the @VaginaCoach) about common postpartum problems. In the first video of this series, we focused on urinary incontinence: the different types, the causes, and great tips that can help you on your postpartum journey.
⠀
Urinary incontinence is the involuntary loss of urine that can occur at any stage in life and can affect one’s quality of life. It is very commonly experienced in the first few days to weeks postpartum, affecting approximately 33% of individuals during the first 3 months. There are several risk factors for incontinence, including but not limited to: age, obesity, number of deliveries, family history, and smoking history. It is also possible to have incontinence after a Caesarean delivery. The good news: incontinence can get better, or completely resolve with time and with the tips Kim suggests.
⠀
Kim is a restorative exercise specialist and a certified pre/post natal fitness consultant. Kim has created extensive content, such as exercise programs and books to help everyone learn about and connect with their pelvic floor health and the changes that may come with giving birth.
⠀
Stay tuned for the next two videos in this ‘Common Postpartum Problems’ series on pelvic pain and prolapse with Kim Vopni!
⠀

caption:
Every child needs sun protection. This includes (1) applying sunscreen, (2) wearing lightweight sun-protective clothing and (3) avoiding the sun when UV rays are strongest. Too much sun exposure can cause severe sunburns, blisters, dehydration, heat stroke, shivering, and fever. Too much sun exposure in the long term can also lead to skin damage and skin cancer.
⠀
Learn more about how we can better protect our babies/kids from the sun this summer.
⠀

caption:
Have you ever wondered what a low-lying placenta or a placenta previa means?
⠀
The placenta is an organ that develops on the inside wall of the uterus to provide blood, oxygen and nutrients to the developing baby. The placenta can attach on any surface of the uterus. In some pregnancies, the placenta attaches lower down in the uterus (within 2cm of the cervix), which is also known as a low-lying placenta. A placenta previa is when the placenta covers part or all of the cervix.
⠀
Low-lying placenta and placenta previa can occur in as many as 1 out of 3 pregnancies before 20 weeks.The reassuring news: the majority of these placentas will move away from the cervix and lower uterine segment by the third trimester as the uterus grows. Approximately 1 in 200 pregnancies having persistent placenta previa at full term.
⠀
If the placenta is covering the cervix or there are large blood vessels crossing over the cervix at the time of labor, there is a risk of significant bleeding and early separation of the placenta from the uterus. Additionally, some patients with placenta previa may experience vaginal bleeding prior to 37 weeks of pregnancy which can increase the risk of a premature delivery and subsequent low birth weight.
⠀
Swipe to read more about the risk factors, symptoms, diagnosis, and management of low-lying placenta and placenta previa.
⠀

caption:
⠀
⠀
In this series, Xin, one of our medical students, interviews Kim Vopni (the @VaginaCoach) about common postpartum problems. In this second video of the series, we focus on pelvic pain: the different types, the causes, and great tips that can help you on your postpartum journey.
⠀
Pelvic pain can occur during pregnancy, and can persist in approximately 40% of people. There can also be new-onset pelvic pain in about 7% of people after childbirth. The symptoms of pelvic pain vary, ranging from cramps to pain involving the entire abdomen. There are many different causes during pregnancy and the postpartum period, including but not limited to: the growth of the fetus, stiffness of pelvic joints, tension in the pelvic floor, being overweight, and having a history of lower back and/or pelvic girdle pain. So many people suffer in silence, but there is help available. 
⠀
Kim Vopni is a restorative exercise specialist and a certified pre/post natal fitness consultant. Kim has created extensive content, such as exercise programs and books to help everyone learn about and connect with their pelvic floor health and the changes that may come with giving birth.

caption:
Today, we address the common misconception that breastfeeding parents need to avoid certain foods. We discuss the importance of consuming a variety of nutritious foods while breastfeeding and following Eating Well with Canada’s Food Guide (link in bio). There is limited evidence to suggest that following a modified diet that eliminates certain foods or food groups while breastfeeding can help with infant colic, gas, or the development of an allergy in your child.

In this post, we also go over some general nutrition based recommendations for the breastfeeding parent. Some of these recommendations include consuming 2-3 extra food servings per day, increasing your fluid intake, taking a multivitamin (often the same prenatal vitamin you were taking in pregnancy) and limiting high mercury fish.
⠀
Swipe right to learn more about these recommendations and breastfeeding nutrition. We encourage you to consult a registered dietician or your healthcare provider to find a breastfeeding nutrition plan that is right for you.

caption:
Towards the end of pregnancy, your body prepares for labour and delivery by softening and opening the cervix. In some pregnancies, however, labour does not start on its own, and may need to be induced. Induction of labour refers to the use of medical or mechanical techniques to prepare for a vaginal delivery by artificially softening and opening the cervix to initiate contractions.
⠀
When the risks of continuing the pregnancy are greater than the risks of delivering, induction of labour is considered. More than 1 in 5 labours is induced, so induction of labour is common.
⠀
Swipe to read more about the reasons for needing an induction of labour and the different methods of induction...
⠀
Check out our link in bio to watch a video that provides further information on the techniques for induction of labour!

caption:
You may have heard of terms like Rh, antibodies, or RhoGAM thrown around during your pregnancy and you may be wondering, what does all of this mean? Read through this post to learn about the RhoGAM injection and why your Rh status is important in your pregnancy.
⠀
Rh is a protein that may or may not be present on the surface of your red blood cells. It is present in 85% of people. Early on in your pregnancy, you will take a routine blood test to determine whether you are Rh-positive or Rh-negative. If you are Rh-negative, you may be given an injection called RhoGAM. This injection is vital in preventing you from developing antibodies that may ‘attack’ your baby’s Rh proteins in subsequent pregnancies.
⠀
Swipe for more information on why you may be a candidate for the RhoGAM shot, when and where RhoGAM is administered, and its side effects. RhoGAM is an essential medication during pregnancy and administration has not changed in relation to the COVID-19 pandemic.
⠀
What other questions do you have about prenatal care? Write to us in the comments below!
⠀

caption:
Breastfeeding was one of THE hardest things I’ve ever done and also one of my greatest accomplishments. It was tough… my twin girls were born premature but I managed to exclusively breastfeed with the help of an amazing lactation consultant (@sofyabrainin) and support from my partner and family.
⠀
For the first few months, I used nipple shields and I had to build up my supply to provide enough milk for two babies (I pumped after each feed for quite a while). I developed mastitis (an infection due to blocked ducts, nipple shields, oversupply, etc.) not once, but twice, and was quite sick as a result. The worst part about mastitis was that my supply plummeted and I had to rebuild my supply all over again. Despite these setbacks, I was determined to keep going.
⠀
We had such a good rhythm with breastfeeding that when I eventually wanted to introduce bottles, they wouldn’t take them! So it was me, my twins, my twin breastfeeding pillow, and my breasts for several months. To maintain my supply, I was drinking TONS of water, herbs (fenugreek and blessed thistle), and was making sure my calorie intake was adequate. I absolutely LOVED breastfeeding my girls but it was also all-consuming for me.
⠀
I learned to breastfeed in tandem… it was really the only way with twins, but it was tricky to do so in public, especially since you sort of need to completely undress and I always needed a breastfeeding pillow to prop them up. It was really hard when I compared myself to moms with just one baby who could just breastfeed anywhere and had a lot more freedom.
⠀
I breastfed until the girls were about 15-18 months… I was sad when they eventually weaned off the breast themselves, but it also happened so organically. Once they stopped, it gave me back some freedom.
⠀
At the end of the day, I think it’s important to emphasize that breastfeeding is difficult for many people. Some of my patients struggle to continue breastfeeding, some continue to exclusively pump, some have chosen not to breastfeed at all, and some may not even have the option of breastfeeding due to health reasons.
⠀
Bottom line: no matter what your feeding journey is, we are here to support you.

Some parents may choose not to breastfeed, may be unable to breastfeed, or may experience challenges with breastfeeding. In these situations, commercial infant formulas are the only safe and acceptable alternative to breast milk. This is because infant formula is designed to resemble breast milk nutrient composition and digestibility.
⠀
There are many different types of formula, including cow’s milk-based, soy, hydrolyzed, elemental and specialized formulas. Regardless of which kind of formula you use, ensure it is iron-fortified.
⠀
In addition, formula is packaged in three main forms: (1) powder, (2) liquid concentrate, and (3) ready to feed. No one packaging formulation is 'best' - choose a formulation that works best for you, your infant and your lifestyle.
⠀
*Note: Because powdered formula is not sterile, babies under two months of age, premature babies and not yet two months past their expected due date, and babies who have a compromised immune system should only be given concentrated liquid or ready-to-feed formula.
⠀
Swipe through this post to read more about which type of formula and which packaging formulation may be best for you and your infant.
⠀
We realize the decision to breastfeed or formula feed your baby is an incredibly personal one. If you feel comfortable, please share your experiences in the comments below so we can learn from each other.
⠀

caption:
Breastfeeding did not come easy for me. I knew it was going to be hard, but I didn't really understand all of the emotions and mom guilt that would come along with it.
⠀
It took several days for my milk to come in and then when it did, I was in so much pain. There were hot showers, stinky cabbage leaves, and struggling to figure out a brand new pump. This was all combined with recovering from a difficult vaginal delivery.
⠀
My first child and I really struggled with breastfeeding. We were at either the lactation consultant or the pediatrician almost every day that first month. I had friends using herbal supplements, but I knew if I was going to succeed, I needed to pull out the big guns so I went right to the maximum dose of domperidone when Jack was only a few days old. I was so exhausted that when people talked to me about trying tube feeding, I knew I wouldn't be able to make it work and that would throw me over the breastfeeding ledge. As a result, I started cup feeding formula to top him off after breastfeeding.
⠀
It took me the full month for Jack to get back to his birth weight. I remember when the pediatrician told me I didn't have to come back for a month, I asked her what I would do with myself. She told me to "find some friends". I continued to breastfeed for 4.5 months, at which point I was going back to work and knew I wouldn't have the time or flexibility to pump so I switched over to formula. I kept up with the domperidone until I weaned because I was so afraid to come off and struggle again.
⠀
At the end of the day, I think it’s important to emphasize that breastfeeding is difficult for many people. Some of my patients struggle to continue breastfeeding, some continue to exclusively pump, some have chosen not to breastfeed at all, and some may not even have the option of breastfeeding due to health reasons.
⠀
Bottom line: no matter what your feeding journey is, we are here to support you.
⠀

tags: coronavirus, breastfeeding, COVID19, feedingyourbaby, primarycare, pandemicpregnancy, postpartum, obstetrics, pushingthroughthepandemic, duedateduringthepandemic, breastfeedingsupport

caption:
I remember lying in the delivery room after our first, Layla, feeling completely overwhelmed with emotion and exhaustion. Her little weight on my chest was incredibly humbling and when she was first put on my breast, my feeding worries melted away...for a moment. Through our hospital stay, despite the support of our kind nurses, I was unable to produce anything and when her blood sugar dropped, we decided to give her some formula. This is the first time I felt shame that my body was unable to produce what she needed. I felt this a lot in her first year. Despite visits to lactation clinics, herbs and breastfeeding cookies (lots of cookies), my supply was never enough to meet her needs so we did a combo of formula+pumped milk. I felt an internal pressure for her to have breastmilk, so I would pump several times a day. I remember crying over an oz. of pumped milk that was left out and discarded because it had taken so much effort to make. Even if it was just an oz. here and there, it felt like it qualified me to be her mom.
⠀
After months of pumping, it was Layla's doctor who saw the effect it was having on my mental health. She saw what I couldn't see myself, in the form of postpartum anxiety. The time spent pumping and sleep loss was taking a toll and she gave me what I could not give myself, permission to stop. At 8 months, we transitioned Layla onto formula. With Myles, my milk came in more easily but when my mental health started to shift, I decided to stop pumping at 5 months and transitioned him fully to formula.
⠀
In retrospect, the amount of breastmilk our kids were receiving was very little. Both of our beautiful and healthy kids, now 3 and 9 months are doing awesome and I now see that the time spent away from them to pump could have been spent being with them (or sleeping). When you're in the thick of it though, it's hard to see clearly when obscured by guilt.
⠀
Parents face a lot of external (and internal) pressure for every decision we make. This is hard stuff. Let's support each other with kindness, especially during this pandemic when things are more difficult.
⠀
Sending love to all of you whatever your feeding journey is. We are here to support you.

caption:
Jaundice is the yellow discolouration that can be seen in the skin, the whites of the eyes, and the gums. It is a very common condition in newborns, presenting in 60% of term babies and 80% of preterm babies. Approximately 5% of jaundiced babies require treatment. 

The cause of jaundice due to a high level of an orange-yellow pigment called bilirubin in the blood. Jaundice is common and will generally clear on its own. In rare circumstances, there is a risk of complications when the levels of bilirubin are too high, untreated, and/or rising rapidly.

Swipe to learn more about jaundice in newborns: when and how screening and diagnosis is done, the risks, and the treatments. 

If you suspect jaundice in your newborn, please contact your healthcare provider or visit your local hospital.

Do you have more questions about neonatal jaundice? Let us know in the comments below.

caption:
⠀
⠀
In this third video of our ‘Common Postpartum Problems’ series, Xin, one of our medical students, interviews Kim Vopni (the @VaginaCoach) about pelvic organ prolapse: the different types, the causes, and tips that can help you on your postpartum journey. You don’t want to miss this segment - Kim uses some great visual aids to help describe the different types of prolapse.
⠀
Pelvic organ prolapse (POP) occurs when organs, such as the bladder and uterus, descend from their anatomical position and push against or out of the walls of the vagina. It is possible for more than one organ to prolapse. POP occurs due to weakened and/or stretched pelvic floor muscles that normally hold your pelvic organs in place.
⠀
POP can occur immediately after childbirth or over time. Risk factors for prolapse include, but are not limited to: family history of prolapse, smoking history, connective tissue disease, operative vaginal delivery using vacuum or forceps, and increased pressure in your belly such as frequent constipation or obesity. Although POP is strongly associated with vaginal deliveries, having a Cesarean delivery without labour does not fully protect against the incidence of POP. Up to half of previously pregnant individuals have some degree of clinical POP, of which approximately 10-20% are symptomatic.
⠀
There are many different symptoms of POP depending on the severity, including but not limited to: pressure in the lower belly, something falling out of your vagina, and/or pain during intercourse. Many people may not be aware of their POP if it is asymptomatic or if the symptoms are transient. However, as Kim explains, it is important to get screened before returning to exercise due to the potential risk of worsening the POP. The good news: there is help available and it can get better over time and with the exercises Kim suggests.
⠀
Kim Vopni is a restorative exercise specialist and a certified pre/post natal fitness consultant. Kim has created extensive content, such as exercise programs and books to help everyone learn about and connect with their pelvic floor health and the changes that may come with giving birth.
⠀
Disclaimer in comments below...

Babies require several check-ups in their first year of life which helps your doctor get to know your little one and ensure your baby is growing and developing on track. The first two* routine visits are usually within baby’s first week home from the hospital and at 1 month. During the pandemic, the 1-month visit can be virtual if there are no concerns. Please read to see what to expect at these visits so you are best prepared! Please note: visits and procedures may vary depending on you and your baby’s health and medical history. The schedule may also be shifted due to the pandemic, so please check with your care provider.
⠀
Subsequent Well Baby Visits at 2, 4, 6, 9 and 18 months will be described in upcoming posts. Stay tuned!
⠀
*There may also be a 2-week visit, but this is optional and consists of the same assessments as the 1-week visit.

caption:
As hot tubs are starting to open back up following COVID-19 closures, it is important to address the safety of hot tub use for pregnant individuals.
⠀
During pregnancy, it is important to avoid activities or environments that can increase your inner body temperature. Overheating, especially in the first trimester, carries risks to the baby including miscarriage and birth defects.
⠀
We strongly advise pregnant individuals to avoid using hot tubs in the first trimester. The safest option is to avoid using hot tubs throughout the whole pregnancy. In our personal practices, we counsel against hot tub use entirely, given that you cannot closely monitor your own internal body temperature.
⠀

caption:
Hand hygiene is a very important method of infection control as there are many different microorganisms, such as bacteria and viruses, that may be on your hands but invisible to the naked eye. It can help prevent 1 in 5 respiratory infections and 1 in 3 diarrhea-related illnesses. Therefore, it is important to engage in proper hand hygiene practices, especially during the pandemic and with school starting soon. Not only does hand hygiene protect you, it also protects the people around you by preventing the spread of germs. This is particularly important if you live with or come into contact with vulnerable populations, such as the very young, the elderly, those with pre-existing medical conditions, and those with compromised immune systems.
⠀
In this post, we describe the different steps of handwashing, some tips to help encourage your family to practice hand hygiene, and the key moments of hand hygiene. Swipe right to learn more about hand hygiene...
⠀

⠀

caption:
⠀
In this expert series, Isabella, one of our medical students, interviews Dr. Julia Carroll (@drjuliacarroll) about the safety of sunscreen and insect repellent use in newborns and older children. Here we discuss the different types of sunscreens and bug sprays that are available and safe to use, and special considerations that should be taken for children with specific skin conditions (ex. acne or eczema).
⠀
DEET is the active ingredient in many insect repellents. Below are the Canadian guidelines for the recommended DEET concentrations per age group:
- 30% for adults and children older than 12 years old
- 10% for children ages 2 to 12 years old, and can be applied 3 times maximum daily
- 10% for children aged 6 months to 2 years old, and should not be applied more than once a day
- Do not use a DEET containing repellent on children younger than 6 months
⠀
Bottom line: when protecting against both sun and insects, try to stay in the shade and use clothing as additional protective methods. Finally, remember to put on sunscreen first, and bug spray second.
⠀
Dr. Carroll is a board certified dermatologist practicing in Toronto at Compass Dermatology. Her areas of focus include acne, rosacea, skincare and cosmetic dermatology. She is the current president of the Canadian Association of Aesthetic Medicine and the Ontario director on the board of the Canadian Dermatology Association.
⠀
Do you have more questions for Dr. Carroll? Let us know in the comments below.

caption:
In a recent post on hand sanitizers, we described the safety warnings for hand sanitizers made with technical grade ethanol. Today, we found an example that we want to show you... Swipe right to take a look!
⠀
Given the increased demand for hand sanitizer during the pandemic, there has been a shortage of medical-grade ethanol as an ingredient. Health Canada has authorized the use of technical-grade ethanol, which is recommended for adults only and not recommended for anyone pregnant or breastfeeding. Products with technical-grade ethanol must be indicated in the ingredients list along with the safety warnings mentioned above. Many of these products have been recalled in Canada due to non-compliance, including but not limited to: Med Clean Hand Sanitizer, Agape Hand Sanitizer, and Protectenol Hand Sanitizer.
⠀
Bottom line: Hand sanitizers made with medical-grade ethanol are safe for kids and pregnant or breastfeeding people.
⠀
*For more information on hand sanitizer with technical-grade ethanol, please visit the the linktree in our bio.*

caption:
⠀ ⠀
⠀
In this interview, our very own Dr. @eli_shore answers one of our most commonly asked questions... “I am a teacher and pregnant - what should I do about going back to school?”

The back to school period during the COVID-19 pandemic is a stressful time for parents, teachers, and students alike. This video is targeted toward pregnant teachers who are returning to work and what this means given the COVID-19 pandemic. In this interview, Dr. Eli Shore provides evidence-based information and reassurance surrounding this topic. 

Key takeaways:
1. COVID-19 case numbers in Ontario are currently low and have been low for quite some time, suggesting that there is limited community transmission.
2. If a pregnant individual gets COVID-19, there are currently no known implications for the fetus.
3. While masks/sanitizing may be unfamiliar in the school setting, there are many pregnant healthcare professionals who regularly wear masks and sanitize even prior to COVID-19, and there are no adverse effects of this on the pregnancy.
4. The most important thing is to ensure that we all have access the appropriate personal protective equipment and that we practice proper mask etiquette and hand hygiene.
5. Public Health Ontario recently released guidelines for individuals who are at high risk of COVID-19. At this time healthy, low-risk pregnant individuals are not included on this list and therefore are not indicated to be off work related the COVID-19 pandemic. You can find this list here or at our link in bio:
https://www.publichealthontario.ca/-/media/documents/ncov/factsheet/2020/05/factsheet-covid-19-immunocompromised.pdf?la=en#:~:text=Staying%20home%20and%20physical%20distancing,are%20immunocompromised%20stay%20at%20home.
⠀
Please note, this interview is given from an Ontario-specific perspective, where COVID-19 case numbers are currently low. In addition, please remember that COVID-19 evidence is constantly changing; therefore, while information shared in this video is relevant today, this video may no longer reflect the most up-to-date findings as time goes on. Finally, these guidelines and recommendations may change as local case numbers change.

Talking to your kids about how to practice safe respiratory etiquette will help make the return to school safer for everyone and prevent the spread of COVID-19. Helping your child engage in proper respiratory etiquette is important at school and at home. It is important to note that while we want to help prepare kids on how to cough or sneeze in public, it is critical to keep your child home from school if they are ill. ⠀
⠀
In this post, we discuss 4 strategies to practice safe respiratory etiquette. These tips  include coughing or sneezing into a tissue (or your sleeve if there is no tissue available), discarding your tissue, and washing your hands with soap and water or an alcohol-based hand sanitizer. ⠀
⠀
To help demonstrate proper respiratory etiquette to your child, check out this animation made by the government of Canada called Reduce the spread of COVID-19: Hygiene for Kids: ⠀
https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/video/covid-19-kids-hygiene.html⠀
⠀

caption:

Today, we will be addressing those concerns with developmental pediatrician, Dr. Ripudaman Minhas (@ripudaman). This is the first of three videos @drsheilaw recorded with Dr. Minhas. Today’s video will focus specifically on the development of babies and toddlers and how that may be impacted by social distancing during this pandemic.
⠀
Dr. Ripudaman Minhas is a Developmental Pediatrician with the Inner City Health Program at St. Michael's Hospital, the Director of Research in the Department of Pediatrics at St. Michael’s Hospital, and an Assistant Professor in the Department of Pediatrics at the University of Toronto.
⠀

@ 06:43 - Families are often worried about coming in to see their doctor during the pandemic, what are you recommendations regarding this?
@ 07:26 - My toddler hasn’t been around other kids since March, will this affect their development?
@ 11:04 - Will my toddler be set back socially if we decide not to send them to a nursery program?

caption:
Mythbusters Tip #8: Care Providers in Pregnancy
⠀
Myth: All pregnant individuals need to see an OBGYN during their pregnancy and delivery.
⠀
Fact: Pregnancy and delivery can be managed by family doctors, midwives and obstetricians.
⠀
In Canada, most pregnant individuals choose to be followed by an obstetrician and gynecologist (OBGYN) during their pregnancies, especially if their pregnancy is considered high risk. Some family doctors have special training in obstetrics (FMOB) and can therefore follow you throughout your pregnancy, deliver your baby, and follow you and your baby after. Alternatively, some people choose to have their pregnancy, labour/delivery, and postpartum care followed by a midwife. Depending on the clinic, you can self refer to any of these providers once you find out you are pregnant, or you can ask your primary care provider for a referral to the provider of your choosing.
⠀
So, how are they different? Swipe through this post to find out!
⠀

caption:

⠀
Enjoy a 25-minute podcast with Lindsay Witton discussing strategies for parents coping with back to school and pandemic-related anxiety.
⠀
Lindsay explains that it is normal to experience anxiety in these uncertain times, especially as we send our children back to school. She shares that in some ways this anxiety is protective and beneficial and the goal is not to rid of this anxiety, but rather to cope with it. She discusses techniques such as grounding, ways to slow down, navigating social media, and connecting to laughter and silliness in these times. Lindsay also discusses the importance of compassion and self-compassion when it comes to anxiety surrounding pandemic parenting.
⠀
Lindsay reminds us that if you are reading this or listening to this, you ARE coping, adjusting, and helping your family system navigate these challenging times.
⠀
Finally, Lindsay recommends the following experts: Tara Brach @tarabrach, Dennis Tirch @drdennistirch, Esther Perel @estherperelofficial, Nedra Tawwab @nedratawwab, and Lynn Lyons @flusterclux. This list can also be found in our Linktree.
⠀
Lindsay Witton is a Toronto-based Registered Social Worker, Psychotherapist with more than 15 years’ experience supporting individuals and couples through pregnancy, early parenthood and beyond. She is also a mom of three school-aged children. For more information, visit her website at http://www.lindsaywitton.com/.

caption:
Have you ever experienced your baby having hiccups during pregnancy?
⠀
Baby hiccups in the womb are normal movements generated by the baby’s diaphragm when their lungs are maturing. When the baby “inhales” in the womb, the amniotic fluid that enters their lungs will cause their diaphragm to contract, resulting in hiccups.
⠀
Every pregnant individual will start to feel baby hiccups at a different time, and some may not experience them at all. In general, however, most pregnant individuals will begin to feel baby hiccups by the start of the third trimester.
⠀
Baby hiccups may feel like a pulsing or rhythmic twitching from one area of your belly, and can last anywhere from a minute to an hour. Some pregnant individuals experience them rarely, while they may occur several times a day for others.
⠀
Baby kicks may feel like movement coming from different parts of your belly, and may stop if you reposition yourself. They can occur when the baby is adjusting their position, or when their senses are stimulated after you eat something cold, hot, or sweet.
⠀
Typically, baby hiccups are a normal reflex. However, you should contact your care provider if you have concerns.
⠀

caption:

⠀
With kids back at school, teaching your children about regular and proper hand hygiene is critical in preventing the spread of COVID-19. In this expert series, @drsheilaw sits down with Dr. Nisha Thampi, a pediatric infectious disease specialist, and her daughter, Lekha to discuss the importance of effective handwashing.⠀
⠀
Dr. Thampi is a pediatric infectious disease specialist. She is an assistant professor at the University of Ottawa and the medical director of the Infection, Prevention and Control program at the @cheohospital.⠀
⠀
In today’s interview, Dr. Thampi tells us about the hand hygiene song she created to help her children remember the 6 steps of handwashing, recommended by the WHO. This song has now been translated in 28 languages and has become an important tool around the world in helping children wash their hands.⠀
⠀
The lyrics to the song are as follows (to the tune of Frère Jacques):⠀
⠀
“Scrub your palms, between the fingers, wash the back, wash the back, twirl the tips around, scrub them upside down, thumb attack, thumb attack.”⠀
⠀
Watch Lekha’s step-by-step demonstration at 3:55 and jump straight to the song at 5:00.⠀
⠀
This handwashing song and its 28 translated versions can be found at this link: https://cleanhandssavelives.org/hand-washing-song/⠀
⠀
We hope you enjoyed this expert series and we encourage you to sing this song with your child to help make handwashing fun and easy to remember!⠀

caption:
Many of you have been asking… “I am pregnant. Should I get the flu shot this year, given the pandemic?”
⠀
Pregnant people are recommended to get the flu shot and with the COVID-19 pandemic, it’s more important than ever.
⠀
Flu shots are a safe way to protect you and your baby from getting the flu. While the flu shot itself will not protect against COVID-19, getting the flu shot this year will hold significant benefits for public health, and most importantly, for you and your baby’s health.
⠀
Swipe through this post to find out more about the flu shot in pregnancy and why it’s especially important this year…

caption:
Many people have wondered if they should delay getting pregnant during the pandemic... A recent perspective piece published in The New England Journal of Medicine (@NEJM) explores important considerations for delaying pregnancy during a public health crisis.
⠀
The authors provide background information regarding the topic of pregnancy avoidance during previous public health crises, such as the HIV epidemic, the H1N1 influenza outbreak, and the Zika virus outbreak. They also outline a specific set of criteria that would support a recommendation against getting pregnant during a public health crisis.
⠀
The bottom line: The authors believe that the risks associated with COVID-19 DO NOT meet the criteria for recommending against getting pregnant during a public health crisis.
⠀
