caption:
Many of us have wondered about the risks of transmitting COVID-19 to newborns.
⠀
A recent study published in JAMA Pediatrics, assessed the risk of transmission of SARS-CoV-2 infection (ie. COVID-19) in 101 neonates born to mothers with confirmed or suspected SARS-CoV-2 infection, who roomed-in and directly breastfed.
⠀
The bottom line: There was no clinical evidence of *vertical transmission identified in 101 newborns of mothers in NYC with confirmed or suspected SARS-CoV-2 infection, despite most of the newborns rooming-in with birthing parent and directly breastfeeding.
⠀
* transmission during pregnancy (in the uterus), labour or delivery or immediately afterward (e.g. via breastfeeding).
⠀
Swipe right to read the key points from this article.
⠀

⠀
Use these time stamps to skip to specific questions Nishta addresses:
⠀
@ 00:53 - How much food should my baby be getting when introducing solids?
@ 4:00 - How much should I be feeding between bottle/breast versus solids?
@ 4:57 - Can you give us a sample feeding schedule for a typical day, for before and after 9-10 months?
@ 9:25 - At what age do you see breastmilk/formula intake decrease?
@ 10:47 - Are there any foods should I NOT give to my child in the first year of life?
⠀
Nishta Saxena is a registered dietician with a evidence-based and holistic approach to nutrition. Nishta has a faculty appointment in the Department of Family and Community Medicine at the University of Toronto. She is a clinical educator for medical students and residents, and a preceptor for dietetic interns. She is also a food and nutrition expert with Global National News, and makes regular contributions to CTV Your Morning, the Globe and Mail, CBC.ca and UHN News.
⠀
We hope you found this video helpful. If you have any other questions for Nishta about introducing solids in the first year of life, ask us in the comments below!

caption:

It has been almost 10 months since the start of the COVID-19 pandemic. There have been many updates to public health policies and numerous research articles have been published during this time. However, there is still a lot of uncertainty that remains for the pregnant population, especially now that many parts of the world have entered the second wave of the pandemic.
⠀
On October 12th, Dr. @TaliBogler chatted with Dr. Ruchi Murthy (@ruchimurthy) and provided an overview of the most up-to-date evidence for the pregnant community.
⠀
Dr. Murthy is an infectious disease physician at the Queensway Carleton Hospital in Ottawa and she recently gave birth during the height of the pandemic.
⠀
Use these time stamps to skip to specific questions Dr. Murthy addresses:
⠀
@ 2:46 - Summary on most up-to-date evidence, including the recent CDC article (“Characteristics and Maternal and Birth Outcomes of Hospitalized Pregnant Women with Laboratory-Confirmed COVID-19 - COVID-NET, 13 States, March 1-August 22, 2020”) which can be found on our #medicalmonday highlight reel
@ 4:57 - Summary on BMJ study (“Clinical manifestations, risk factors, and maternal and perinatal outcomes of coronavirus disease 2019 in pregnancy: living systematic review and meta-analysis”) - this can also be found on our #medicalmonday highlight reel
@ 6:24 - Bottom Line: The risk of transmission at the hospital is low; the hospital remains a safe place to deliver

caption:
⠀
⠀
Our bodies love a schedule, which is why time change is so challenging for us and our kids. In this @ctv interview, Child and Infant Sleep Expert, Amanda Jewson (@babysbestsleep), provides tips for us and our families to beat the upcoming daylight savings time change.
⠀
In preparation for when we “fall back” this Saturday night, Amanda suggests starting now and moving your kids’ bedtime and wake-up time forward each day by 15-30 minutes. For example, if your little one’s bedtime is 7pm, move their new bedtime to 7:15pm for a few days and add 15 min every few days. Similarly, if your little one currently wakes up at 6am, start taking them out of their crib at 6:15am instead if possible.
⠀
Thank you Amanda for allowing us to share this incredibly practical CTV interview with all of you!
⠀
Amanda Jewson (@babysbestsleep) is a Child and Infant Sleep Consultant. She is a member of the Association of Professional Sleep Consultants and has completed extensive and rigorous training in 1 of only 5 pediatric programs recognized by the APSC. Her programs are rooted in the latest child and infant research and sleep science so you can rest assured your baby is working within not only a gentle program, but a scientifically proven one. She is also a mom of two!
⠀
We hope you found this video helpful. Please feel free to share your own daylight savings tips in the comments below!
⠀

caption:
As of November 3rd, 2020, the Public Health Agency of Canada has updated its recommendations on non-medical face masks. They now recommend face coverings that are made of three layers: two of which should be a tightly-woven material (such as cotton or linen) and the third, middle layer should be a filter-type fabric (e.g. a non-woven polypropylene).
⠀
This suggestion aims to add an extra layer of protection against COVID-19 by trapping small infectious particles.
⠀
Canada's Chief Public Health Officer, Dr. Theresa Tam, emphasizes that you don’t need to throw your two-layered masks in the trash, but rather suggests purchasing a disposable filter to insert between the layers.
⠀
Reference:
https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/another-layer-of-protection-feds-now-recommend-three-layer-masks-with-filters-1.5172995
https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/about-non-medical-masks-face-coverings.html

caption:
Baby acne, also known as neonatal acne, is very common - affecting 1 in 5 children. Baby acne appears in the first few weeks of life and can last several months.It looks like red, inflamed bumps and pimples and may be found on the cheeks, forehead, and temples, as well as the chest and back.
⠀
While it may be understandably concerning for caregivers, baby acne does not cause any harm or pain to your baby and does not require any treatment. It will resolve on its own within a few weeks to months. However, if you are concerned and suspect it may be something else and/or your child is displaying any other symptoms, check in with your care provider.
⠀
Swipe through this post to read more about baby acne and other common mimickers.
⠀
If you feel comfortable, share your own experiences with baby acne in the comments below!
⠀
Content references:
https://www.todaysparent.com/baby/baby-health/baby-acne/
⠀
Photo references:
https://www.babycenter.com/101_visual-guide-to-childrens-rashes-and-skin-conditions_10332129.bc
http://www.atlasdermatologico.com.br/disease.jsf?diseaseId=5

caption:
A recent study in the U.S. was published suggesting a possible association between epidurals during labour and an increased risk of autism spectrum disorder in offspring. The findings of this study understandably caused significant concern in the pregnant and medical professional communities. However, the conclusions of this study should not be accepted at face value. There are MANY limitations to this study that we wish to address for our community today for #medicalmonday. Swipe right to read more...
⠀
Bottom line: The findings of this study cannot be interpreted as a causal link between labour epidurals and childhood autism spectrum disorder. Epidurals continue to be a very safe option for analgesia during labour.
⠀

caption:
To the NICU parent waiting for an answer or a response to treatment, you are stronger than you think.
To the NICU parent experiencing anxiety related to feeding, you are stronger than you think.
To the NICU parent who is worried about adequate milk supply, you are stronger than you think.
To the NICU parent who finally builds a good milk supply but then gets an infection of the breast, you are stronger than you think.
To the NICU parent who is too unwell to visit the NICU, you are stronger than you think.
To the NICU parent of twins struggling with one twin showing more improvement than the other, you are stronger than you think.
To the NICU parent who is trying to balance other kids at home and a new baby in the NICU, you are stronger than you think.
To the NICU parent who is emotionally, mentally and physically drained, you are stronger than you think.
To the NICU parent who comes home with empty arms, you are stronger than you think.
To the NICU parent finally discharged, you are stronger than you think.
To the NICU parent who’s baby was in the NICU many years ago but still thinks about that time… you are stronger than you think.
To the NICU parent who feels anything but strong, you are stronger than you think.
 
 

Thank you Dr. @talibogler for these wise words.

caption:
⠀
Many people have had their pap smears delayed due to COVID-19. Recently, physicians have begun re-starting this important screening practice and it is important that you get an updated pap test if your last one was more than 3 years ago.
⠀
For those who have had an abnormal pap smear or those who have not started screening yet, there have been changes made to the Ontario screening recommendations:
⠀
1) If you’ve had an abnormal pap smear in the last 6 months to 1 year, your physician may recommend that you get a repeat test done in 1 year instead of 6 months. This applies to those whose previous pap smear showed ASCUS (atypical squamous cell of undetermined significance) or LSIL (low grade squamous intraepithelial lesion).
⠀
2) If you have not yet started screening, the guidelines are changing to recommend screening starting at age 25 instead of 21. Please see the slide at the end of the video for more information regarding this change.
⠀
Doctors are also trying to take advantage of opportunistic screening during this pandemic. If you are visiting your doctor for an unrelated health reason, your visit may be a good opportunity for your doctor to also add in a pap smear instead of doing this in a separate visit.
⠀

caption:
This week we shared two recently published studies investigating the impact of COVID-19 on pregnancy.
⠀
Looking at the CDC/MMWR study, as well as other studies from past #MedicalMondays, it appears that COVID-19 may be associated with adverse pregnancy outcomes.
⠀
However, there is some conflicting evidence, including the recent JAMA study we shared that rather had reassuring results in terms of pregnancy outcomes.
⠀
While this is a not a direction comparison of the two studies, it highlights that further studies are needed (especially here in Canada!) to better characterize the impact of COVID-19 on pregnancy and neonatal outcomes.
⠀
To access this week’s two studies, check out the following links:
https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamanetworkopen/fullarticle/2773105?resultClick=1
https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/69/wr/mm6944e2.htm

caption:
What is the latest on the COVID-19 vaccine and pregnant/breastfeeding individuals in Canada?
⠀
Canadian health authorities have not yet released statements on the COVID-19 vaccine in pregnancy/ breastfeeding at the time of this post. We will update our followers as soon as we receive more information.
⠀
In the U.S., the FDA and the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (a CDC committee) have recently released their statements that they will NOT be excluding pregnant or breastfeeding individuals from the COVID-19 vaccination. This is in contrast to the UK/Public Health England’s statement that pregnant/breastfeeding should be excluded from vaccination.
⠀
BOTTOM LINE: We currently have no data to speak to the risks of the vaccine for the pregnant individual or the fetus, but also no data that would warrant a contraindication to use in pregnancy at this time.We (PPG) agree that the U.S. FDA/CDC’s statement is a good move - giving women the CHOICE over their healthcare and to make an informed decision with their health care provider, taking into account their individual situation.
⠀
For more information, you can also visit the New York Times article here:
https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/11/health/coronavirus-vaccine-pregnant-breast-feeding.html
⠀

caption:
What is the latest on the COVID-19 vaccine and pregnant/breastfeeding individuals in Canada? December 21, 2020 Update.
⠀
Since our last post, Health Canada’s National Advisory Committee on Immunization (NACI), as well the Society of Obstetricians and Gynecologists Canada (SOGC) have released statements regarding the COVID-19 vaccine in pregnancy and breastfeeding.
⠀
NACI’s Bottom Line: The COVID-19 vaccine should not be offered to pregnant or breastfeeding individuals until further evidence is available. However, if a risk assessment deems that the benefits outweigh potential risks it may be offered for both of these groups.
⠀
SOGC’s Bottom Line: “For individuals who are at high risk of infection and/or morbidity from COVID-19, it is the SOGC’s position that the documented risk of not getting the COVID-19 vaccine outweighs the theorized and undescribed risk of being vaccinated during pregnancy or while breastfeeding and vaccination should be offered.”
⠀
We currently still have no human data to speak to the risks of the vaccine for the pregnant individual or the fetus, but also no data that would warrant a contraindication to use in pregnancy at this time.
⠀
We (@PPG) feel that the SOGC’s statement (along with the previous statement from the FDA/CDC) is a good move - giving women the CHOICE over their healthcare and to make an informed decision with their health care provider, taking into account their individual situation/risk.
⠀
How do you feel about the NACI and SOGC statements? Let us know your thoughts in the comments below! And stay tuned for a video discussion on this topic with our very own Dr. @talibogler.
⠀
References:
https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/immunization/national-advisory-committee-on-immunization-naci/recommendations-use-covid-19-vaccines.html
https://sogc.org/en/-COVID-19/en/content/COVID-19/COVID-19.aspx?hkey=4e808c0d-555f-4714-8a4a-348b547dc268

caption:
The Toronto Star recently interviewed Dr. @talibogler about the unequal access to COVID-19 vaccine for pregnant & breastfeeding health-care workers in hospitals across Toronto.(1)
⠀
Dr. Bogler also shares her thoughts & reviews how multiple factors have contributed to this problem in a Twitter thread.(5)⠀
⠀
The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted ongoing & historical issues associated with excluding pregnant women from clinical trials, citing them as a vulnerable group. This is a longstanding issue with drug & vaccine development & has been problematic in other public health crises such as the Ebola epidemic.(2)⠀
⠀
Please note: We are not advocating that the vaccination should be mandatory (currently the COVID-19 vaccine is not mandatory). We are advocating for those individuals who are pregnant who are at high risk of exposure (e.g. essential workers/healthcare workers) &/or high risk of COVID-19 illness, that they should be able to talk to their healthcare provider & have the CHOICE to make the decision if vaccination is in their best interest. ⠀
⠀

caption:
Should I wait to conceive after receiving the COVID-19 vaccination? And if so, for how long?
⠀
Official statements differ in their suggestions on whether pregnancy should be delayed (and for how long) after vaccination.
⠀
Health Canada’s National Advisory Committee on Immunization (NACI) recommends waiting 28 days after receiving the complete vaccination series before trying to conceive. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), on the contrary, mentions no advice to avoid pregnancy after COVID-19 vaccination
⠀
It should be noted that during the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine trials, 23 women (12 in the vaccine arm and 11 in the placebo arm) became pregnant following vaccination and are being followed for pregnancy outcomes with no reports of adverse effects to date.
⠀
Bottomline: currently there is no data indicating that pregnancy should be delayed after receiving the COVID-19 vaccination. Given the lack of data at the moment, NACI has recommended delaying trying to conceive by 28 days. We suggest speaking with your primary care and/or obstetrical care provider until further data is available.
⠀
References:
https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/immunization/national-advisory-committee-on-immunization-naci/recommendations-use-covid-19-vaccines.html
https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/recommendations/pregnancy.html
https://sogc.org/common/Uploaded%20files/Latest%20News/SOGC_Statement_COVID-19_Vaccination_in_Pregnancy.pdf

caption:
For #MEDICALMONDAY, we are sharing a large US cohort study, comparing the clinical outcomes of individuals hospitalized for childbirth with and without COVID-19.⠀
⠀
The major findings of this study were that there were higher rates of myocardial infarction (heart attacks), venous thromboembolism (blood clots), preeclampsia (pregnancy complication characterized by high blood pressure and protein in the urine), preterm birth and higher mortality rates in individuals giving birth with COVID-19. These results highlight the importance of including this population in clinical trials for treatment and vaccines (which up until now they have been largely excluded from) AND offering them the option to receive the vaccine, particularly those at high risk of exposure and severe illness. ⠀
⠀
To read the full study, visit this webpage: https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamainternalmedicine/fullarticle/2775396⠀
⠀

caption:
Our very own Dr. @talibogler (FMOB @unityhealthto) along with Dr Jonathan Zipursky (Internist and clin pharm/toxicology @sunnybrookhsc), Dr. Rebecca Greenberg (bioethicist @sinaihealthtoronto) and Dr. Cindy Maxwell (ObGyn, MFM division head @sinaihealthtoronto) published an article in @cmaj.ca today discussing pregnancy, breastfeeding and the COVID-19 vaccine. In the article, the authors propose an ethics-based framework for shared-decision making that takes into account both the current evidence/data and patient’s values/goals.
⠀
Swipe through this post to read key points from the article and view the shared-decision making framework.
⠀
BOTTOM LINE: Shared decision-making can help individuals make a choice regarding the covid-19 vaccine that aligns with their own values, while weighing risks/ benefits and considering personal circumstances.
⠀
To read the whole article, visit: https://www.cmaj.ca/content/cmaj/early/2021/01/26/cmaj.202833.full.pdf
⠀
Thank you to the authors for your tireless work and advocacy navigating the COVID-19 vaccine in pregnancy and breastfeeding!

This is a hard time. It is ok to not feel ok regardless of what your life looks like right now. Even if you feel grateful for parts of your life, it's also ok to feel sad and grieve that things are different. Everyone has been affected by this pandemic.⁣⁣

caption:
⠀
⠀
Dr. @TaliBogler chats with Dr. @Alex.Dainis about the myth that the COVID-19 vaccine can cause infertility. There is NO evidence to suggest that this is true. Dr. Dainis breaks down the science as to why this is a false claim.
⠀
When we revisit the data from the Pfizer vaccine trials, 23 women became pregnant, despite recommendations against conceiving at the time. Women who received the vaccine outside of the trials have also been able to become pregnant.
⠀
Altogether, there is no evidence to suggest that the COVID-19 vaccine is a threat to fertility.
⠀
Dr. Dainis is a science communicator with a PhD from Stanford University in Genetics. Her work uses digital video to make science accessible and engaging to broad audiences.
⠀
⠀

caption:
Many essential nutrients necessary for your baby comes from your body during pregnancy, including Vitamin D. It is used in the regulation of cell growth, immunity, cell metabolism, and it is particularly important for bone health. caption:
We have received many questions and concerns about whether the new COVID-19 Variants of Concerns (VOCs) are more severe in children. So, for #MEDICALMONDAY, we are sharing a UK-based study that assessed the clinical severity of children with COVID-19 in the first wave compared to the second wave.
⠀
The major finding of this study was that infection with the B.1.1.7 variant does NOT result in an appreciably different clinical course than the original strain and severe COVID-19 is uncommon among children.
⠀
To read the full study, visit this webpage: https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lanchi/article/PIIS2352-4642(21)00030-4/fulltext
⠀

caption:
For #MEDICALMONDAY, we are sharing an article published in the BMJ, written by Gareth Iacobucci, that discusses a new document released by the Association of Reproductive and Clinical Scientists and the British Fertility Society on the COVID-19 vaccine and fertility.
⠀
There has been a great deal of misinformation spread about the COVID-19 vaccine and infertility. The major takeaway from this article is that there is NO evidence to support the link between the COVID-19 vaccine and infertility.
⠀
To read the full article, visit this webpage: https://www.bmj.com/content/372/bmj.n509.
⠀

caption:
“My water broke!” is a common phrase that we have all heard of but what does it really mean?

Your baby is surrounded by a fluid-filled bag called the amniotic sac. The breaking of water or rupture of membranes (ROM) is the term used when a tear forms in this sac. When people say their “water broke”, they are referring to ROM. It often feels like either a gush or trickling of fluid from the vagina. ROM often happens at full term (after 37 weeks) and it can happen with or without contractions.

**It is important to seek medical attention if you experience fluid leaking.**

Swipe to read more about how ROM is diagnosed and managed…
⠀

caption:
Today, on International Women’s Day, we are honouring each and every one of you for your strength and resilience during this past year. We are also honouring the loss many of us have experienced. Pregnancy and parenting is hard at the best of times but in a pandemic, it can often feel overwhelming and isolating. We thank all of you for following along and for sharing your stories and these intimate and inspiring moments with us. While we are all unique in our journeys, we are connected by the universality of these experiences as women, inclusive of cis and trans women and those identifying along the feminine spectrum.
⠀
The stories shared are vulnerable accounts of individual experiences. They are heart wrenching, honest and inspiring. We have not edited any of the content and are sharing directly as shared with us. Thank you for trusting us with your stories, we know these will resonate with so many and build strength and a sense of community as we continue to navigate this time.

Sharing of first story of resilience in honour of IWD...
⠀
“My name is Angela and I gave birth to my daughter Avery last May. The pandemic has certainly been a challenging experience, but one of the hardest things for me has been my inability to share the hardships and joys with my family. Despite that, becoming a parent has been a dream realized for me.

In a time when typical pregnancy and parenting resources aren’t always relevant (thanks, pregnancy app, for suggesting that Avery should have her first friend by now...) I really appreciate PPG and your solid, evidence based information!” -Angela (@anlast)

Continuing our sharing of stories of resilience as well as loss in honour of IWD...
⠀
“I went into labour on my due date with my first on September 30th. I was so nervous because I knew that once it was go time I could be alone for hours waiting until my husband could actually join me to help support me through. I had spent the majority of my pregnancy appointments, scans and tests going it alone. My husband was deprived of all of those experiences and I felt like I was missing my partner and participating in our baby growing without him being able to be involved like he wanted to be. At 3 am on October 1st I threw up and I heard my husband in the nursery gathering our things - he walked past the bathroom and said “that’s enough. You’re going to the hospital”. I put off going as long as I could. I ended up labouring for another 3 hours alone in triage until they would admit me and allow my husband to come up and join me. I didn’t ever imagine that being masked and isolated would be a part of my birth.
⠀
In the end everything went to plan and our baby girl Rogue was born that evening at 7:27 pm. I love her and our family but I can’t help but think about all of the interaction she’s missing out on in her first few months of life. I can’t wait until this is over and we can share more of her.” -Stacey (stace.wellington)

“Just wanted to start off by thanking everyone in the PPG team for creating this account and sharing the best and helpful resources. Being a first time mom, first pregnancy during a pandemic and lockdowns has not been easy, but having this account to get information has been extremely helpful.
⠀
I want to share my story, partially for awareness, but mostly for my own healing from the trauma.
⠀
I found out I was pregnant at the end of January 2020, and while I had lots of nausea, "morning" sickness and food aversions to everything (I even lost weight in the first trimester), it seemed like I was having a normal, low risk pregnancy...or so I was told. When lockdown started in March 2020 it came at a great time because I started working from home, which looking back I think is what greatly helped me being able to carry my baby full term.

Fast forward to the third trimester, I was having terrible headaches that never went away, started getting pain in my upper right side, radiating all across my upper back and my upper left side, I also started having nausea and vomiting again. I was always thorough and told my OB in detail all my pains and aches, but was dismissed as "normal pregnancy." I even asked if there would be a blood test (my last blood test was at 20 weeks) or a urine sample, but was told no because my blood pressure was low and the baby seemed fine.
⠀
On October 7 I had an OB appointment and I was not good, I even said to my OB "I don't know how anyone ever has more than one kid because this is so hard." Looking back, I was having all the HELLP syndrome symptoms. But I was told I was fine and to go to triage if I feel off. Not even 12 hours later, at 3am, I told my husband we needed to go to the hospital.
⠀
I had been vomiting all night, didn't even have anything else in me, my body pains were more intense and I was cutting in and out. My husband didn't quite understand why we had to go and was trying to go back to sleep, as this was not signs of early labour like we had learned from the prenatal classes.
⠀
We went to the hospital around 3:30am--luckily it's only a 10min drive away but I'm pretty sure I passed out twice.

Continuing our sharing of stories of resilience as well as loss in honour of IWD...

“I wanted to share my experiences and perspective around being pregnant, giving birth and being a first time mom in Canada during a pandemic. I first want to say I am so grateful for all the health care workers who have had to make many sacrifices throughout this year, and that my comments are in regards to the health care system not the people. Note this is also coming from a person who struggles with anxiety and at times depression.

Starting with my pregnancy, which began basically at the start of the pandemic in Canada, it felt fairly manageable. I did have some phases where I struggled with depression in that period, which were further exacerbated by the fact I wasn't allowed to have my husband with me for any appointments - mostly bummed he couldn't be apart of the ultrasounds and that I didn't get to share those things with him in the moment. Instead it was in the car afterwards showing him pictures we had to pay for so he could be at least somewhat apart of the pregnancy and experience a portion of what he should have been able to had there not been pandemic restrictions.

Fast forward to labour and delivery. The staff at the hospital were fantastic. For me, it hardly felt like we were in a pandemic besides the fact that we had to wear masks. I felt like our quality of care was not diminished in the slightest by the pandemic. My husband got to be apart of almost all phases of labour, just not the initial assessment, so that helped immensely.

Things have been the most upsetting more recently post delivery/during my postpartum period.

Being a first time mom comes with its stressors and anxieties even when there isn't a pandemic. Added to that I've been struggling with postpartum depression and anxiety. Our daughter has had a few medical concerns that have required her to have an increased number of visits to our family doctor, one trip to emergency and one trip to the children's hospital for an appointment. All of this I was forced to take on by basically myself, with my husband patiently waiting in the car for us.

Continuing our sharing of stories of resilience in honour of IWD…

“Navigating pregnancy during a pandemic is petrifying. As a first time mom, I was already nervous - I was also working as a nurse which added to the stress. My pregnancy was unusual, and scary. But here I am snuggling my beautiful one month old son, so incredibly thankful. I felt so isolated , it seems like no one talks about the ‘ugly’ side of pregnancy.

At 24 weeks along I found out, alone, that my baby had a velamentous cord. I went to hospital in pain, and found out things might get complicated for us going forward. I was so scared for my baby. At 31 +3, our son decided he wanted to try to meet us. I wasn’t feeling right, and went into hospital begrudgingly -called myself a wimp even. Thankfully the (amazing) team at my local hospital recognized the preterm labour and sent me to another hospital that could manage this. Things got really intense , but thankfully they were able to stop labour long enough for steroids to work in case he decided to arrive again.

I was hospitalized for 8 days. With the current covid situation at that time, the visitor policy had changed, and I can honestly say this was the hardest week of my life. I was restricted to not even being able to see my husband, because when he came he wasn’t allowed to leave, and we had no idea what the next days/weeks may or may not bring.

My take away though, is to remain positive in this very humbling time being a patient and not the nurse.

For the moms, moms to be, anxious moms, NICU moms, high risk moms- all off us. (and all the dads that I am sure feel helpless in these times). I have learned quickly that these babes make us stronger, but it’s still okay to feel all the emotions. What matters is recognizing that this happens, and should be talked about. Feeling like there is no where to reach out to talk makes things harder. Thankfully I have amazing support, and I knew things would be okay.

I was discharged from hospital, and managed to carry to 39 weeks! We had a healthy baby boy, and feel so lucky.

Continuing our sharing of stories of resilience in honour of IWD…
⠀
“Last year I was wrongfully dismissed from my job of 4 years a month after announcing my pregnancy. My husband & I had to prepare for a baby with 40% less household income. I always wanted to go back to school, so since I had more time on my hands I took the opportunity to start taking courses to better myself in the business world. It was a very hard emotional time due to hormones, and even the unexpected realization that I was grieving a job and a lifestyle that I enjoyed. I hired a lawyer and am in the process of suing the company because I don't go down without a fight. I had my baby in Jan 2021. I had to get induced as I was having trouble dilating because the baby was facing sunny side up. I got a cervidil inserted for 24 hours, got sent home and went back. Only 1/2cm. Then a Foley inserted for another 24hrs. Got sent home and went back yet again. (I can't even count all the cervical assessments I got).
⠀
After 12 hours of labor and having my water broken, the doctor said since baby is still happy in there we should consider a c-section because it's better to go about it now, then wait for an emergency because the longer we wait the riskier it can get. (as my water had been broken for quite some time). I've never had surgery before, let alone an unexpected one! So I was very nervous. Finally the moment arrived when my baby was born. My husband & I couldn't have been happier!!! 2 days later we were discharged. My parents came over to meet the baby. Also, during this time my grandmother was at the same hospital I was, but on a different floor due to a flare-up of a heart condition she has. My grandmother ended up testing positive for COVID during her stay at the hospital. Then my mom tested positive for COVID (but no symptoms). So no one was able to help us out with the baby for the first couple of weeks.
⠀
Toronto Public Health sent my mom a letter and later phoned her as well to say if she had no symptoms after 1 week she didn't have to stay in quarantine. That was the most anxious week of my life. But she felt great the whole time!

Today marks the first-ever Canadian Women Physicians Day - a day designated to honour women’s achievements in medicine. On March 11, 1875, Dr. Jennie Trout became the first woman licensed to practice medicine in Canada. Despite that women physicians make up over 43% of Canada’s physician workforce, women physicians still face challenges — including pay inequity, harassment and bias, or exclusion. PPG is proud to be comprised of a strong team of female physicians and physicians-to-be, who are continuing to break down barriers and change medicine for the better.
⠀

caption:
Continuing our sharing of stories of resilience in honour of IWD…
⠀
“I’d love to share my mama birth pandemic sorry!
⠀
I gave birth at St. Mike’s hospital during the middle of the pandemic in august! My birth went well and baby and I are both super healthy and I’m so so happy for you. But my postpartum mental health has been rocky to say the least. It’s been a roller coaster. Lots of crying lots of postpartum anxiety. I have good days and bad days. It took me time to get help, but I’m now working on it! I’m part of a great program at women’s college hospital that supports women, and in my case postpartum mental health support. So far it’s been very helpful and I’m optimistic things will improve. I’ve learned nothing is linear postpartum, so I’m not expecting a perfect picture moving forward. I’m hopeful that I’ll build some solid mama tools to help my mental health.
⠀
I do wish that we spoke more openly about postpartum mental health. The more I open up to my mom friends the more tell me how they also struggled either with depression or anxiety.
⠀
I hope that through your sharing of stories you can share many about the trials and tribulations of postpartum depression and anxiety. A lot of social media depicts the first year of babies life as perfect. And what I’m learning from my own experiences and from my mom friends is it’s nothing close to that. It’s a magical experience. It’s amazing seeing this little human you birthed grow and thrive. But it’s tough and It’s hard work.” -Heather Christine @thestateofmotherhood 
⠀

Continuing our sharing of stories of resilience in honour of IWD…
⠀
“We miscarried with our first pregnancy 5 days before the pandemic shut everything down in Ontario. To go through one of the most difficult things without being able to see friends and family was so challenging. I work in public health so although I took a few days off of work, when I returned I was immediately thrown into an intense work schedule. One side it was a nice distraction, but on the other I’m not sure I ever really finished grieving with how busy this past year has been. We continue to struggle to get pregnant. As we approach the one year anniversary of our loss, I have such mixed feelings towards what has happened. I’m a believer that things happen for a reason, and maybe it was meant to have happened so that we didn’t have to spend our first pregnancy and mat leave in a lockdown without being surrounded by loved ones to share the moments with, but on the other hand my mind will always wonder about what life would have been...
⠀
I’m fortunate to have been able to receive both doses of the covid vaccine, so hopefully one day we’ll be able to get pregnant and I’ll be able to pass along those antibodies to my baby” -Kelly @kellyj1217
⠀

Continuing our sharing of stories of resilience in honour of IWD…
⠀
1/3 “It’s been a year.
On March 13, 2020, the world, including Toronto where I live, shut down. It was only supposed to be for two weeks and somehow two weeks turned into the most introspective, scary, mind-numbingly boring, joyful, lonely, painfully sad and historic year. It was also the day my daughter was born.
No one hands you a “What to Expect with your Pandemic Baby” book when you give birth on the first day of a pandemic. No one can prepare you because no one knows anything.
She was born at home as planned with the care and support of the amazing midwife who delivered my first. She was one week late. I often wonder if it would have been different if she was born on her due date but maybe she knew better. I remember looking at her and thinking, “I can’t wait to introduce this amazing girl to the world.” But sadly, I’m still waiting.
The early days were debilitating. The lack of sleep, the tears (for both of us), the pain, the guilt you carry in the best of times wondering if you’re doing enough, if you are enough, but the pandemic added another layer. No mom to hold the baby while you caught up on your sleep. No friend to hold your hand and tell you that things will get better. No introductions, no celebrations, no family time, no anything. In my case, not even my husband or older daughter, who had mysterious rashes and were ordered to isolate away from me and the baby for 2 weeks. Nothing but you, your newborn baby, and a scary virus swirling and growing outside your front door.”
⠀

Continuing our sharing of stories of resilience in honour of IWD…
⠀
“I was 24 weeks pregnant with our second son when the pandemic hit. I suddenly found myself off work as a precaution and home with our toddler who no longer had daycare. It was such a scary and isolating time.
At 32 weeks I ended up in the emergency room with kidney stones and was all alone because I wasn’t allowed to bring my husband in. He’s the best. He sat in the parking lot the whole time.
I was 10 days late when baby decided to arrive. I was showing no signs of going into labour and given the projected weight and previous shoulder dystocia with our first baby, I was waiting for a c section. Labour and delivery was packed that night and my c section kept getting pushed. With no warning my water broke and the chaos began. Two hours and one minute later, our beautiful baby boy arrived.
⠀
Liam was born July 25th, 2020 at 2:09am. He weighed 9lbs 10oz and 22.5 inches.
He’s 7 months now. He’s hardly met anyone which has been incredibly hard but Mommy, Daddy and Big Brother Evan have enjoyed every minute with him.
We call him our light in 2020 or our little ray of sunshine. He’s the best and his timing was both terrible and perfect. One day I think we’ll all look back and be proud of what we’ve done.” -@joyjackman
⠀
⠀

caption:
Continuing our sharing of stories of resilience in honour of IWD…
⠀
“Having a baby in NICU was extraordinarily isolating during the pandemic, with my partner not being allowed to be with us, and not being able to have any family visit to help.
⠀
I was wheelchair bound due to a traumatic delivery, but I had no one to help push my wheelchair to get around the hospital. Trying to move around on my own severely exacerbated my pain and delayed my recovery, but being away from my baby did not feel like an option.
⠀
The patient fridges were off limits so I couldn’t bring multiple meals, nor could I get myself to the cafeteria or the hospital doors to get food delivered due to my inability to walk, so I survived on granola bars and the like.
⠀
Covid restrictions added such an immense level of suffering to an already overwhelming time.
⠀
At one point my baby was put on covid isolation precautions due to protocol, and I had to wear full PPE to hold her. None the less, no gown, mask, or shield can block the love I had to give to my baby. We made it through a very trying 3 weeks, and are home safe and sound.”
⠀

Continuing our sharing of stories of resilience in honour of IWD…
⠀
“As a first time mom I was overwhelmed with so many things when our sweet baby Stevie arrived on July 26, 2020 but by far the best of all of these things was the amazing community of moms I was able to connect with. Some were experienced moms and some first time moms like me. This mom community has taught me so much over the past 7.5 months. I’m so thankful for the mom who taught me how to drink coffee while strolling with a stroller, the mom who told me she too couldn’t use a baby carrier for more than an hour before her back hurt, the mom who shows up for a walk with an extra chocolate croissant, the mom who will share a pitcher of beer with me on a patio and talk about how tough breastfeeding can be, and the mom who just makes you feel like you’re not doing as bad as you think you might be. 2020 is the year I became a mom and joined the club of amazing women doing the same thing as me. Navigating motherhood the best we can.” -Jaclyn @jac044
⠀

For this week’s #MEDICALMONDAY, we are sharing an article published in @cmaj.ca that is a review of the latest studies on the impact of COVID-19 on pregnancy outcomes.
⠀
Specifically, this study looked at 42 published studies and combined their data. They found that compared with no COVID-19 infection in pregnancy, COVID-19 was associated with preeclampsia*, preterm birth, stillbirth, ICU* admission for the pregnant individual, lower birth weight in baby, and NICU* admission for baby.
⠀
*Preeclampsia = a condition during pregnancy characterized by high blood pressure and protein in your urine
*ICU = Intensive Care Unit, *NICU = Neonatal Intensive Care Unit
⠀
To read the full article, visit: https://www.cmaj.ca/content/early/2021/03/18/cmaj.202604
⠀

caption:
Another one for this week’s special double #MEDICALMONDAY!
⠀
We are highlighting a pre-print study showing that mothers who received two doses of the Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine may not only be protecting themselves, but can potentially pass COVID-19 antibodies to their babies through the placenta.
⠀
The authors write, “These encouraging results have important implications for maternal care and the development of appropriate vaccination strategies.” However, more research needs to be done to further understand the safety and efficacy of COVID-19 vaccines for pregnant individuals and their babies, and to determine the best timing for someone to receive the vaccine during their pregnancy. “
⠀
To read the full article, visit this webpage: https://www.medrxiv.org/content/10.1101/2021.03.11.21253352v1
⠀

This week is poison prevention week. Check out an article written by Dr. Daniel Rosenfield, a pediatric emergency doctor at Sick Kids, about an important pandemic risk in young children: unintentional poisonings from household poisons. Steps you can take to protect your children include:
•Close supervision
•Keeping all poisons locked in cabinets
•Storing medications in childproof containers
⠀

caption:
Continuing our sharing of stories of being pregnant and parenting during the pandemic…

“I had my second son in July, 2020. I had been working as a nurse at CAMH until May, when I started my maternity leave. Going from seeing my co-workers everyday to seeing no one was quite challenging. But I think I naively hoped it wouldn't last too long. My son was born at home and what started out as a blissful newborn stage, quickly turned into anger, sadness, and resentment. I was in pain, I was sore, I was lonely and I felt this baby was completely to blame. My mother had died November 2017 and I wished I could have her with me to help or just give me words of encouragement and I knew I'd never get that from her again. My anxiety about my baby came and went and came and went. I had wonderful days where I'd look at my family and think how lucky and perfect everything was and days where I'd wish it would all end. My husband was amazing and supportive and did more than I could have ever have asked or hoped for, but ultimately it was my body that constantly needed. It was my body that had transformed and was now unrecognizable. I almost enjoyed lockdown so I wouldn't have to see anyone looking how I did. As my baby got older, I reached a breaking point where I finally reached out to my sisters and I'm so happy I did that. Being a mother or new mother in quarantine or lockdown is hard. Luckily, I've been feeling so much better and have been actually able to enjoy my kids more and more. These are times that I wish I could be sharing with my sisters, my friends, my in-laws and they are forced to watch this stage of my children's lives through video and pictures.

I will always cherish these moments that we as a family have been able to have together, but I will always wonder what amazing memories we never got to experience.”

-Camellia, @camelliamohebat

For #MedicalMonday, we are highlighting the LARGEST STUDY to date, published in the American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology (AJOG) to show that COVID-19 mRNA vaccines are effective in pregnancy (same immune response as the general population) and the resulting antibodies are transferable to babies.

Swipe for some key points from this study 

Please note: This study was published March 25th, 2021 and newer evidence may continue to be released.

To read the full article, visit this webpage: https://www.ajog.org/article/S0002-9378(21)00187-3/fulltext

We continue to share stories of hardship and loss, but also incredible resilience and strength becoming new parents during the pandemic.⠀
​⠀
1/3 “My husband and I had always planned on trying for a baby in the fall of 2020, and the pandemic had not changed too much for us. So with everything settling down in the summer, we decided to simply start trying a couple months ahead of schedule. Well, we got pregnant very quickly and were over the moon about it. Then, at a last minute ultrasound booked due to some unexplained spotting, we discovered that our baby had a Cystic Hygroma. We were devastated, especially when told the odds for our baby's survival and quality of life. We were given the option of terminating or doing genetic testing to try and determine the cause, and we took the later option. What followed were months of quiet tears, stress, secret appointments and desperately trying to stay positive while only keeping a chosen few in the loop. I hid my pregnancy from friends and some family, and couldn't bring myself to feel happy about it.I dreaded growing attached in case things went wrong, and this was all while trying to continue working as teachers in a pandemic. Work was stressful, appointments took their toll, and things were a struggle.⠀
​⠀
Finally, after weeks/months of tests, we were told the Hygroma was shrinking, and that everything had come back negative, but that they had also discovered that we had a single umbilical artery. It felt like we had finally received the good news only to be thrown one more curveball. So now we monitored for growth. There was no way to hide the pregnancy any more, and I was growing attached as I felt kicks, hiccups, and rolls. I knew this baby was ours and I was finally willing to share with friends and family. We continued to be monitored and checked and things were progressing beautifully. The Hygroma was almost entirely gone and our baby was as healthy as could be!⠀

Yesterday morning, our very own Dr. @talibogler was interviewed on @cbcradio discussing whether or not pregnant people should get a COVID-19 vaccine.
⠀
In the segment, Dr. Bogler explains that while pregnant and breastfeeding people were excluded from clinical trials, currently we have no data indicating that there are any significant side effects or adverse pregnancy outcomes in pregnant people who have received the vaccine, nor is there any scientific reason to believe that the vaccine is harmful in pregnancy (given that is not a live vaccine). In addition, Dr. Bogler shares that more recent real world evidence suggests that vaccination in pregnancy may allow the pregnant person to transfer antibodies (which are protective against COVID-19) to their baby, and this transfer may also occur through the breastmilk of vaccinated breastfeeding parents.
⠀
Dr. Bogler states that right now in Canada, pregnant people are not all routinely recommended to get the vaccine, but rather they are recommended to have a risk-benefit analysis with their healthcare provider to decide whether or not to receive the vaccine.
⠀
Every day, more and more real world data is coming out so stay tuned on our Instagram page for the latest on everything pregnancy and pandemic-related!
⠀
The 20-minute segment can be accessed at: https://www.cbc.ca/listen/live-radio/1-63-the-current/clip/15835882-expecting-shot-pregnant-people-wondering-whether-covid-19-vaccine
⠀

caption:
For #MEDICALMONDAY, we are sharing a systematic review and meta analysis published at the end of March, by Chmielewska et al., published in the Lancet, on maternal and perinatal outcomes during the COVID-19 pandemic.
⠀
The bottom line of this study is that some maternal and perinatal outcomes such as stillbirths, maternal deaths, ruptured ectopic pregnancies and maternal depression have increased in incidence during the pandemic (not related to COVID-19 infection/illness itself). However, some maternal and perinatal outcomes such as hypertensive disorders of pregnancy, gestational diabetes, neonatal ICU admission, low birth weight and others (swipe right to read more) do not appear to have increased during the pandemic. This study highlights the importance of ensuring access to high quality pregnancy care during this public health crisis.
⠀
To read the full article, visit this webpage: https://www.thelancet.com/journals/langlo/article/PIIS2214-109X(21)00079-6/fulltext
⠀

caption:
We continue to share stories of hardship and loss, but also incredible resilience and strength becoming new parents during the pandemic.
⠀
“I’ve been working at the bedside as a nurse since the beginning of the pandemic. All was great until I got pregnant in the fall and found out just before Christmas! I had so many emotions, I was so excited as I have endometriosis and we didn’t think we’d get pregnant so fast or if at all and I had just recently come off my oral treatment for endometriosis. The excitement then turned to fear; this could be my only pregnancy, what if I get covid-19, is it safe for both of us to get vaccinated etc. I’d have panic attacks before work and not sleep (not ideal before a 12hr busy shift) as I was so anxious. I leaned on my support of people and my manager assured me I wouldn’t be exposed to a potential positive patient or confirmed positive patients. I was re-fitted for my N95 and set to go. Recently I received my first Covid-19 vaccine at 20 weeks 6 days gestation. I’m proud to say I work on the only inpatient floor in my hospital not to have a covid-19 outbreak and I miss my team so much they’re honestly amazing!
⠀
Amazing men and women! So supportive of one another and so caring for our patients and each other. Working while pregnant is terrifying but also I’m grateful that my vocation has allowed me to work through all of this mess, granted with more stress than usual, but it could be much worse.”

⁣Changes to your menstrual cycle after the COVID-19 Vaccine? Read below to hear from @drjengunter on potential mechanisms for why this may be and swipe up on our stories to read her informative article!⠀
⠀
Key take-home messages:⠀
1. Vaccine research needs to include data beyond potential side effects like fever to include other potential changes such as menstrual irregularities.⠀
⠀
2. Dr. Gunter hypothesizes that the menstrual irregularity may be due to an immune response to the vaccine in the endometrium, which is part of the immune system.⠀
⠀
Repost @drjengunter

On April 13th, the U.S. paused the administration of Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 vaccines after 6 people out of 7 million recipients developed a rare blood-clotting disorder. There have also been rare blood clot concerns with the AstraZeneca vaccine.
⠀
Dr. @TaliBogler chats with Dr. Menaka Pai (@menakagram) about the common questions our community has asked about blood clots related to the vaccines, pregnancy, postpartum, and combined oral contraceptive pills. (Our apologies in advance for misspelt names in the auto-generated captions.)
⠀
Here are the topics discussed in this interview:
@ 00:43 - Blood clots related to COVID-19 vaccines
@ 02:28 - How are the clots related to the vaccines different to clots associated with pregnancy and contraceptive pills?
@ 03:43 - Can we directly compare the different types of clots?
@ 06:42 - Any advice for pregnant women who have received a Johnson & Johnson/AstraZeneca vaccine?
@ 08:01 - Why are we seeing the vaccine-related blood clots in younger women?
@ 09:10 - Importance of a gender lens in science
⠀
Blood clot risk statistics described by Dr. Pai:
AstraZeneca - 1 in 100,000 to 250,000
Combined oral contraceptive pills containing estrogen - 1 in 3000 per year
Pregnancy - 1 in 300 per year
Postpartum - 1 in 250 per year
*It is important to note that we cannot directly compare the risks between the vaccine-related blood clots and hormone-related blood clots. Watch the interview to learn more...
⠀
Dr. Pai is a hematologist and thrombosis specialist at the Hamilton General Hospital and the lead author of an advisory for healthcare professionals with regards to COVID-19 vaccine-induced blood clot disorders as part of the Ontario COVID-19 Science Advisory Table. She is also an Associate Professor of medicine at McMaster University, the Head of Service for Benign Hematology at Hamilton Health Sciences, and the Quality Lead for Transfusion Medicine in the Hamilton Regional Laboratory Medicine Program.
⠀
*Please see the disclaimer in the comments and at the end of the video.*
⠀

⠀
⠀
Enjoy this 10-minute run down of postpartum return to running with Hayley O’Hara.
⠀
Are you thinking about getting back into running after you deliver? Worried about your pelvic floor after delivery and if it’s safe and how to return to your pre-pregnancy running routine? Hayley describes evidence-based guidelines and tips with your health and safety in mind.
⠀
Hayley O’Hara (@pelvicgoddess) is a physiotherapist with a special focus in Pelvic Health and Women’s Health. She has completed advanced courses in perinatal care and has helped women prepare for labour and delivery as well as assist with recovery in the postpartum period. She also has experience treating a wide range of musculoskeletal issues, including working with athletes in a rehabilitative and performance capacity. Hayley is also a practitioner with the Wellbe Family Wellness team (@hello.wellbe).
⠀

caption:
Recently, a story was aired on @CTV sharing the experience of pregnant individual who contracted COVID-19 and was admitted to the ICU, just 19 days before giving birth. Thankfully, both mom and baby are doing well now.
⠀
It is important to share this story, not to generate fear, but to ensure people are informed of the risks of COVID-19 in pregnancy. It is important to note that majority of pregnant people with COVID-19 do not have severe symptoms, but there are increasing reports that pregnant people are getting more sick and being admitted to the ICU in Toronto, Ontario specifically - especially with the spread of the COVID-19 variants of concern. This story and the changes we are seeing also highlight the importance of considering vaccination during pregnancy. We are advocating for you at the systemic level to try to increase access to vaccination for pregnant individuals.
⠀
We know this is a challenging time and a difficult story to hear. Please continue to take all public health precautions to minimize your risk of contracting COVID-19. As well, please pay attention to your mental health as you navigate your pregnancy journey in these uncertain times.
⠀
If you need support, please reach out to your healthcare provider and we will be resharing our mental health resources this week.
⠀
Article can be found at: https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/worst-fear-come-true-toronto-woman-was-in-icu-with-covid-19-days-before-giving-birth-1.5388199

caption:
If you listen to one thing today, please listen to this: be mindful of your mental health right now.

It’s okay to not be okay.

To support one another, we are organizing two IG LIVES with perinatal psychiatrists:

1. Tonight (SAT) 8:00-8:30 PM EST with Dr. Lucy Barker, Perinatal Psychiatrist at Women’s College Hospital. Facilitated by @drsheilaw

2. Monday night 8:00-8:30 PM EST with Dr. Arielle Dalfen, Perinatal Psychiatrist at Mount Sinai Hospital.

Feel free to comment or DM us ANY emotions or feelings you’re struggling with right now and would like addressed. 

We will also have the live chat function available throughout the sessions.

With love,
PPG Team

Join us for a review of how to support your mental health through this difficult time with the incredible Dr. Lucy Barker. Dr. Barker is a perinatal psychiatrist at @wchospital in Toronto.  She is also doing her PhD in clinical epidemiology with a focus on the social determinants of postpartum mental health service use. She is passionate about equity, reproductive health and mental health. ⁣
⁣
Questions included:⁣
•how to manage emotions such as anger, sadness and reactivity?⁣
•where to get help for low mood and anxiety⁣
•managing the constant news cycle and turning off your phone⁣
•boundary setting when loved ones don’t have the same ideas about public health measures ⁣
•how to get help for intimate partner violence ⁣
•dealing with panic/anxiety⁣
•dealing with isolation ⁣
•loss of identity and how to get help.⁣
⁣
Thank you to everyone who shared your stories and questions with us. Sending lots of love to each and every one of you during this time.  Please join us for part 2 on Monday April 19 at 8pm.

caption:
April is Caesarean Awareness Month, and we want to share a video that provides useful information on elective repeat caesarean sections.
⠀
In general, patients who have had one previous caesarean section have two options for their delivery in the next pregnancy: a trial of labor (TOLAC) or an elective repeat caesarean section (ERCS).
⠀
In this video, obstetricians including our own Dr. @eli_shore take us through this decision making process and details some of the risks and benefits when considering an ERCS.

We have also previously posted a video on TOLAC. You can watch the full video series here: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCl9Bi8PE54MqWKueH877ekA

Check out this handout for further information: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1PYE0hPaaV_ZQ6HTbc9Hl4p917Sq5XV-u/view

caption:
During this challenging time, we know that you may have more questions than answers. We want to help provide some clarity over these next few days by doing a series of live Q&A sessions.

Schedule for the week ahead (bookmark in your calendars!):

1. Monday (TODAY! 8-8:30pm EST): Mental health Q&A with Dr. Ariel Dalfen and Dr. Sheila Wijayasinghe
2. Tuesday 20th (8-8:30pm EST): COVID vaccine Q&A with Dr. Tali Bogler
3. Thursday 22nd (time TBD): Ask your OB Q&A with Dr. Eliane Shore and A Special Guest

PPG team

Join us for a mental health chat with the wonderful Dr. Ariel Dalfen. Dr. Dalfen is a psychiatrist at Mount Sinai Hospital in the Perinatal Mental Health Program where she specializes in treating women who are pregnant or postpartum. She recently stepped down after 12 years as the head of this Program and continues to be the Head of the Perinatal Telemedicine Program. Dalfen is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Psychiatry at the University of Toronto and has published in both medical journals and the popular media. In 2008, she published a book, When Baby Brings the Blues: Solutions for Postpartum Depression. This book is highly regarded and utilized by both health care providers and the general public.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Tonight’s chat focused on:⁣⁣
⁣⁣
•Mental health resources - virtual options⁣⁣
•How to manage panic, especially when having to leave home when it feels anxiety-provoking⁣⁣
•Tips for sleep during pregnancy during the pandemic⁣⁣
•How to speak to family and friends about what you are going through⁣⁣
•Pregnancy after loss, brief discussion about PTSD in pregnancy⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Thank you for sharing your questions and stories with our PPG community. Sending love and healthy wishes ❤️⁣⁣
⁣⁣

You asked, we listened, we advocated, and we were heard!
⠀
ONTARIO UPDATE: The Ministry of Health Ontario has just moved pregnancy into the "Highest Risk" health condition category in the Phase 2 vaccination plan. As of April 23, 2021, all pregnant individuals are eligible to register for COVID-19 vaccination appointments. You can book COVID-19 vaccine appointments through the provincial call centre: 1-833-943-3900 between 8am-8pm.
⠀
In the last few weeks, ICUs have been seeing increasing numbers of pregnant women in critical condition from COVID-19. While the majority of pregnant individuals infected with COVID-19 still have mild to moderate symptoms, numerous studies are also showing that COVID-19 is associated with adverse complications for the mother and baby, including preeclampsia, preterm birth, stillbirth, lower birth weight, ICU admission for the pregnant individual, and NICU admission for the baby. Previously, pregnant individuals were placed in the “at risk” category in the vaccination plan. But pregnant individuals are now considered not just “at risk,” they considered in the highest risk category for COVID-19 infection.
⠀
Thanks to the advocacy of Drs. @talibogler, Isaac Bogoch, and many others, pregnant individuals are being moved higher in the prioritization for COVID-19 vaccination.
⠀
How do you feel about this update? Let us know in the comments below!
⠀

caption:
A new study by NEJM reveals early data on the safety of mRNA COVID-19 vaccination in pregnant individuals.
⠀
Key findings:
⠀
1. The side effects were similar in pregnant vs. non pregnant individuals. There were small differences: injection site pain was more common in pregnant persons, but systemic side effects like fever and headaches were more common in non-pregnant persons.
⠀
2. Although not directly comparable, the proportion of adverse pregnancy & neonatal outcomes among the participants who completed pregnancies (i.e. delivered) in the v-safe registry were similar to published incidences in pregnant population studies just before the pandemic.
⠀
3. Out of the participants who had a live birth, 98.3% of participants received their first dose in the 3rd trimester. We do not have enough data on first trimester vaccination from this cohort yet!
⠀
Bottom line: these early findings did not show obvious safety issues with respect to pregnancy or neonatal outcomes associated with COVID-19 vaccination in the third trimester of pregnancy. More data is needed to assess outcomes associated with COVID-19 vaccination in the earlier stages of pregnancy.
⠀
To read the full article, visit this webpage: https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa2104983#.YIGGenKyhrw.twitter
⠀

1/ “My husband and I started trying for our first baby in April 2019. We finally had success and I got my first positive pregnancy test in December 2019, unfortunately just a week later I miscarried over Christmas. I felt so broken and alone. We kept trying after that using it as a positive sign to keep going.
⠀
When the pandemic hit, I remember questioning if we should still try, is it safe for me and the baby? After our miscarriage there truly wasn't any stopping us, of course we would still try. We had gotten so close already.
⠀
Exactly a year later we got pregnancy. April 2020. We were so naively confident that by January 2021 when our baby was due that the pandemic surely had to be over. Little did we know then that we'd be giving birth in a second wave and a second provincial wide lock down.
⠀
The pregnancy was totally normal and healthy. Over the months I truly loved being at home sharing my bump when we could. Overall, I was able to remain positive. After the miscarriage, It was hard to celebrate the pregnancy for a while, it was hard to be excited with people because all I could say was "it's still early, anything could happen”
⠀
I was so scared of losing the baby. At 16 weeks I had a kidney stone for the first time and rushed to the ER thinking that was it.
⠀

Today (May 3, 2021) NACI released an updated statement regarding the COVID-19 vaccine in pregnancy. 

Key updates include: 

1. COVID-19 vaccine may be offered to pregnant individuals after a risk assessment & informed consent

2. mRNA vaccines (i.e. pfizer and moderna) are preferred for use in pregnancy, due to recently published data on their safety in pregnant women and VITT (i.e. the rare vector associated vaccine-induced blood clots) is more complicated to treat in pregnancy 
To read the full guidelines visit: 
https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/immunization/national-advisory-committee-on-immunization-naci/recommendations-use-covid-19-vaccines/summary-updated-statement-may-3-2021.html

caption:
For World Maternal Mental Health Day we have compiled a list of FREE, ONLINE mental health resources. This was adapted from a list done by Aarti Dhanda, a social worker and therapist in Toronto.

Perinatal mental health disorders are the most common complication of childbirth and pregnancy, with 1 in 5 Canadian women affected.  Perinatal mental health issues can arise anytime during pregnancy up to the first year postpartum. It is  important to note that perinatal mood disorders impact BIPOC mothers and LGBTQ2S+ birthing parents at higher rates.  

Please know that if you or someone you know is struggling, it’s ok to be not be ok.  Mental health concerns often go untreated as it can be difficult to reach out for support because the symptoms can be dismissed, it may not be clear where to ask for help and despite it being so common, there remains significant stigma related to it.  By openly discussing mental health concerns, we can raise awareness and help us all feel less alone in these struggles.  

Motherhood and parenthood are no small feat and they can carry emotional, physical and mental weight that has been magnified during the pandemic.  We at PPG are here to support you and help you access the resources you need. 

Do you have any resources you have found helpful and want to share with others? Please comment down below and share with our community.

caption:
Our very own Dr. Tali Bogler (@talibogler) recently discussed the increasing number of questions and reports around menstrual cycle changes after the COVID-19 vaccine with Global News: https://globalnews.ca/news/7841955/covid-19-vaccine-irregular-menstruation/
⠀
There is no clear evidence yet linking the COVID-19 vaccine with menstrual changes (this is currently being studied by researchers at the University of Illinois: (https://redcap.healthinstitute.illinois.edu/surveys/index.php?s=LL8TKKC8DP) but increasing number of reports are surfacing online of women reporting changes in their menstrual cycles shortly after receiving the COVID-19 vaccine (i.e. breakthrough bleeding, heavier, and/or more painful menses). These menstrual changes are short term (i.e. for the 1-2 cycles immediately post vaccination) and do not last. There is also no relationship with possible short-term menstrual changes post vaccination and future infertility. However, if you do experience changes in your menstrual cycle after receiving the COVID-19 vaccine it is important to tell your doctor.
⠀
“It’s somewhat infuriating, I believe, when I feel like I can’t counsel my patients — women who are menstruating,— on the full spectrum of potential side effects that could impact them. … I don’t want my patients surprised if they have spotting, or earlier bleeding, or heavier menses.”
⠀
“But Bogler said this gap in research is not shocking. In fact, it consistently presents itself in numerous issues that affect women — like how pregnant individuals were left out of the COVID-19 initial vaccine trials.”
⠀
“I think [this] really highlights how there are inequities in the way we study vaccines, study treatments, and deliver our treatments to our populations,” she said.”
⠀

caption:
In honour of International Kangaroo Care Awareness Day, we are sharing a study by Sinha et al. (2021), recently published in JAMA, on the effect of “community-initiated kangaroo mother care” on postpartum depression. You are probably wondering...what in the world is Community-initiated Kangaroo Care?

Community-initiated Kangaroo Care = promotion of skin-to-skin contact and exclusive breastfeeding during the neonatal period.

This study found that Community-Initiated Kangaroo Mother Care (which was supported by home visits until 28 days after birth) was effective at reducing moderate to severe postpartum depression symptoms in mothers of low-birth-weight infants. This highlights that interventions in the immediate postpartum period can be effective in preventing poor maternal mental health outcomes and emphasizes the need to advocate for more support during this time period.

To read the full article, visit this webpage: https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamanetworkopen/fullarticle/2779045

caption:
If there is a possibility of an unplanned pregnancy for any reason, emergency contraception can be used to reduce the risk of a pregnancy. In the past, the two main categories of emergency contraception are the “morning after pills” and the copper IUD.
⠀
A recent study published in the New England Journal of Medicine has shown evidence to suggest that levonorgestrel (hormonal - Mirena/Kyleena) IUDs are also safe and not inferior to copper IUDs as emergency contraception. This new data can help guide care providers in offering levonorgestrel IUDs as a new option.We are excited that there are more options available in the realm of women’s health to allow for more personal choice and increased access.
⠀
Swipe to read more about IUDs and the results of the study...
⠀
The study can be found here: https://www.nejm.org/doi/10.1056/NEJMoa2022141
⠀
For more information about contraception, please visit this website from the Society of Obstetricians and Gynecologists of Canada: https://www.sexandu.ca
⠀

caption:
For #MedicalMonday this week, many people have asked us about breastfeeding and the COVID-19 vaccine:
⠀
In light of recent research showing that antibodies from mRNA COVID-19 vaccines can pass through breast milk, we’ve received many questions about breastfeeding and the protection breast milk from COVID-19 vaccinated mothers might provide to their babies.
⠀
We know from other vaccines, antibodies can be transferred through breast milk but only provide some immunity. As well, antibody transfer is greater in pregnancy vs. breast milk, which is why we recommend the whooping cough vaccine during pregnancy and not after delivery.
⠀
We also want to acknowledge that breastfeeding is not always easy and for many mothers there are significant barriers to breastfeeding. Additionally, relactation is a challenging process and may only yield a small volume of milk.
⠀
Finally, we’ve also had questions about milk sharing from a COVID-19 vaccinated individual. It is important to note that there are risks to sharing unpasteurized breast milk and the Canadian Paediatric Society recommends against this. If you are considering milk sharing, please speak with your healthcare provider.
⠀
Bottom line:
Many studies have shown that antibodies from mRNA COVID-19 vaccines CAN pass through breast milk! Right now there is little evidence to recommend prolonging breastfeeding/pumping for older children etc. because most immunity to baby is from antibodies transferred via the placenta during pregnancy rather than breast milk. It is also unknown IF and HOW these antibodies in breast milk actually protect the baby from COVID-19. At this time, the best protection for your baby is to consider getting vaccinated during pregnancy and to encourage those around you to get vaccinated.
⠀

caption:
Today (May 28, 2021) NACI released updated guidance regarding the COVID-19 vaccine in pregnancy and breastfeeding.

Key update:
The mRNA COVID-19 vaccine SHOULD be offered to pregnant and breastfeeding individuals. Previously, the statement had: The vaccine MAY be offered after a risk assessment & informed consent. Even though it’s a ONE word difference…. It’s a BIG change. 

To read the full guidelines visit: 

https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/immunization/national-advisory-committee-on-immunization-naci/recommendations-use-covid-19-vaccines/summary-updated-statement-may-28-2021.html

caption:
We at PPG are devastated to learn about the 215 children found at the former Kamloops Residential School.  We stand in solidarity with Indigenous communities.  We are holding space for all 215 children, their families and for all Indigenous people who are experiencing this unimaginable news.  We also hold space for the thousands more who’s stories have been told and for those who may never have their stories told. 

We recognize as healthcare providers, we have a role in understanding and working to rectify how systemic racism affects our Indigenous patients.  There are significant maternal health disparities between Indigenous and non-Indigenous Canadians (Kolahdooz et al, 2016).  Compared to Caucasian mothers in Canada, Indigenous mothers are 20% more likely to suffer from prenatal and postpartum depression.  A 2015 Voices and PHACES study found that almost all of the pregnant Indigenous women interviewed reported being deeply and negatively impacted by having someone in their life who survived the Residential School system (@cpmhc).   

We are sharing Indigenous based resources for Indigenous community members who may be looking for support.  We acknowledge and are grateful to @wchindigenoushealth @queerveganeducator @cpmhc for sharing these resources.

We have received many questions about whether or not the COVID-19 vaccine can transfer through the placenta to the fetus OR through breast milk. So for #medicalmonday we are sharing a recent study published in the Journal of Clinical Investigation, which provides evidence that the mRNA vaccine itself does NOT cross the placenta. Only antibodies for protection against COVID-19 infection cross the placenta.

The vaccine was shown to induce a strong immune response in pregnant women and effective transfer of IgG antibodies across the placenta, potentially providing significant protection to the newborn against COVID-19 infection as early as TWO WEEKS after the FIRST vaccine dose. This also helps answer the other very common question around whether any protection from the mom can be transferred after only one dose of the vaccine.

What about potential transfer of the vaccine in breast milk? In another pre-print study (not yet peer-reviewed or published in a medical journal), the mRNA COVID-19 vaccines were NOT detected in breast milk samples 4-48 hours post-vaccination. This study provides evidence that COVID-19 mRNA vaccine itself does not transfer into breast milk and further strengthens the recommendation that breastfeeding individuals who receive a COVID-19 mRNA vaccine should continue to breastfeed their babies uninterrupted (i.e. no need to “pump and dump” or change your breastfeeding routine).

The studies can be found here: https://dm5migu4zj3pb.cloudfront.net/manuscripts/150000/150319/cache/150319.1-20210520093620-covered-e0fd13ba177f913fd3156f593ead4cfd.pdf
https://www.medrxiv.org/content/10.1101/2021.03.05.21252998v1.full.pdf
