caption:
For #MEDICALMONDAY, we are sharing results from a recent study that looked at the placentas from patients who received the COVID-19 vaccine during pregnancy.
⠀
The study compared 84 patients who received the COVID-19 vaccine during pregnancy and 116 pregnant patients who did not receive the vaccine during pregnancy - all of whom were negative for COVID-19 infection.
⠀
The results showed that vaccinated pregnant women had very good antibody responses. When examining the placentas of those who were vaccinated vs. not, there was NO increase in placental abnormalities or placental injury.
⠀
Why is it important for us to look at the placenta?
 
1. Placentas are like the “black box” of pregnancies. When somethings goes wrong in the pregnancy, we often see changes in the placenta. 
 
2. There was a vaccine myth/theory floating around the internet several months ago claiming that the spike protein on COVID-19 (also encoded for by the COVID-19 vaccine) shares genetic similarities to syncytin-1 (an important protein for placental development). The claim went on to say that if our antibodies attack the spike protein, perhaps they can also attack syncytin-1 and damage the placenta. See our video with @alex.dainis from back in January that reviews why this theory is not biologically plausible, as the genetic sequence similarity between the two proteins is only 3% (which is essentially nothing in the genetics world). This most recent study is just further proof that the COVID-19 vaccine does not affect the placenta.
 
3. There ARE some studies showing that COVID-19 infection itself can cause concerning changes to the placenta
⠀
The bottom line of this study is that COVID-19 vaccination in pregnancy is associated with a very good antibody response without placental injury. This study adds to the growing body of literature suggesting COVID-19 vaccination is safe in pregnancy.
⠀
To read the full article, visit: https://journals.lww.com/greenjournal/fulltext/9900/severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome_coronavirus_2.206.aspx
⠀
tags: MEDICALMONDAY,

caption:
Unfortunately, the rising number of postpartum mental health visits during the pandemic is not surprising. We have heard this from our community on PPG and in our clinical practices. 

Yesterday, @cbc published an article, written by @laurenpelleycbc, that focuses on the increasing rates of mental health issues among new parents throughout the pandemic and the need for more supports. It discusses a study recently published in CMAJ by Vigod et al., that showed that there has been an increase in mental health visits among individuals in the postpartum period since the beginning of pandemic. The CMAJ article can be found by swiping up on our latest story or by visiting the following link: https://www.cmaj.ca/content/193/23/E835

This CBC article also features our very own, Dr. @talibogler, who emphasizes this increased mental health strain among pregnant individuals and new parents and highlights that this group is a “particularly vulnerable population at the best of times.” 

In this post we also share some free mental health resources (adapted from a list done by Aarti Dhanda, a social worker and therapist in Toronto) that we encourage you to check out. If you are struggling, although we know it can be difficult, please reach out for help and know that you are not alone. Mental health conditions and struggles are so common during the peripartum time and yet they often go undiagnosed and untreated. The PPG team is here to support you and help you access the resources you need. 

#pandemicpregnancy #mentalhealthmatters #ppa #ppd #postpartumanxiety #postpartumdepression #supportnewmoms #youarenotalone #mentalhealthawareness

caption:
CW: intimate partner violence, sexual assault.
.
.
.
There is a shadow pandemic of increased intimate partner violence (IPV) happening during the COVID-19 pandemic. A new study conducted by The Ottawa Hospital has revealed that nearly 25% of 216 respondents experienced forms of abusive behaviour, such as having their whereabouts controlled or contact with friends and family limited, during the perinatal period. Of note, there were few cases of physical and sexual assault reported in this study. Studies conducted before the pandemic estimated that approximately 3-9% of people experienced intimate partner violence during their perinatal period. 

Authors @darine5, @drmarkcwalker, @kmuldoon and colleagues at The Ottawa Hospital (@ottawahospital), found those with a household income less than $119,400 per year are 3x times more likely to encounter IPV. During health emergencies such as the COVID-19 pandemic, stress and loss of income are among many factors that can exacerbate the risk of violence. 

Intimate partner violence occurs in ALL settings and among ALL socioeconomic, religious, and cultural groups. During pregnancy, intimate partner violence has been associated with complications including preterm birth, miscarriage, stillbirth, low birth weight infants, and newborn injury or death. It is essential for our society to recognize the prevalence and impact of IPV, work to prevent IPV, and offer support to help people survive and escape violent situations. 

We are hoping to add awareness to the prevalence and impact of intimate partner violence, which has increased during the pandemic. We are aware that this post may be upsetting to read. If you are in crisis and in need of support, please reach out for help. The Assaulted Women’s Helpline offers a 24/7 crisis line to support women who have experienced abuse, which can be accessed toll-free at 1-866-863-0511.

We have provided a list of resources you can access if you, or someone you know, is impacted by IPV. We will also share these resources to our stories, in case you do not wish to read through the post.

⁣Many of you have shared your questions or concerns regarding the COVID-19 vaccine & fertility, particularly those actively trying to conceive or undergoing fertility treatments. We are sharing a few recent studies to provide some further reassurance on this topic.⠀
⠀
Why are these studies important?⠀
Initial COVID-19 vaccine trials excluded those actively trying to conceive, pregnant or breastfeeding, which led to rumours being spread on the internet around the covid-19 vaccine and infertility. This myth has since been debunked, as there is no biological plausible reason why the COVID-19 vaccine would impact fertility, however to further help put this myth to rest, we are sharing some additional studies looking at this very question. These studies provide further evidence that mRNA COVID-19 vaccines (Pfizer was the specific vaccine used in these studies) do NOT appear to impact fertility or fertility treatment outcomes.⠀
⠀
Studies can be found at:⠀
https://www.medrxiv.org/content/10.1101/2021.04.09.21255195v1⠀
https://www.medrxiv.org/content/10.1101/2021.05.30.21258079v1⠀
⠀
#pregnancy #ttc #infertility #tryingtoconceive #fertility #infertility #infertilitywarriors #pandemicpregnancy⠀
⠀

caption:
Happy Father’s Day to all the fathers, father figures, fathers to be and fathers that are missed. Also sending love to those who may struggle with this day for whatever reason. We see you. 

If you feel comfortable, share your wishes to your dads in the comments below. ❤️

In honour of Father’s Day yesterday, we’ve decided to focus on men’s health for our #medicalmonday this week, specifically male fertility, in relation to COVID-19 infection and the COVID-19 vaccine.
⠀
As we’ve previously covered on PPG, rumours have spread online in relation to the COVID-19 vaccine and infertility. Most of these myths/theories (which have since been debunked) focused on women’s fertility. This is not new, as many anti-vaxx groups have used fear mongering around women’s future fertility with other vaccines in the past. But what about men’s health? What about studies pertaining to the COVID-19 vaccine and male fertility? And what is the research on COVID-19 infection itself on men’s health and future fertility?
⠀
So today, we’re sharing a recent study published on June 17, 2021 that investigated sperm before and after COVID-19 vaccination, including semen volume, sperm concentration, sperm motility, and total motile sperm count, as well as evidence about COVID-19 infection and erectile dysfunction.
⠀
What is the bottom line?!
⠀
Despite circulating concerns regarding the COVID-19 vaccine and male infertility, there is NO evidence indicating that sperm parameters are affected by the vaccine. On the contrary, COVID-19 infection itself has been linked to a nearly 6x increased risk of developing erectile dysfunction. #gettheshottokeepithot
⠀
To read the full studies cited here: https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2781360?guestAccessKey=17114e03-640c-4688-b1c2-9ed8b936c3cd&utm_source=For_The_Media&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=ftm_links&utm_content=tfl&utm_term=061721
⠀
https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/andr.13003
⠀
tags: gettheshottokeepithot, medicalmonday

caption:
We've received lots of messages about mix and matching COVID-19 vaccines in pregnancy. Here is the National Advisory Committee on Immunization (NACI)’s statement explaining that the same mRNA product should be offered for 2nd dose, BUT if the same product is not readily available, another mRNA vaccine is considered INTERCHANGEABLE and SHOULD be used to complete the series.
⠀
There have been no studies on this specifically in pregnancy, but there is no reason for us to believe that this would be ANY DIFFERENT in the pregnant population. In terms of Pfizer and Moderna: 1) both of their mRNA sequences code for the same full length of the spike protein 2) their lipid envelopes are different, however, this can actually be a good thing and help boost the immune response 3) finally, we use vaccines interchangeably for so many other diseases like Tetanus and Hepatitis.
⠀
Bottom line: According to NACI, Moderna and Pfizer COVID-19 vaccines are considered interchangeable and should be used to complete your vaccination series if the same product is not available.
⠀

Canadian basketball player Kim Gaucher (@kgaucher) may be forced to choose between participating in the Tokyo Olympics and breastfeeding her 3-month-old infant daughter due to COVID-19 rules that prevent family from attending the Summer Games.
⠀
As Erin Durant, a trial lawyer based in Ontario who is not involved with Gaucher's case said: "As we know in other areas of society, sometimes, uniform rules impact people much, much differently and can result in discrimination."
⠀
We at PPG strongly support keeping babies and moms together, and feel it is important for the IOC @olympics to recognize how uniform policies may be harmful to certain groups or individuals. This is an important step towards ‘Making working moms normal'
⠀
How does this make you feel? How can we as a community help advocate for Kim Gaucher?
⠀
Please let us know your thoughts in the comments below.
⠀
Full article: https://www.cbc.ca/sports/olympics/summer/basketball/olympics-canada-basketball-kim-gaucher-breastfeeding-1.6078717

caption:
“Access to birth close to home, surrounded by loved ones, is taken for granted by most Canadians.”
⠀
For #MEDICALMONDAY, we are sharing a study published in the Canadian Medical Association Journal by our colleague Smylie et al., comparing long distance travel for birth among Indigenous vs. non-Indigenous individuals living in rural and urban areas within Canada.
⠀
This research highlights the inequities Indigenous individuals face socially and in accessing obstetrical care close to home, family members and their communities. It demonstrates the need to improve access to pregnancy care in these communities to ensure every Canadian can give birth close to home, surrounded by loved ones and in a culturally acceptable manner.
⠀
Dr. Smylie et. al conclude “To address these inequities and better align with international law (United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples, www.un.org/esa/socdev/unpfii/documents/DRIPS_en.pdf), the Calls to Action of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canada (www.trc.ca/assets/pdf/Honouring_the_Truth_Reconciling_for_the_Future_July_23_2015.pdf) and the Calls for Justice of the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (www.mmiwg-ffada.ca/final-report/), there is a pressing need to advance policies, facilities and services to increase geographic access to birth closer to home.”
⠀
To read the full article, visit: https://www.cmaj.ca/content/193/25/E948#ref-5
⠀

caption:
#MedicalMonday During the pandemic, health care pivoted to virtual care, including prenatal care. 

This was critical to reduce exposure to COVID-19 and had other advantages including, improved access to care and convenience (avoided transit costs, lost productivity for patients, child-care demands etc.).

However, an important question remained: would this model (mix between in-person and virtual prenatal care) have any impact on pregnancy outcomes?

One study recently published in the Lancet (July 3, 2021) by Palmer et al. looked at this question. This study, done in Australia, showed that integration of telehealth in prenatal care did NOT compromise pregnancy outcomes.

Another study, published in @jamanetwork and conducted in Texas, also showed there was NO difference in the frequency of adverse perinatal outcomes between individuals who had a blend of in-person and audio virtual prenatal visits. Importantly, the majority of participants in this study were from low-income communities and found that implementation of virtual visits was associated with a greater attendance rate of prenatal visits.

Bottom line: Studies so far have shown that prenatal care models incorporating virtual care are safe, effective, and not associated with changes in perinatal outcomes. Beyond the COVID-19 pandemic, models that incorporate virtual pregnancy care may be beneficial for those who face barriers to accessing care in person.

As we begin to enter the recovery phase of the pandemic…
-What has been your experience with virtual prenatal care this past year?
-Are there elements you hope will stay the same or change?
-Are you hoping to continue a combination of in-person and virtual prenatal care post-pandemic?

Share your experiences with us in the comments below.

⁣For this week's #MedicalMonday, we are sharing some fresh CANADIAN data- BORNOntario has recently released data showing the safety of COVID-19 vaccinations during pregnancy. Although COVID-19 vaccination safety has already been shown in US studies, this is the first Canadian data. It is important to note that this report is based on preliminary data and BORN Ontario will be conducting formal studies over time as more data becomes available. We will continue to share their data as it becomes available to us. 
⠀
Between December 14, 2020 and May 31, 2021, 30,892 pregnant persons received at least one dose of COVID-19 vaccine during pregnancy. Specifically, 25,012 (81.0%) received the Pfizer-BioNTech mRNA vaccine, 5,661 (18.3%) received the Moderna mRNA vaccine, 103 (0.3%) received a viral-vector vaccine (i.e., AstraZeneca or COVISHIELD), and 116 (0.4%) had missing information on type of vaccine received.⠀

To answer the questions ppl have sent:
➡️ these are preliminary findings for period between December 2020-May 2021
➡️129,000 pregnant ppl in ON during that time period, 1/4 received at least 1 vaxx & most were given in April 2021 (when pregnant ppl were prioritized)
➡️On average, pregnant individuals received the vaccine around 25 weeks gestation
➡️As of May 31, 2021, 85% of the vaccinated pregnant women still had not given birth yet (future reports will be able to report on their pregnancy and birth outcomes)
➡️among those vaccinated who had already given birth, there was no increased risk for poor pregnancy or birth outcomes
⠀
The bottom line of this study is that the cumulative rates of pregnancy and risk for stillbirth, preterm labour, or small babies among vaccinated pregnant persons did not differ from the background rates and birth outcomes in Ontario.⠀
⠀
In addition, an article published today in JAMA demonstrates that COVID-19 vaccines are effective at reducing the rate of infection in pregnancy. 
Link to article: 
https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2782047?guestAccessKey=119e3c9e-dcab-42ff-95ce-e9fb7ff5e1c9&utm_source=silverchair&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=article_alert-jama&utm_content=olf&utm_term=071221.⠀
⠀

caption:
Preeclampsia is a serious medical condition which includes a new onset of high blood pressure (systolic >140 and/or diastolic >90) after 20 weeks of gestation AND signs or symptoms of damage to your body. It can occur in patients with pre-existing high blood pressure and it is often associated with protein in your urine. High blood pressure can result in serious complications for both the mother and the baby, to organs such as the brain, heart, kidneys and eyes. Some symptoms of preeclampsia include headache, visual changes and abdominal pain. For details about signs and symptoms of preeclampsia, please visit our post on gestational hypertension. 

There is no cure for preeclampsia other than delivery. Therefore, prevention is key. This is where low dose aspirin comes in. Taking a low dose aspirin does not take away your chances of developing preeclampsia. However, multiple studies have shown it does DECREASE your risk of developing preeclampsia, with no increased maternal or fetal complications. This post summarized the July 2018 ACOG guidelines on low-dose aspirin use during pregnancy, which can be found here https://tinyurl.com/nt2zhdjm

Taking low dose aspirin to prevent preeclampsia is recommended by many health authorities including the American College of Obstetrics & Gynecology (ACOG), US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTP), and the World Health Organization (WHO). Your healthcare provider may recommend low-dose aspirin for the prevention of preeclampsia if you have one or more HIGH-risk factors or two or more MODERATE-risk factors. Please see slides five and six for what these high and moderate-risk factors are.

Your healthcare provider (HCP) will recommend a dose between 80 -162 mg, ideally started between 11-16 weeks of gestation and taken before bed. Your HCP may then discontinue your low dose aspirin as different times, depending on your situation and preferences, but typically it is continued to at least 36 weeks of pregnancy. Speak to your provider about what option is best for you and if you should be taking low-dose aspirin.

This #MedicalMonday, we are sharing results from a study recently published in @jamanetwork that demonstrates that the Pfizer mRNA COVID-19 vaccine is EFFECTIVE at reducing the rate of infection in pregnancy.

The study conducted in Israel assessed the association between COVID-19 vaccination and the risk of COVID-19 infection among pregnant women. A total of 29,111 women were included in the full study cohort. Vaccinated pregnant women were 1:1 matched to unvaccinated women based on characteristics such as age, gestational age, residential area, population subgroup, and influenza immunization status. The main study group included 7540 vaccinated and 7530 matched unvaccinated women.

Overall, COVID-19 infection occurred in 118 vaccinated women and 202 unvaccinated women following a median (i.e., the “middle” value that separates the higher half from the lower half in a data set) of 37 days post-vaccination. Among those infected, 88 of 105 (83.8%) were symptomatic in the vaccine group vs 149 of 179 (83.2%) in the unvaccinated group. The hazards (i.e. risk) of infection were 0.33% and 1.64% in the vaccinated and unvaccinated group, respectively. Vaccine-related adverse events were non-severe and reported by only 68 patients, the most common ones being headache, general weakness, non specified pain, and stomachache - all lasting less than 1 day!

Why is this study important??? While we have shared data supporting the safety of COVID-19 vaccination in pregnancy and that pregnant individuals mount a good immune response after vaccination, there has been a lack of evidence on the effectiveness of the vaccine (it’s been assumed by the good immune response) in reducing rates of infection among pregnant women - until now. 

Bottom line: mRNA COVID-19 vaccination compared with no vaccination is associated with a significantly lower risk of COVID-19 infection in pregnant women.

July 19-25, 2021 is Black Maternal Mental Health Week. ⁣
⁣
Between 20-25% of mothers suffer from perinatal mood and anxiety disorders (National Perinatal Association). Black mothers may face even more challenges.  According to a 2019 study in the Archives of Women’s Mental Health, close to 40% of Black mothers will suffer from postpartum depression. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
To be able to understand and help navigate the nuances of systemic racism and oppression, many find it helpful to find someone who understands their experience and history, because they themselves have lived through similar.  Today, in honour of Black Maternal Mental Health Week, we are sharing mental health resources aimed at supporting Black individuals.  Please share widely.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
We would like to acknowledge and thank @marissalamour @quirkylindsayharle and https://www.blackmentalhealthday.ca/resources for sharing these resources.⁣⁣
⁣⁣

caption:
As public health measures gradually allow for more interactions and larger gatherings, more kids are catching colds and non-COVID19 viruses again.  To address this, @torontostar met with Dr. Eddie Lau, a pediatrician at @unityhealthto in Toronto. ⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
Why is this happening? ⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
“There’s a number of common viruses that are around all the time and when you are around other people in closer contact, you’re more likely to spread them,” Dr. Lau said.⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
While this may be worrisome, this is not necessarily bad news. “It’s good for them to get exposed to these less significant viruses because it basically primes their immune systems to develop responses to them so that their immune system gets trained to fight illnesses,” Lau said. ⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
Dr. Lau shares these tips to keep your kids safe as society begin to reopen:⁣⁣⁣⁣
•	Encourage healthy hygiene habits like wearing a mask and proper handwashing.⁣⁣⁣⁣
•	If your child has a fever for no more than two or three days and they’re eating and drinking well, generally some “TLC” will work.  Give anti-fever medication and make sure they stay hydrated.⁣⁣⁣⁣
•	If your child’s fever persists, they have a loss of appetite or have any other concerning symptoms, they should get checked by a doctor. ⁣⁣⁣⁣
•	Newborns should also be taken to a doctor immediately since they’re more vulnerable to severe infections compared to older children.⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
Bottom line, we are going to start seeing more infections as we begin interacting more.  Follow these tips and remember that your healthcare providers are here for you, so please don’t be afraid to get your child checked if you are concerned. ⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Link to full article: https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/2021/07/21/more-kids-are-starting-to-catch-colds-again-heres-why.html⁣
⁣

caption:
For today’s (belated) #MedMonday, we are focusing on something a little different: sexual health during the COVID-19 pandemic. Many predicted that spending more time at home during the pandemic would lead to increased sexual activity and a “post-pandemic baby boom” but what’s really happening between the sheets?

A study by Brotto et al., from UBC investigated the sexual health of Canadians during the pandemic. The study team surveyed >1000 Canadians (aged 19-81) on 4 facets (desire, behavior, compliance, coercion) of sexual health from April to August 2020 (important to note: the majority of respondents were heterosexual women).

Bottom line: This study contributes to well-established literature showing that the relationship between sexual desire and sexual behavior is NOT linear and positive, but rather complex and impacted by the environment. This suggests that there are factors contributing to sexual desire beyond the contribution of stress that must be considered in the context of COVID-19. It also highlights that increased supports for mental health and sexuality will be important to help re-cultivate sexual health as we move forward.

One important note of the study: While overall rates of sexual coercion were low in this study, COVID-19-related stress has led to increased rates of sexual violence. These results are concerning given the possible long-term effects of stress persisting post-pandemic and the recognized rise of intimate partner violence (IPV). *If you are experiencing IPV, please see our highlights titled “IPV” for resources.* 

Swipe through the slides to learn more about the findings in this study.

You can find the full study here: https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/19317611.2021.1947932

caption:
Have you ever wondered about what fibroids are and how they might affect pregnancy? 

Uterine fibroids are non-cancerous growths of the smooth muscle layer of the uterus. They grow in various locations within the uterus and can vary in number, shape, size, and location. Fibroids are very common and occur in 70-80% of women by the age of 50. Many women have fibroids without having any symptoms. You may find out that you have fibroids during one of your pregnancy ultrasounds. 

Risk factors for developing fibroids include: age, getting your period early (before age 12), women who have never had a baby, obesity, increased frequency of menses, family history of fibroids, and individuals of African/Black descent. 

Symptoms that you may experience if you have fibroids include: heavy/irregular/long periods, pelvic pain/pressure, pain with sex, low iron or hemoglobin levels, increased urinary frequency (need to pee), constipation, and fertility issues.

Not all fibroids cause infertility, however they can if in a submucosal (the space where the baby grows) location. In some studies, submucosal fibroids have shown to negatively impact fertility (getting pregnancy and staying pregnant). In patients with submucosal fibroids and no other cause for infertility, these fibroids can be removed surgically.

There are limited studies on how fibroids change in size throughout pregnancy. There is some evidence that if they grow, it tends to happen in the first trimester and then may shrink postpartum. Possible pregnancy complications from fibroids include: pain, early miscarriage, small babies (requiring more frequent ultrasounds), preterm labour, separation of the placenta from the uterus before birth, babies not being head down at the end of the pregnancy.

If you have previously had fibroid removal surgery (myomectomy), you may need a C-section for delivery. Depending on the size and location of the fibroids, your baby may not be head down at the end of pregnancy. Lastly, fibroids in the lower part of the uterus or cervix may block the ability to have a vaginal delivery. Talk to your healthcare provider to see if your fibroids may impact your mode of delivery.

This #MedicalMonday, we are sharing the results of the ARRIVE Trial: A Randomized Trial of Induction Versus Expectant Management in low-risk first-time pregnant women. Recommendations on the timing of delivery are based on balancing maternal and fetal risks.

This study was conducted to determine if elective induction of labour (starting labour without a medical reason) during the 39th week of pregnancy (the week before the due date) would result in a lower rate of serious complications or death for babies around the time of delivery compared to the usual practice of waiting to induce labour until at least 5 days after the due date (40 weeks and 5 days). Researchers also wanted to know if inductions had an affect on the odds of Caesarean delivery.

Researchers screened more than 50,000 individuals across 41 hospitals in the U.S. and identified eligible participants as being “nulliparous” (first-time mothers) and “low-risk” (carrying a single, head-down baby with no major medical conditions). Of those participants that were eligible and agreed to participate, 3062 pregnant women were placed into the induction at 39 weeks group (induced between 39 weeks and 0 days and 39 weeks and 4 days) while 3044 pregnant women were placed into the expectant management group. Expectant management meant that pregnant women would a) wait for labour to begin on its own; b) be induced for medical reasons at any point necessary; or c) be induced electively after 40 weeks and 5 days.

What did the researchers find? Induction of labour at 39 weeks did not improve the outcome of perinatal death or serious complications in babies (i.e., there was no difference in this outcome between the induction group and expectant management group). For mothers, induction at 39 weeks compared to expectant management resulted in a LOWER rate of Caesarean delivery (19% vs. 22%) and a LOWER risk of developing pregnancy-related high blood pressure (9% vs. 14%). Mothers in the early induction group spent more time in the labour and delivery unit, but LESS time in hospital postpartum.

Continued in comments below!⬇️

caption:
The Canadian Paediatric Society recently released a position statement on the use of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) or serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) in pregnancy. 

Common SSRIs include citalopram (Celexa), Escitalopram (Cipralex), Sertraline (Zoloft), Fluoxetine (Prozac), and Paroxetine (Paxil). Common SNRIs include venlafaxine (Effexor).

The bottom line is: Use of an SSRI or SNRI to treat depression during pregnancy is safe for, and well tolerated by the baby, whereas untreated maternal depression or anxiety is associated with adverse outcomes for both the parent and newborn. Although non-pharmacological treatments are considered first line for anxiety and depression, families should be supported when deciding to use an antidepressant medication during pregnancy or in the postpartum period.

Perinatal mood disorders are common and help is available. Please see our previous mental health related posts in our ‘Mental Health’ highlight, including our lists of perinatal and postpartum mental health resources posted on May 5, 2021 and July 2, 2020.

To access the full position statement, visit: https://www.cps.ca/en/documents/position/selective-serotonin

caption:
This study in the UK, published on Aug 1, looked at 133 pregnant individuals who came to give birth at a single hospital centre in London who had at least 1 COVID-19 vaccine and matched them (for age, ethnicity, pre-pregnancy diabetes etc.) with 399 pregnant women who were not vaccinated. The study found NO differences in: stillbirth, birth defects, small for gestational age (low birth weight), C-Section rates, maternal or neonatal ICU admission, delivery less than 40 weeks, or other labour complications. 

TL:DR This reassuring study out of the UK contributes to the large body of evidence that COVID-19 vaccination in pregnancy is NOT associated with adverse pregnancy or newborn outcomes. . 

Bottom line: Pregnant individuals are are still reluctant to take the COVID-19 vaccine despite a large body of evidence indicating that it is safe and effective in pregnancy. Clear communication & targeted strategies are needed to address concerns related to the vaccine in pregnancy, including more research and gathering additional data on pregnancy outcomes, particularly first trimester vaccination and long-term infant follow-up. 

You can read the full study here: https://www.ajog.org/article/S0002-9378(21)00873-5/pdf

Today, we are reviewing an article from this past April, 2021 discussing the rise in alcohol consumption among women during the pandemic. We are not addressing the WHO draft statement released in June regarding Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorder (FASD) and the issues with the WHO statement (more on this another time); rather, we are discussing alcohol use in women in general, particularly during the pandemic, and the associated health consequences. We are hoping to discuss alcohol use (rising alcohol consumption in women, concerns around the WHO draft statement and its paternalistic approach, alcohol use in pregnancy, “mommy wine culture” etc.) over the next few weeks. Stay tuned for more.⠀
⠀
⠀
Did you know that drinking 2 glasses of wine/day, increases your risk of breast cancer by 50%? Or that drinking 3-6 alcoholic beverages/week increases your risk of breast cancer by 15%? Many are not aware of of this and we need to talk about it.⠀
⠀
⠀
Public Health Canada’s chief officer identified alcohol use in women as one of the most pressing concerns of our time. If you are concerned about your risk, or you are worried about a loved one - reach out to your primary care provider for resources in your community. If you don't have a primary care provider, we are sharing online resources that are accessible to all. We will continue to share resources in the weeks to come.⠀
⠀
⠀

caption:
You might be wondering, what is the big announcement? What was the CDC recommending before and why the update now? 

Until now, the CDC said the COVID-19 vaccine COULD be offered during pregnancy; the recent update in guidance strengthens the official advice, now URGING pregnant people to be immunized. 

This update in guidance is reportedly due to new safety data (pre-print study: https://www.researchsquare.com/article/rs-798175/v1) suggesting that receipt of COVID-19 mRNA vaccines preconception or in early pregnancy (before 20 weeks gestation) is not associated with an increased risk of a miscarriage. There is also a large body of evidence at this point indicating that the vaccine is safe and effective in pregnancy. The CDC is now in line with recommendations made by ACOG and other American obstetrical and public health societies and organizations.

What about Canada? Well, the Public Health Agency of Canada in accordance with the National Advisory Committee on Immunizations has already RECOMMENDED getting a full series of an mRNA COVID-19 vaccine while pregnant or breastfeeding. 

We hope this helps put things into context a bit more.

To read more about the CDC’s guidance: https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/covid-19/clinical-considerations/covid-19-vaccines-us.html

To read more about NACI’s guidance: https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/immunization/national-advisory-committee-on-immunization-naci/recommendations-use-covid-19-vaccines.html

Picture reference: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/08/11/health/vaccine-pregnant-cdc.html

caption:
This #MedicalMonday, we are sharing a pre-print study from the CDC v-safe pregnancy registry on the safety of COVID-19 vaccines in pregnancy. The new safety data obtained from the v-safe pregnancy registry was used to inform the recent CDC update in guidance urging pregnant people to be immunized. 

What is v-safe? V-safe is a smartphone-based tool in the U.S. available for voluntary enrollment to those who have received the COVID-19 vaccine. Through text messaging and web-based surveys, v-safe is designed to provide personalized health check-ins following receipt of the COVID-19 vaccine. Those who reported they were pregnant at the time of vaccination were invited to enroll in the v-safe pregnancy registry, which involved telephone follow-ups each trimester, during the postpartum period, and 3 months following live birth. 

What are the results of this study? Among the 2,456 pregnant women who received an mRNA COVID-19 vaccine preconception or in early pregnancy (prior to 20 weeks’ gestation), the risk of miscarriage prior to 20 weeks was 12.8% (age-adjusted). 

BOTTOM LINE: Compared to the miscarriage rate across all pregnancies (12.5%-18.7%), receipt of the mRNA COVID-19 vaccine preconception or prior to 20 weeks’ gestation is NOT associated with increased risk of miscarriage. This adds to the growing body of evidence supporting the vaccine is safe & effective in pregnancy.

caption:
This week, the Taliban gained control over Afghanistan’s capital, Kabul. The Taliban has not had rule over the country since 2001 and already there have been reports of restrictions of human rights, particularly for women and girls (i.e., forced to stop working/going to school).
⠀
This post outlines 4 things that you can do to support and help protect those in need in Afghanistan . These include: (1) learning more about the crisis from trustworthy sources, (2) donating to humanitarian organizations if it is available to you, (3) supporting female Afghan voices and protecting female journalists in Afghanistan, and (4) ensuring that those around you are well-supported.
⠀
Of note, the following accounts, among others, are offering free therapy sessions and/or support groups for Afghan individuals: @arghoshi_psychotherapy @wajma_omer_psychotherapy @prospecttherapy @restorationmha
⠀
At the end of this post we have included quotations from an Afghan woman who bravely shared her current experiences in Kabul. Please continue to amplify Afghan voices. To access the full Guardian article visit: https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/aug/15/an-afghan-woman-in-kabul-now-i-have-to-burn-everything-i-achieved?fbclid=IwAR0qWor4ZJDXZgYis-G-Ji4wxoK5cwlqGGV89qM3_I4TBPxLwkAEARQh9gY
⠀
Finally, we at PPG are committed to continuously learning and sharing. If you know of other ways to support and protect those in need in Afghanistan, please share these with our community in the comments below.
⠀

#MedicalMonday: BORN Ontario has released a 2nd report on their preliminary findings on COVID-19 vaccination during pregnancy. This infographic summarizes some of the key preliminary findings from 140,000 people who were pregnant from December 14, 2020 to June 30, 2021:

➡️28% (almost 40,000) received at least 1 COVID-19 vaccine during their pregnancy (between December 2020-June 2021).
➡️Out of 13,000 pregnant people who received 2 doses of a COVID-19 vaccine during pregnant, 84% received 2 doses of the SAME vaccine and 63% received the 2nd dose within 4-8 weeks of dose 1.
➡️The percentage of pregnant people receiving COVID-19 vaccines increased from <1% in December 2020 to over 45% in June 2021.
➡️For those who have already given birth, the data from this report DO NOT suggest any pattern of increased risk of poor pregnancy or birth outcomes.

You can read the full report here: https://www.bornontario.ca/en/whats-happening/resources/Documents/BORN-COVID-19-Vaccination-During-Pregnancy-in-Ontario-Report-2---FINAL.pdf

Check out @thisisourshotca's facebook Q&A on this topic featuring our very own Dr. @talibogler (Chair of Family Medicine Obstetrics, St Michael’s Hospital), Dr. Nav Grewal (Emergency Physician at Delta Hospital & MSJ) and @alysonschafer (Family Therapist & Parenting Expert).

What is the long-term safety of the mRNA COVID-19 vaccines? Are they safe for kids?
I am worried that the vaccines will affect my kids fertility - what do we know
about this? 
Similarly: Can vaccines affect puberty in adolescents? (eg. menstrual cycle)
I am worried about my children getting myocarditis/pericarditis with their shots - what is the risk of getting this?
Children seem less impacted by COVID-19 so why is it necessary for them to
get vaccinated?

Are the vaccines protective against variants? Specifically, this delta variant?
When will vaccines be available for kids under 12?
Will kids need booster shots for vaccines?
How do we keep our kids from getting infected when they go back to school?

Multiple studies have shown that COVID-19 vaccination leads to the production of antibodies that are transferred in breast milk. For #medicalmonday, we are sharing this new study which found that the presence of antibodies against COVID-19 in breast milk was higher in mothers who had been lactating for greater than 23 months compared to those who had been lactating for less than 23 months. Study link https://tinyurl.com/284tcn6k

First of all, we want to acknowledge that many people do not breastfeed this long, choose not to breastfeed or simply cannot breastfeed for various reasons.

Even though these are interesting findings, it is important to acknowledge what we still do not know: 

- How much breast milk is necessary to transfer a significant amount of antibodies from mother to child 
- The level of immunity that is conferred (i.e. is it robust or barely enough?) 
- How long the protection lasts  
- Furthermore, the amount of antibodies taken in by a baby depends on the volume of milk they consume and the amount of antibodies that happen to be contained in that volume. 

Also important to note that:
1. Antibodies in breast milk do not make it into the baby’s bloodstream, but rather coat the mouth, throat and gut and then eventually get digested 
2. The antibodies on the mucosal surface work by fighting off infections at the body’s entrance. This is different and less effective than being vaccinated in pregnancy, which can transfer antibodies into the baby’s bloodstream

BOTTOM LINE:

- Presence of antibodies against COVID-19 in breast milk was HIGHER in mothers who had been lactating for greater than 23 month 
- However, it is important to remember that antibody transfer through breast milk confers only some level of immunity compared to a child being fully vaccinated or vaccination during pregnancy and there are many unanswered questions regarding the immunity conferred. More research is needed.

Finally, we would also like to acknowledge that while we are sharing this information to keep everyone up to date on what we are learning about COVID-19 and perinatal health, breastfeeding is not an easy journey for many people for so many reasons…

caption:
For #MEDICALMONDAY, we are sharing the most recent science brief published by the Ontario COVID-19 Science Advisory Table on the incidence, severity, outcomes and implications of COVID-19 in Pregnancy. 

Summary of the science brief:
* The rate of SARS-CoV-2 infection in pregnancy does not appear to be higher than in the general population
* However, compared to their non-pregnant counterparts, pregnant individuals have higher morbidity and mortality, with a higher risk of intensive care unit (ICU) admission, mechanical ventilation, and need for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO). They also have a higher frequency of pre-eclampsia, Cesarean delivery, and a higher rate of preterm birth.  
* Care of the critically ill pregnant patient with COVID-19 requires a multidisciplinary team that includes obstetrics, neonatology, anesthesia, infectious diseases, medicine, and critical care.
* Vaccines against SARS-CoV-2 are safe to use among pregnant individuals and vaccination is highly recommended in this population. 

Key messages:
1. Despite the safety and efficacy of COVID-19 mRNA vaccines and the increased risk for severe disease in the pregnant population, vaccine uptake in pregnant individuals is lower than other higher-risk populations. 
2. Tailored messaging to increase vaccine confidence is needed — particularly considering more virulent Variants of Concern (VOCs).

caption:
#MedicalMonday Today we are sharing a study published in @jamanetwork showing that many women changed their pregnancy intentions once the COVID-19 pandemic hit. In this study from New York, 1179 women who were mothers of young children (but not currently pregnant) were asked about their plans for pregnancy after the first wave of COVID-19.

The study found that many people who were thinking of getting pregnant or actively trying to get pregnant were no longer considering pregnancy once the pandemic was declared. Out of those who were not thinking about getting pregnant, only 4.5% had started considering it. Swipe through the slides to see the exact statistics.

Out of those who changed their mind about pregnancy, those who STOPPED considering pregnancy were more likely to have public insurance, lower educational level, lower current financial security, or higher levels of stress. Finally, of those who were trying to get pregnant, Hispanic women were more likely to have stopped. Those who were newly thinking about getting pregnant were more likely to be non-Hispanic White.

Bottom line: This study showed that many women CHANGED their pregnancy intentions after the COVID-19 outbreak, and many were uncertain if their decision would change in the future. These uncertainties were associated with increased stress and financial insecurity. These findings are similar to what was seen during the 2008 economic recession and highlights the economic stress on women, especially working mothers and racialized women.

What about Canada - did COVID-19 lead to a baby boom or bust? Canada-wide birth data for 2020 isn’t available yet, BUT some places have reported a baby bust (although some hospitals have reported a 2021 summer baby boom).

Swipe to the end for a sample of the questionnaire used in this study. How might you have responded to this survey?

Full study text here: https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamanetworkopen/fullarticle/2784116

caption:
Join us on Tuesday September 28 at 7:30pm EST for a LIVE postpartum healing yoga practice with Anita Balakrishna. Note- this live will be saved for those who can’t make it.⠀
⠀
Anita has been exploring the practice of yoga for healing for the past 8 years.  She is a certified yoga teacher with over 1500+ hours of yoga teacher training from both Yoga Raksanam in Chennai, India and Yoga Therapy Toronto.  She is currently in the process of completing her yoga therapist certification from Yoga Therapy Toronto.⠀
⠀
Yoga practices, including asana (postures), pranayama (breath work) and dhyana (meditation), played an integral part in Anita preparing for her recent pregnancy as well as the healing that was required after her pregnancy.  When she is not busy looking after her new 3 month old son, Kiaan, she is continuing to explore new ways of incorporating yoga practices into her day.  She has recently started doing yoga practices with Kiaan, which brings great joy and peace. ⠀
⠀
Anita is also a trained lawyer and is currently the Director, Equity, Diversity and Inclusion for the Temerty Faculty of Medicine at the University of Toronto (currently on parental leave). She is extremely interested in the intersections between wellness, healing in community, social justice work, and equity.⠀

caption:
#MEDICALMONDAY: 10 POINTS breaking down the science and recommendations around acetaminophen (AKA Tylenol) use in pregnancy:

1⃣ The statement summarizes experimental & epidemiological studies suggesting acetaminophen use in pregnancy MIGHT alter fetal development which MIGHT increase the risks of some reproductive, urogenital and neurobehavioral disorders. The authors call for "precautionary action."
 
2⃣ There are LIMITATIONS to the studies referenced: 
1) Recall bias (inaccuracies in recalling acetaminophen use)
2) Difficulty disentangling whether it's the painful condition requiring acetaminophen, or acetaminophen itself, that might have a link to neurobehavioral problems.
 
3⃣ The author's search was not systematic—it was limited to one database and the English language.
This was also only a "consensus statement" of the 13 expert authors which was not endorsed by any international specialist society—this is considered the weakest form of evidence. 
 
4⃣ Certainly, further well-designed studies, a proper systematic review, and consensus among international specialist societies is needed before clinical practice guidelines are updated regarding the use of acetaminophen in pregnancy.
 
5⃣ Further, if the authors were worried about the association between acetaminophen use and neurodevelopmental outcomes, why wasn’t there a focus on early childhood exposure to acetaminophen? This oversight only perpetuates the culture of blame & guilt that exists in pregnancy.

See comment below for remainder of caption and POINTS 6-10

caption:
Today, on September 30th, we commemorate the lost children and survivors of residential schools. This day was created on June 5th 2021, following the devastating discovery of 215 children found at a former Kamloops residential school. To date, the Truth and Reconciliation Commission documented 4,118 children who passed away in residential schools. This number is continuing to grow as we learn more. 

In honour of National Day for Truth and Reconciliation, we are sharing quotes from a recent Lancet commentary by Dr. Richardson and Dr. Boozary discussing the urgent need for reconciliation in Canadian health care.

As healthcare workers and allies, we must continuously ask ourselves what reconciliation means and what we can do to support decolonising work. While this commentary helps highlight these points, it also provides a brief history behind residential schools and an introduction into the Truth and Reconciliation Commission (TRC) report and Calls to Action.

We commit at PPG to take today and every day to learn about Indigenous histories and health. It is only together and through our collective knowledge that we can provide Indigenous peoples with the quality of care that is the right of every individual.

Dr. Richardson and Dr. Boozary conclude “All Canadians and the global community need to stand with Indigenous peoples so that our children and grandchildren can live together in health, dignity, and prosperity.” 

To read the full article, visit: https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(21)01953-X/fulltext

Link to find TRC report and Calls to Action: https://nctr.ca/records/reports/

#pandemicpregnancy #maternalhealth #indigenoushealth #truthandreconciliation

caption:
Since the start of the pandemic, there have been reports of skyrocketing cannabis sales, not only in the U.S., but here in Canada as well.
⠀
For today’s #MedicalMonday, we are sharing a study published in @jamanetwork comparing the use of cannabis during pregnancy before and during the COVID-19 pandemic.
⠀
The study looked at a group of 100,005 pregnant individualsin California between Jan 2019 and Dec 2020. Urine toxicology screening was performed in the prenatal period around 8 weeks gestation. Cannabis use was found to have increased from 6.75% pre-pandemic to 8.14% during the pandemic. According to their statistical analysis, this was equivalent to a 25% increase in cannabis consumption in pregnancy during the pandemic.
⠀
Canadian data is currently limited. A smaller study of 7040 Canadian pregnant individuals found no increased use in cannabis consumption in pregnancy during the pandemic. However, this study was different in that it was a considerably smaller sample and based off of patient reports rather than urine tests.
⠀
Nevertheless, providers should continue to screen and counsel on cannabis use during pregnancy. Cannabis can contain over 400 active ingredients, some of which the effect on the fetus is unknown. The two main active ingredients, THC and CBD, are known to cross the placenta. Studies have shown an increased risk in low birth weight, stillbirth, preterm birth, and impaired neurodevelopment leading to long-term effects in childhood, adolescence, and adulthood.
⠀
Bottom line: There is no known safe amount or duration of time of cannabis use during pregnancy.
⠀

caption:
Today and everyday, we at PPG are honouring the many families who have experienced pregnancy or infant loss. At 7pm, we lit a candle in remembrance of the babies lost too soon. We acknowledge that this loss is profound and can trigger a ripple effect of change through families and communities.We will continue advocating in healthcare for comprehensive supports for those who have experienced pregnancy or infant loss.
⠀
In honour of this day, we will be hearing next week from Michelle LaFontaine, who is a bereaved mother and program manager at the Pregnancy and Infant Loss (PAIL) Network. We will also be hearing from a panel at Bereaved Families of Ontario. If you have any questions for these groups please post them in the comments below or DM us privately.
⠀
We see you. We honour you. We honour all the babies lost.

Leave a ❤️ below in the comments for those who have gone through this loss.  We are in this together.

caption:
For #MEDICALMONDAY, we are sharing a study published in @greenjrnl helping answer the question whether vaccinated pregnant patients remain at high risk for severe disease. This is one of the most common questions we’ve been getting on @pandemicpregnancyguide , especially for those who are double vaccinated and wondering if patients with breakthrough infection (COVID-19 infection after 2-dose vaccine series) remain at high risk for severe disease.

The study observed a total of 10,092 pregnant patients in Louisiana. 1,332 patients were vaccinated while 8,760 were incompletely vaccinated or unvaccinated. 

The vaccinated pregnant individuals had LOWER ODDS of severe or critical COVID-19 disease or COVID-19 of any severity during the Delta predominant 4th wave of COVID-19.

In the unvaccinated group, there was 1 maternal death due to COVID-19 complications and 6 stillbirths, 3 of which occurred in patients who had COVID-19 infection earlier in the pregnancy. 

Bottom line: Study shows an association between COVID-19 vaccination and LOWER ODDS of severe or critical COVID-19 disease and COVID-19 of any severity in pregnant patients during the Delta variant-predominant 4th surge of COVID-19. 

Limitations include that this study identified a low vaccination rate among pregnant patients (13.2%). Further studies are needed to understand the risk of breakthrough infections in pregnancy.

caption:
During the COVID-19 pandemic, routine in school-based vaccination programs, such as the HPV (Human Papilloma Virus) vaccine have been temporarily suspended. The HPV vaccine has been shown to decrease the risk of cervical cancer. In honour of Canadian #cervicalcancerawarenessweek (October 25-30, 2021) and #MedicalMonday, we are sharing this letter by Dr. Milena Forte and our own PPG student @laurdiamond that addresses the importance of catch-up vaccination programs.

Teenagers who were scheduled to complete their vaccination schedule in 2020 or 2021 did not have access to their in school vaccinations due to the temporary suspension. Subsequently, attendance at catch-up vaccination clinics has been low. The main students affected by the suspension would have been in grade seven in the 2019/2020 and 2020/2021 academic years. “Adequate catch up vaccination is unlikely to happen without a coordinated, school-based approach.” 

It’s also important to highlight that school-based vaccination programs allow for more equitable vaccine uptake.  This is especially important given the well-established increased burden of cervical cancer and reduced cervical cancer screening in low-income communities.  

We at @PandemicPregnancyGuide are advocating for women’s health that the government and public health put a plan in place to catch up on the vaccination schedule.

caption:
This week is the province’s ‘blitz week’ for pregnant and breastfeeding individuals, and those planning to become pregnant, in an attempt to increase Cvid-19 vac*ination rates amongst this vulnerable population. 
 
Despite the safety and efficacy of CVID-19 vac*ines and the heightened risk for pregnant individuals who contract CVID-19, vac*ination rates among pregnant individuals have remained consistently low with most recent data showing only 68% of pregnant individuals have received a first dose of the vac*ine and 59.8% are fully vac*inated in Ontario. 
 
The Ontario Ministry has been working closely with provincial stakeholders and experts in the field, putting out tailored messaging about CVID-19 vaccines and pregnancy, promoting the safety of CVID-19 vaccines for pregnant and breastfeeding individuals and raising awareness of the heightened risks for those who are unvaccinated.

Many people have been asking for details on the Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine trial in kids ages 5-11. The trial was published today (Nov 9, 21) in NEJM. We have included key components of the study in the following slides so you can read through and save as a reference for yourself.

TL:DR:  The data indicate very high efficacy (91%), a strong immune response, and absence of any serious side effects in 2,286 participants.
Tonight we welcomed our new team members to PPG!  We are excited to continue providing you with up-to-date information on pregnancy to parenting through the pandemic and beyond.

BORN Ontario has released a 3rd report on their findings on COVID-19 vaccination during pregnancy in Ontario. This report looks at vaccine coverage in people who were pregnant at any point between December 14, 2020 and September 30, 2021.

➡️During this time 64,234 pregnant individuals received at least one dose of the COVID-19 vaccine.
➡️Among pregnant individuals in September 2021, 58.7% had received at least ONE dose, 52.1% had received TWO doses, and 41.3% had not received any doses of the COVID-19 vaccine.
➡️62.8% of those ≥35 years of age had received at least one dose of the vaccine before or during pregnancy. 36.3% of those <25 years of age had received at least one dose.
➡️COVID-19 vaccination rates differed by income quintile. In the lowest income quintile, 56.1% of pregnant individuals received at least one dose of the vaccine. In the highest income quintile, 72.1% of pregnant individuals received at least one dose.
➡️Among people who were unvaccinated before or during pregnancy, and gave birth by July 31, 2021, about 32% remained unvaccinated as of September 30, 2021.

You can read the full report here: https://www.bornontario.ca/en/whats-happening/resources/Documents/BORN-COVID-19-Vaccination-during-pregnancy-in-Ontario_Report3.pdf

caption:
We’ve had many questions about the Omicron variant, so today for #MedicalMonday, we’re sharing what we know so far as of today (November 29, 2021).

The new COVID variant AKA Omicron was designated a variant of concern last week by the World Health Organization. This means that Omicron has some concerning mutations that MAY be impacting the behaviour of the virus. While it is possible that these mutations could increase transmissibility of the virus or disease severity, we do not have enough evidence yet to say for sure.

There is some early evidence showing that current vaccines work to prevent severe disease from Omicron, but we need more research in this area as well.

Bottom line: There is a lot of ongoing research to better understand Omicron. We do not know how it impacts pregnancy or kids yet so please stay tuned. We will keep you updated as we learn more. And remember, all our public health measures still apply: wear a well fitted mask, practice frequent hand hygiene, self-isolate if you are sick/exposed, and avoid crowds when possible. Finally, consider getting your COVID vaccine, if you haven’t yet.

Please share any questions you might have about Omicron below⬇️. We’ll do our best to answer them as we learn more.

caption:
December 1st is World Aids Day, an international day dedicated to raising awareness about the HIV epidemic, increasing HIV knowledge, speaking out against HIV stigma and continuing the fight against HIV worldwide. Today, we are providing information about the importance of testing for HIV in pregnancy, as well as how to decrease mother-to-child transmission of HIV during pregnancy and delivery. Early awareness of HIV status can help you make informed choices during pregnancy to decrease passing on HIV infection to your baby, while ensuring a healthy pregnancy. By following these guidelines, there is a less than 1% chance of transmitting HIV to your baby. For further information about HIV in pregnancy visit: https://www.cdc.gov/hiv/group/gender/pregnantwomen/index.html

caption:
#MedicalMonday: A recent preprint study investigating the presence of COVID-19 neutralizing antibodies in breastmilk of vaccinated lactating mothers and the transfer of passive immunity to breastfeeding infants. The study enrolled 30 lactating women who received an mRNA-based COVID-19 vaccine (20 received Pfizer, 10 received Moderna) between January and April 2021. Serial milk samples were collected before vaccination, across 2-3 weeks after the first dose, and across 3 weeks after the second dose. Women also provided blood samples after the first and second dose. Stool samples from breastfed infants aged 7 days to 21.7 months old were collected 21 days after mothers received their second dose. These samples were compared to pre-pandemic samples of milk, blood, and infant stool from prior studies.

Milk samples were tested for the presence of neutralizing antibodies against the COVID-19 spike protein and 4 variants of concern: D614G, alpha, beta, and gamma (delta was not tested). These new genetic variants of concern from the original COVID-19 sequence are associated with increased infectivity and enhanced transmissibility. Stool samples from 24 infants aged 55 days to 11 months were also assessed for detection of anti IgA and IgG antibodies. 

It was found that breast milk from vaccinated mothers contained elevated levels of antibodies against COVID-19 spike protein, resulting in significantly increased neutralizing ability as compared to their matched pre-vaccine milk samples. The neutralizing ability of milk was significant against the spike protein and all four VOCs, though there was  considerable variability among women. Additionally, presence of antibodies against COVID-19 spike protein in the stool of breastfed infants was detected for the first time in a research study. Detection of these antibodies suggest potential protection of infants from COVID-19.

caption:
On #December6 we at PPG reflect on those who have experienced and been impacted by gender based violence. Gender-based violence continues to be a daily reality for many women, girls and LGBTQ2S+ individuals across the world. Today serves as a reminder of the importance of challenging the culture that allows gender-based violence to persist and taking action to advocate for changes that create safe and accessible spaces for all, regardless of gender identity. 

On the National Day of Remembrance and Action on Violence Against Women we acknowledge the reality that gender-based violence continues to persist and has widespread impacts, ranging from health to economic and social costs to all. In marking the murder of 14 young women at École Polytechnique 32 years ago today, we honour the memory of these women and are reminded of the work that must continue to be done, standing up and speaking out against gender-based violence. As women’s health physicians and advocates we make a commitment to continue to watch for signs of abuse among patients, colleagues and those in our communities. We are reminded of our duty to not only educate others on gender-based violence, but further, to provide assistance to those who need it. 

#endvaw #endgbv #ecolepolytechnique #rememberthe14 #vaw #weremember

A recent Statistics Canada report outlines how family planning, birth rates and fertility rates have changed throughout COVID-19 pandemic. The report indicates that the pandemic has had an impact on fertility planning amongst Canadians, which is evident in declining birth and fertility rates across the country. The report also outlines factors that might explain these changes to family planning, including economic factors, rising costs of living, access to social supports, and general uncertainty surrounding the changing conditions of the pandemic.  

Not all Canadians are impacted by these factors in the same way - individuals without children, individuals from visible minority groups, and those living in Ontario were reported more likely to want fewer children or to delay having children. In a recent interview with @globalnews PPG’s very own Dr. Tali Bogler comments on the impact she has seen within her own practice, with more families cancelling or delaying family planning, or making decisions to reduce initially-planned family sizes in response to pandemic-related factors.

Most notably, it is likely that these declines in birth and fertility rates will be seen in population-level trends for years to come. Dr. Bogler explains that while delaying pregnancy by 1-2 is not something to be generally concerned about, the longer the delay (given that Canada is already a "late-childbearing country"), this might potentially lead to a growing number of individuals/couples encountering age-related infertility issues and not achieving their desired family size. 

Has the COVID-19 pandemic altered your fertility plans? If you’re willing to share, please tell us how/so and why in the comments section…

https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/n1/pub/45-28-0001/2021001/article/00041-eng.html
https://globalnews.ca/news/8420794/covid-19-less-babies-canada/

Excerpt from @thetorontostar article, featuring our very own, @drtalibogler: 

"Last winter, after Canadian health officials released initial guidance on who was eligible for COVID-19 vaccines, Dr. Tali Bogler knew she would need to advocate for her pregnant patients.

As chair of family medicine obstetrics at St. Michael’s Hospital, Bogler was alarmed that pregnant individuals — especially essential workers and health-care providers who could not stay safe at home — were at first excluded from getting the shot.

Bogler immediately pushed for pregnant people to have access, raising her concerns at the provincial level, in the local hospital system and on social media, where she has a prominent voice as co-founder of the Instagram account @pandemicpregnancyguide (PPG).

“I just felt I had to do what was best for my patients,” she said, noting evidence quickly accumulated that COVID vaccines are safe and effective in pregnancy. “They are a vulnerable group and I wanted to do whatever was in my power to ensure they were better protected.”

In April, the province prioritized pregnant individuals for vaccines after an alarming number of pregnant patients were in hospital critically ill with the virus.

Since then, Bogler has continued to speak up for pregnant people and uses PPG to provide evidence-based advice on why COVID vaccines are vital during pregnancy. With Omicron surging and only about 70 per cent of pregnant people in Ontario having received two doses, Bogler has no plans to stop.

“When someone comes up to me at a mass vaccination clinic because they recognize me, and says ‘Thank you. I’m here because of you,’ that is the most meaningful to me. That is what keeps me going.”

—Megan Ogilvie"

One of the most common questions we have been receiving is whether pregnant individuals are still at risk for severe illness with a breakthrough infection after vaccination. Up until now, we’ve had very little data thus far. 

New study by Morgan et al. published in Obstetrics and Gynecology looked at this exact question.
* Retrospective cohort study looked at the incidence of severe or critical COVID-19 illness in vaccinated versus unvaccinated pregnant individuals during the Delta variant-predominant 4th surge
* A total of 10,092 pregnant patients: 1,332 vaccinated patients and 8,760 incompletely vaccinated or unvaccinated patients
* The vaccinated group included patients who were fully vaccinated 2 weeks before the start of the study period.
RESULTS:
* Vaccinated patients had lower odds of severe or critical COVID-19 and COVID-19 of any severity
* In the unvaccinated group there was one maternal death secondary to COVID-19 complications and six stillbirths, three of which occurred in patients who had SARS-CoV-2 infection earlier in the pregnancy
* When including all partially vaccinated patients who received any doses of the vaccine before the study, an association between vaccinated status and lower odds of severe or critical COVID- and COVID-19 of any severity remained.
BOTTOM LINE:
* Study showed an association between COVID-19 vaccination and LOWER ODDS of severe or critical COVID-19 or COVID-19 of any severity
* Breakthrough infection in pregnancy after vaccination appears to be less severe compared to unvaccinated

THAT’S THE POST.

#parentinginapandemic #parenting #parentingquotes

caption:
Many have been asking if COVID-19 vaccination during pregnancy offers protection to your baby once born and what is the best timing to get the vaccine? 

For #MedicalMonday, we are sharing 2 recent studies investigating the timing of COVID-19 vaccines during pregnancy and antibody levels at delivery.

🚨TL;DR The best time to receive the COVID-19 vaccine in your pregnancy is NOW.🚨

Study #1 was published in JAMA Pediatrics by Kugelman et al. 
💉Pregnant women in this study received 2 doses of an mRNA vaccine during the 2nd trimester of pregnancy. This study found that:
➡️Receiving an mRNA vaccine in 2nd trimester was associated with BOTH maternal and neonatal immune responses.
➡️Neonatal (baby’s) antibody levels were 2.6 times higher than maternal antibody levels, and higher maternal antibodies were associated with higher neonatal antibodies.
➡️Maternal and neonatal antibody levels decreased with each week that passed since the second vaccine dose.

1/3

caption:
This week, Ontario’s Chief Medical Officer has asked vaccine clinics to prioritize pregnancy. Getting vaccinated while pregnant can protect not only you but also your infant from COVID-19. Research shows that when vaccinated in pregnancy, antibodies can last in the infant for the first few months of life.

Pregnant individuals have some of the lowest rates of vaccination in the province, despite their risk of severe illness if infected with COVID-19. It is strongly recommended that pregnant individuals get their COVID-19 vaccine, including their booster (third-dose) which they are eligible to receive three months after their primary series (i.e. first and second dose). There is no “right” trimester to get vaccinated. We recommend getting vaccinated as soon as you are eligible.

For those who live in other jurisdictions, please check with your local public health unit or healthcare provider for more information relevant to your area.

Many have been asking if the COVID-19 vaccine has an impact on menstrual cycles and periods -  for #MedicalMonday we are reviewing 3 research studies that investigate this potential link.💉💭

❗️TLDR: Menstrual cycles are not always exact, and can change cycle to cycle due to a number of factors. There are three studies from 3 different countries that we present that all show similar findings: the COVID-19 vaccine was not associated with major or long-lasting changes to the menstrual cycle.❗️

➡️Two of the 3 studies showed that the COVID-19 vaccine produced minimal changes to menstruation and one of the studies showed NO impact.
➡️The most recent study published in Obstetrics and Gynecology (Study #3)  found a small statistically significant increase (i.e., periods were approximately 0.5 days longer after the 2nd vaccine and closer to 2 days if both doses were given in the same cycle); however, this change was short lasting and period lengths returned to normal in subsequent cycles. While some media headlines have obscured this finding saying that the study showed “an IMPACT on menstruation,” it is important to distinguish between statistical significance and clinical significance. In the context of menstrual cycles, clinical/medical significance is when someone has an increased menstrual length by more than 8 days. 
➡️The study did not investigate changes to period heaviness or cramping (which anecdotally, we know people have reported) 

These studies bring up a really important lesson for clinical research: the effects of medical interventions on menstruation should not be an afterthought, and instead, monitored in future research and clinical trials, including trials of COVID-19 vaccines. This information is important to allow patients to plan for potentially altered cycles if applicable. We applaud the scientists who contributed to these studies and investigated this potential association -  concerns regarding menstrual changes post-vaccination are important! Further well-designed prospective studies, similar to Study #3, are needed in order to further study other outcomes like menstrual heaviness, which have been reported online as well.

caption:
The start to 2022 has been tough. 

We reached out to the PPG community, asking you to share the things that are helping you get through each day, whether big or small, and the moments that remain highlights amidst these difficult times. We were incredibly overwhelmed with the amount of responses we received, and wanted to share a few of them with you, our community. 

From self care tips, to encouraging messages, and highlights of the week, we are so empowered by the ways you continue to demonstrate resilience and make the best out of this immensely difficult time. We are so thankful for this community, and are so grateful for each and every one of you that are a part of it. 

We’re in this together 🤍

Updated guidance: symptomatic pregnant individuals are now eligible and prioritized for PCR or rapid molecular testing for COVID-19 infection. 

Thank you to everyone who advocated on the importance of access to COVID-19 testing for the pregnant population!

For #medicalmonday, we’re sharing this excellent summary by @sciencewhizliz on a new study that came out in Nature last week.

****************************************************
Repost @sciencewhizliz :

As an 18 week vaccinated pregnant woman, this has been more of the data I’ve been combing the literature and waiting for. So I’m glad to be able to share it with the rest of you today. A new study JUST came out in Nature yesterday titled "SARS-CoV-2 infection and COVID-19 vaccination rates in pregnant women in Scotland"

This study looked at vaccination rate for pregnant people in Scotland, as well as outcomes of infection between unvaccinated and vaccinated patients.

Data was through October 31st, 2021. So BEFORE omicron.

Swipe through slides for details of the study but summary below:

Between December 2020 and October 2021, there were 4,950 confirmed COVID-19 cases in pregnancy.

> 77.4% of cases occurred in those unvaccinated. 19.5% associated with hospital admission. 2.7% associated with critical care admission.

> 11.5% in partially vaccinated. 8.3% associated with hospital admission. 0.2% associated with critical care

> 11.1% in fully vaccinated. 5.1% associated with hospital admission. 0.2% associated with critical care.

Even though unvaccinated account for 77.4% of pregnancy cases, they accounts for 90% of hospital admissions & 98% of critical care admissions.

[Other pregnancy outcomes]

> 11 still births, and 8 neonatal deaths occurred in those unvaccinated. 10 stillbirths and 4 neonatal deaths were within 28 days of the infection.

> NO stillbirths or neonatal deaths reported in those vaccinated.

> Rate of pre-term birth was 16.6 per 100 live births for COVID-19 infection within 28 days of delivery. For those who received the COVID-19 vaccine pre-term rate was 8.6/100 births. Background rate with no confirmed COVID was 7.9/100 births.
[1/2]

caption:
People still have questions about the COVID-19 vaccine and fertility. For #MedicalMonday, we are breaking down a recent study that shows that the COVID-19 vaccine does NOT impact fertility. 

‼️TLDR; a prospective cohort study found:‼️
-no association between female and male partner fertility following COVID-19 VACCINATION
- no association between female fertility following COVID-19 INFECTION
- short-term (<60 day) association between male partner fertility following COVID-19 INFECTION.

The study recruited 2,126 females aged 21-45 years old, who were living in United States or Canada, and trying to conceive without fertility treatment. Participants completed a baseline questionnaire and then completed follow-up questionnaires every 8 weeks over the period of December 2020 to September 2021. The comprehensive questionnaire asked about COVID-19 infection and vaccination status, sociodemographic (i.e., household income, education, health insurance, etc.), and lifestyle information (i.e. partner information, body mass index, intercourse frequency, doing something to improve chances of conception, sleep duration), and many more variables! Patient partners (male) were also invited to participate and complete the questionnaire. 

The authors then took all of these variables and created several models to assess whether the variables (i.e., vaccination, infection, and fertility) were related and/or whether the other information collected (i.e., the socioeconomic and lifestyle information) explained the trends seen. 

The study found (1) that COVID-19 vaccination status had no association with reduced fertility in either female or male partners, (2) that COVID-19 Infection was not associated with declined female fertility, and (3) that COVID-19 Infection was associated with short-term (<60 days) decline in fertility for male partners who tested positive. However, it is important to note that the short-term decline in male fertility following a COVID-19 infection was not seen in all male partners infected with COVID-19. It is also important to not that there was NO ADVERSE association between COVID-19 Infection and male fertility >60 days after infection. [1/2]

caption:
With school closures and the recent Omicron wave, this has been a difficult start to 2022 for so many. Parents and parents-to-be are struggling with their mental health right now. This is why we’re doing a mental health check-in with Dr. Tanya Cotler (@drcotler, Clinical Psychologist) on Wednesday, January 26th at 8pm EST.  It’s also Bell Let’s Talk Day so we hope this helps to raise awareness, allows us to speak more openly about mental health concerns and gives space to feel more connected.  Dr. Cotler will be sharing her insights on:

* Strategies on how to cope with a chronically activated nervous system
* Tips on how to calm and get grounded when feeling activated (fight/flight) and how to activate when feeling deadened, immobilized in fear (freeze)
* How to help our kids with constant changes and at the same time helping ourselves cope
* How to navigate decision fatigue 
* How to cope with feelings of anxiety regarding birth plans during the pandemic and uncertainties for expecting parents

Please join us for this important LIVE (it will be saved for those who cannot attend).  We hope this will bring you some comfort and tools to help navigate this challenging time.  We’re with you through this and will continue to support you as best we can.  If you have any specific questions for Dr. Cotler, please comment below and share widely.

Thank you to @drcotler for sharing her insights on how to cope and foster resilience during this challenging time. This is one to save and rewatch when you need it. @drsheilaw does get the camera orientation corrected within seconds!
