caption:
Exploring the experiences that underlie postpartum mental health struggles during the pandemic.

*The mental health of postpartum women has worsened during the COVID-19 pandemic*. This new CMAJ article examines how women in Canada have been affected by policies aimed at limiting social contact postpartum.

The main implications of COVID-19 policies aimed at reducing social contact postpartum: 
➡️ Negative postpartum experience in hospital
➡️ Poor postpartum mental health
➡️ Stress asking for help 
➡️ Breastfeeding problems

Bottom Line: IF YOU ARE STRUGGLING, YOU ARE NOT ALONE. Restricting the presence of support persons in hospital and at home appear to have negative consequences on mental health, breastfeeding success, and well-being and safety while in hospital.  Considerations to mitigate harm should be considered when developing policies to protect against transmission of COVID-19 during hospital stay at birth and during the postpartum period. 

See the full article here: https://www.cmajopen.ca/content/9/2/E556

How are you coping with the restrictions in place for delivery? Or if you’ve already delivered, what was helpful for you with these restrictions in place?  Please share in the comments so we can learn from each other.

 **Check out our LIVE with @drcotler (Jan 26, 2022)  that addressed coping with some of the uncertainty of this time with grounding techniques and a comfort toolkit for the time of deliver.

Many people have been wondering whether it is safe to breastfeed following COVID-19 infection. For #MedicalMonday, we are sharing a recent cohort study of 110 women (the largest number of breast milk samples analyzed to date from women with recent COVID-19 infection) that found no infectious COVID-19 virus in the breast milk of lactating individuals. This indicates that recent COVID-19 infection or detection in human milk is not a contraindication to breastfeeding.

So, what should you do if you are breastfeeding and have Covid-19?
Here are 10 helpful tips. Thanks to lactation consultant, @Sofyabrainin for reviewing.

1.	Don’t panic - keep calm and feed on (we have evidence that infectious virus is not found in breast milk)!
2.	Wear a good mask (ideally KN95/N95) when caring for your baby and while breastfeeding.
3.	Practice good hand hygiene before and after caring for baby.
4.	Monitor your baby for signs/symptoms of COVID-19.
5.	Protect your supply by drinking lots of fluids, rest, and adequate breast stimulation (pump as much as you can (only if you can) approximately 8 sessions/day & 10-15 mins/session). If your supply dips while you are ill, don’t worry, you can get it back up once recovered.
6.	Don’t worry if you can't breastfeed while ill, you can always pick it up once you are feeling better. If you are ill, but able to, pump at least 4x/day to help prevent against engorgement/mastitis. 
7.	If you are too ill to breastfeed, ask another adult to feed and care for your baby.
8.	Stored breast milk/formula can be used as a suitable alternative while you are ill.
9.	Reach out to your healthcare provider if you need additional support around feeding or with you or your baby’s health.
10.	Remember, if you got vaccinated in your pregnancy, your baby likely has antibodies against COVID-19.

caption:
The transition to parenthood is tough. The shift from our previous identities, potential changes in relationships, and way of life can have a toll on our sense of self.  Please join us to discuss how to reflect and address this transition with @hello.wellbe 's Tiffany Lewis, RSW, MSW, Social Worker + Psychotherapist on February 9 at 8pm LIVE (will be saved).

Tiffany’s journey to becoming a social worker was largely inspired by her daughter. When she gave birth to her little one, she realized she didn’t know a thing about being a mom and wanted to learn more about child development—particularly the teenage years. This led her to pursue a Master's Degree in social work, and the rest is history. 

She now specializes in perinatal mental health as well as adolescent and young adult development, having previously worked in transitional housing programs, and uses an eclectic approach rooted in various theories and techniques when working with clients. She brings compassion and understanding, particularly when it comes to working with underserved and undervalued populations in relation to systemic and institutional racism, and is currently completing her Doctorate in Social Work with her capstone project emphasizing the need for equal access to mental health services for these populations.

“At the best of times, pregnancy can be stressful. COVID makes it more so. 

If you are pregnant, you’re likely worried about getting COVID and anxious about what that would mean for your health and the health of your baby. That is all understandable.

You may also have questions about the safety of receiving a COVID vaccine during your pregnancy.”

We are sharing an excellent graphic from our colleagues at the Ontario College of Family Physicians and the Department of Family and Community Medicine at the University of Toronto, which answers some important questions: 
➡️ How does COVID affect pregnant people?
➡️ How do I take care of myself and my baby if I have COVID? 
➡️ Do I still need the vaccine if I already had COVID?
➡️ How can I keep safe?
➡️ How will I know if I have COVID? What do I do if I get COVID?

It is important to remember that vaccination remains the best protection against COVID-19 for pregnant, reducing the severity of illness and transmission.

Please listen in our conversation with @tiffanylewisrsw from @hello.wellbe with @drsheilaw.  Tiffany guided us through how to navigate the many roles we carry and the shift in identity that we face as new parents.  This is an incredibly validating discussion that we all need to hear ❤️

We touched upon:
-Reconciling our new parenting identity with our pre-parenting self
-How to reframe and set goals and surrender to ‘good enough’
-Navigating conversations with partners and friends and why and how to ask for help
-How to navigate the guilt that comes with wanting a self and a life
-How the pandemic has shifted our supports and how to still do self-care (how this may look different) and get the support we need.

What have you found helpful in this transition to parenthood?  Please share in the comments so we can learn from each other…

She now specializes in perinatal mental health as well as adolescent and young adult development, having previously worked in transitional housing programs, and uses an eclectic approach rooted in various theories and techniques when working with clients. She brings compassion and understanding, particularly when it comes to working with underserved and undervalued populations in relation to systemic and institutional racism, and is currently completing her Doctorate in Social Work with her capstone project emphasizing the need for equal access to mental health services for these populations.  You can find her at @hello.wellbe

caption:
We’ve previously shared data about fertility rates and changes in fertility intentions during the COVID-19 pandemic in Canada. Why is this happening, and what impact could this have on Canadian economy and society? We’re sharing this interesting discussion from @weareTVO @Theagendatvo that explores this topic, and features our very own @drtalibogler, Chair of Family Medicine Obstetrics at St. Michael’s Hospital @unityhealthto. Other panelists include @Marina_Adshade, economist at @universityofbc; Laura Wright, family demographer and associate professor of sociology at @usask; @jpibbitson, writer at large for @globeandmail and co-author of “Empty Planet: The Shock of Global Population Decline.”

@drtalibogler reviews 3 common themes that are often brought up that might have influenced a change in fertility intentions:
1️⃣ UNCERTAINTY: economic uncertainty, general uncertainty about the future, and the uncertainty/fear around COVID-19 infection on a pregnancy and fetus.
2️⃣ DISRUPTION to the health care system and wider social networks:
- Pregnancy and many ancillary services to support people through the pregnancy journey were disrupted, e.g.  breastfeeding supports, support people while in labour, fertility clinics were closed etc.
- Disruptions to wider social supports and sense of isolation. Also with school closures, lack of support with older children in the home. 
3️⃣ Impact on MENTAL HEALTH of young people particularly women in reproductive age groups (15-44) and those with kids < 15 years-old have reported higher levels of distress according to STATS CAN; also studies (including one of our own published in @cfpjournal) demonstrating higher levels of distress in those who have been pregnant during the pandemic. 

➡️ Watch the video to hear more of the discussion.

caption:
A common question we receive is: “how long will antibodies last in my baby if I was vaccinated during pregnancy?”

For #medicalmonday, we are sharing a recent study published in @jamanetwork that looked at pregnant women who received mRNA COVID-19 vaccine OR were infected with COVID-19 at 20-32 weeks’ gestation.

Findings: 
1️⃣Vaccinated mothers had significantly HIGHER antibody levels at delivery compared to COVID-19 infected mothers 2️⃣Umbilical cord (i.e. baby’s blood at birth) antibody levels were HIGHER  in newborns of vaccinated mothers 3️⃣At 6 months of life, 57% (16 of 28) of infants born to vaccinated mothers had detectable antibodies compared with 8% (1 of 12) of infants born to infected mothers (P = .005). 4️⃣(at 2 months, 98% of infants born to vaccinated mothers had detectable antibodies) 
IMPORTANCE:
Given that we do not currently have a COVID-19 vaccine for infants and we saw an uptick of newborns being admitted to hospitals during the omicron wave, these findings, demonstrating the persistence of antibodies in babies at ~6 months of life, add another strong reason to get vaccinated in pregnancy.

Study limitations include the small number of infants, the longer mean time to follow-up in the infected group (due to pragmatic constraints related to timing of COVID-19 surges in Boston and availability of participants for timely follow-up), and the reporting of antibody titers rather than clinical outcomes.

caption:
We were going to cover the new CDC report, but thanks to @sciencewhizliz, we now don't need to!

Repost from @sciencewhizliz 

The CDC just released a report looking at how much maternal vaccination in pregnancy might reduce the risk that the baby will be hospitalized from COVID-19 if under 6 months old. 

Other data has shown that antibodies can pass through the placenta, but how much protection this offers has been unclear. This data set gives us the first preliminary findings on this issue, but more data will continue to help clarify.

To look at this question they compared the odds of the pregnant person having completed two doses mRNA vaccine series during pregnancy if their child under 6 months was hospitalized with COVID-19 between July 2021-Jan 2022.

Having received two doses of a COVID-19 vaccine in pregnancy was associated with decreased risk of hospitalization in babies less than 6 months after birth. Vaccine effectiveness was as indicated below:

> Anytime in pregnancy: 61%
> Before 20 weeks: 32%*
> 21 weeks or later: 80%

Limitations:
> Could not look at omicron specific data. 
> Did not include women vaccinated before pregnancy but boosted during pregnancy. 
> Data set was small, so unable to get more accurate results on differences in what trimester vaccine was administered in. 
> Did not take into account prior infection (aka hybrid immunity).
> Could not account for potential differences in behavior of the pregnant person. But they did control for age, admissions date and race.

We have ample data that being vaccinated in pregnancy reduces risk to the pregnant person and their unborn child. We also know that the baby receives antibodies through the placenta that persist after birth. 

This data set, while small, gives us some of the first data suggesting how much protection those passive antibodies might supply. We need more data to clarify this issue and also look at how a booster may impact these results. 

However, we have SO MUCH DATA showing the benefits and safety of vaccines for COVID-19 in pregnancy, this is one additional benefit that should be considered. 
If you're pregnant, please get vaccinated - for yourself and for your baby.

How did you choose your pregnancy care provider⁉️

Are you currently pregnant or did you give birth in the past 5 years? 
🇨🇦 Canadian researchers, including @drtalibogler, are conducting a study to understand the factors that are important to you when choosing a pregnancy care provider. 

For more information or to participate, please visit 👇www.PregnancyCareChoices.ca

caption:
For Black History Month, let’s look at the incredible contributions of Black women to Obstetrics & Gynecology. We acknowledge that many other Black individuals have made significant contributions to the field of Obstetrics & Gynecology, and medicine at large, that have never been recognized. We hope to continue to recognize the incredible impacts made by Black figures to women’s health throughout Black History Month and beyond.

1. Anarcha Westcott, Lucy Zimmerman and Betsey Harris: Mothers of Gynecology
Anarcha, Betsey and Lucy were three enslaved women who worked on plantations in Alabama in the 1840s. James Marion Sims, who is credited as the “father of modern gynecology” performed surgeries on these enslaved Black women, amongst many others, without pain medication, operating under the racist notion that Black people did not feel pain. Sim’s work revolutionized surgical treatments for women, however it must be acknowledged that these advancements were made through the exploitation of Black female bodies.

2. Dr. Helen Octavia Smith (1909-2001): Advocate for Contraception and Sexual Health
Helen Octavia Dickens earned her M.D. at the University of Illinois in 1934 as the only African-American woman in her class. She specialized in Obstetrics & Gynecology and became the first African-American fellow of the American College of Surgeons. She led extensive research into teen pregnancy and sexual health issues and advised schools, parents and health professionals on intervention strategies to reduce the incidence of teen pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases.

3. Henrietta Lacks (1920-1951): Immortal Cells that Changed Medicine.
Henrietta Lacks was a Black patient who was diagnosed with terminal cervical cancer at one of the few hospitals that served Black people in Maryland. Unknowingly, her cells were used for research as they were found to be unique in the way they survived and reproduced. Her cells, now known as HeLa cells, have been used to develop vaccines, in vitro fertilization (IVF) and much more, making them one of the greatest discoveries in modern medicine.

#bhm

caption:
Happy International Women’s Day 2022!

We see you. We support you.

In honor of IWD (and ourselves), PPG is taking a short rest.  We will be back soon, refreshed and excited to continue sharing up-to-date information to support you and your families.  Thank you for trusting us over the past 2 years, we are incredibly humbled by your support and care.

Till then, be safe, be well and take rest when you can.

We would also like to express our deep gratitude to our fantastic team of medical students and residents who are the backbone of our PPG team.  Despite having incredibly busy schedules, they volunteer hours and hours to create and share informative posts you see every week.  Big thank you to Alex, Alison, Cheyanne, Gemma, Hafsa, Isabella, Julia, Kellie, Laura, Meg, Michelle, Morgan, Thalia, Sarah, Sepand, Stephanie and Xin.

Be well ❤️

Eli, Sheila & Tali

With ongoing investigations of COVID-19 vaccination and pregnancy, new research led by Dr. Deshayne Fell has evaluated over 97,000 women in Ontario and demonstrated that receiving the vaccination during pregnancy was not significantly associated with an increased risk of adverse peripartum outcomes. 

Here are some details on the study… 
 
Background:
Pregnant individuals in Ontario were designated a priority population for COVID-19 vaccination in late April 2021. In a project supported by the Public Health Agency of Canada through the Vaccine Surveillance Reference Group and the COVID-19 Immunity Task Force, Ontario’s Better Outcomes Registry & Network (BORN) is evaluating COVID-19 vaccination in pregnancy across the province.
 
Key findings:
	•	Among 97,590 pregnant people who gave birth in Ontario between Dec 14, 2020 (when vaccines were first available) and September 30, 2021:
	•	23% (22,660) received at least one dose of a COVID-19 vaccine during pregnancy
	•	Between those who received COVID-19 vaccination during pregnancy versus those who did not, there were no increases in risk of postpartum hemorrhage, chorioamnionitis, caesarean delivery or emergency cesarean delivery, admission to neonatal intensive care unit and low newborn 5-minute Apgar score

Thank you to Ontario’s Better Outcomes Registry & Network (BORN) for the graphic! (1/2)
